detectable regularities of my own habits of thought.
Rather than criticise this view of variable hypotheticals, I want to draw
attention to a feature of the account which is important, namely its
reliance upon the idea that self-conscious attention to my own mental
processes can yield knowledge of regularities, either of the use of a term
or sentence or – in this particular case – of my own inductive practices.
How does that thought connect to the halves of the other two contrasts
that Ramsey endorses, namely anti-scholasticism and the normative
task of philosophy?
1.2.2 Playing and contravention
Let us return to Ramsey’s remark that compares Wittgenstein’s views
about thought to what someone might say about breaking the rules
of bridge. Here is its moral: whatever the activity of inferringg amounts
to, it must leave room for certain instances of illogical inference, just
as whatever the activity of playing a game amounts to, it must leave
room for certain instances of breaking the rules (what I shall call contra-
vention), where we think of illogical inference and of contravention as
parts of the activities of inferring and of game playing, respectively. In
some cases, but not all, to infer illogically is not to cease to infer, and
to commit a contravention in bridge is not to cease to play bridge.
Indeed, I shall argue that it is integral to these activities – playing a
game and inferring – that such deviation be at all times a live possi-
bility. Of course, there are important differences between logical and
illogical inference, just as there are between legitimate bridge playing
and contravention, but it is not a difference captured by some new
description of the activity – playing not-bridge or ‘not-inferring’ – that
we are involved in.
The analogy between the activity of playing certain games and
of inferring is natural and compelling. That analogy, and the further
analogy between committing a contravention in bridge and inferring
illogically, makes clear an objection to T LP. The charge, ultimately, is

The Realistic Spirit 27
that the conception in TLPP of philosophy as merely a limited kind of
clarificatory activity renders philosophy useless.
Not every case of breaking the rules of bridge is a contravention. When
I play poker, I am not contravening bridge, because I was never playing
bridge; and when in the course of learning to play bridge, I make mistakes
as I go, sometimes forgetting the rules or breaking a rule I have not
yet learned, I am not contravening either, because I am not yet playing
bridge.1 2 This much is obvious when we consider the reactions of the
other players: in neither case am I sanctioned, criticised or penalised,
though I may expect to be corrected. Rather, I commit a contravention
in bridge when I purport to be playing the game according to i ts rules
but fail to follow those rules. And purporting to play bridge according to
its rules is to engage in a number of activities and to undertake a number
of commitments, such as: allowing others to believe that I have won if
the game goes in my favour; accepting the accolades of having won;
conceding to some other party that they have won if it goes against me
(and not, for instance, calling the game invalid because I was contra-
vening a rule throughout); responding with appropriate outrage if the
contraventions of someone else who purported to be playing according
to the rules are revealed, and so forth. In short, giving an account of my
use of the sentence ‘x is playing bridge’ involves self-conscious attention;
occasions on which I am prepared to utter it are occasions on which I
am in possession of a number of discoverable expectations, attitudes
and beliefs. And an account of what it is to play bridge – what is meant
by the sentence ‘x is playing bridge’ – will in part be determined by the
regularities of my mental states that I uncover by reflecting in this way
on the use made of the sentence. I say ‘in part’ because it will not be suffi-
cient for my playing bridge on some occasion that I am in possession of
those states, just as in the case of asserting a variable hypothetical, it will
not be sufficient that I be subject to a known psychological law. There
will also have to be certain singular facts of which I am aware; and, in
playing bridge, there will also have to be certain facts of my experience,
such as that I have a partner, am dealt a hand and so forth.
The notions of committing a contravention in a game and playing a
game are closely tied. I said above that not every case of breaking the
rules of bridge is a case of contravention. But it is prima facie plausible
that every case of legitimate bridge playing is at least a potential case
of contravention. What I mean is that I can only be playing bridge on
a particular occasion if it is the case that I know what would count as
a contravention of that game on that occasion. That is, it is a neces-
sary condition on my playing bridge on some occasion that I be in a

28 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
position to tell what it would be for this bid that I am now making, for
instance, to be an illegitimate b id. The italics are important: I am not
talking about knowing what it would be to do s omethingg illegitimate,
such as throwing my cards in the air or taking off my clothes, but rather
about knowing what would be an illegitimate move which would, none-
theless, not relieve me of the commitments I had undertaken nor of the
expectations had of me by the other players.1 3
I cannot know what will count as a contravention of the rules if I do
not understand what it is to proceed in accordance with a rule of that
game; but, similarly, I cannot be playing the game if I do not know
this much.1 4 Someone who spent an hour at a bridge table with three
bridge players and who called out the first thing that came into his mind
on his ‘turn’ would not be playing bridge, even if each of those things
happened to be an appropriate bridge call. Likewise, I cannot know
what would count as a contravention if I am not in a position to identify
whether someone else had proceeded in accordance with its rules or not;
nor can I be said to be playing bridge in those circumstances. Further,
a computer that is programmed to make certain moves in response to
certain inputs is not playing bridge so much as simulating someone’s
playing the game.
Knowing what would count as a contravention is the analogue of a
known psychological law in the case of induction. There, the discover-
able regularities in my inductive practice yield knowledge of that psycho-
logical law, knowledge that is witnessed by my being able to say what I
would assert in the face of certain hypothetical singular facts. Likewise,
the discoverable regularities associated with my use of the sentence
‘x is playing bridge’ yield knowledge of a rule that governs its meaning,
knowledge that is witnessed by my being able to say what I would assert
in the face of certain singular facts.
Turning now to inference: do the same relationships exist? Not every
case of violating the laws of logic in thought is a case of illogical infer-
ence. When I think to myself that ‘Socrates is identical’ follows from
‘Identity has two legs’, I am not inferringg illogically, because I am not
inferring at all (assuming that inference, as opposed to the cognate
syntactic notion, must involve a content). And when, if I am learning
to differentiate valid from invalid arguments, I affirm the consequent, I
am not inferring i llogicallyy but participating in a process of training and
correction the aim of which is to introduce me to the rules of good infer-
ence via exemplars which take the form of dummy inferences. As with
contravention, it seems that I am only thinking illogically if I purport to
think in a manner which is subject to logical norms and yet fails to be

The Realistic Spirit 29
bound by them (and learning to recognise the difference between valid
and invalid arguments is precisely to acquire those norms). Purporting
to think in a manner which is subject to logical norms is to engage in
a number of activities and to undertake a number of commitments: for
example: expecting others to endorse my conclusion if they endorse
my premises and if my argument is valid; committing myself to infer
on future occasions as I have on this one; revising my inference if it is
shown to be fallacious by my own lights (and not, for instance, calling
my opponent’s argument invalid because I have all along invoked a
different standard of validity); seeking to correct the inferences of others
whose arguments are not valid by my own lights, and so forth. In short,
giving an account of ‘x infers q from p’ involves self-conscious attention;
occasions on which I am prepared to utter it are occasions upon which
I am in possession of a number of discoverable expectations, attitudes
and beliefs. And an account of what it is to infer – what I mean by that
sentence – will in part be determined by regularities in my mental states
that I uncover by reflecting in this way on the use that is made of the
sentence. Again, I say ‘in part’ because it will not, of course, be sufficient
for my inferring on such an occasion that I be in possession of those
states.
It is also prima facie plausible that, while not every case of violating
the laws of logic in thought is a case of illogical inference, every case of
inference is at least a potential case of illogical inference. Once again,
what I mean is that I can be inferring logically on some occasion only
if I know what it would be to infer illogically on that occasion – that is,
that I be in a position to tell what it would be for my inference to fail to
meet the appropriate norms. (Again, the italics are important: I am not
talking about what it would be to think somethingg illegitimate, some-
thing perhaps caused by my entertaining a certain thought, or some-
thing arrived at arbitrarily, but rather about knowing what would be an
illegitimate thought to infer.) I cannot know what it is to infer illogically
on some occasion if I recognise no logical norms whatsoever – that is, if I
do not understand that thought aims at logical cohesion.15 But similarly,
I cannot be said to be inferring at all if I am in that position. Someone
who regularly thought q after thinking ‘if p then q, and p’ for any p and
qsimply because the appropriate q happened to pop into his head would
not be i nferring. Similarly, I cannot know what it would be to infer illogi-
cally on an occasion when whatever mental activity I am engaged in is
not one that is governed by any logical norms (for instance, when the
content of that activity is not assertoric); nor can I be said to be inferring
in those circumstances.

30 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Knowing what would count as an illogical inference on a particular
occasion is the analogue of the known psychological law in the case
of induction. That is, the discoverable regularities associated with my
use of the sentence ‘x infers q from p ’ demonstrates knowledge of a rule
that governs its meaning, knowledge of which is witnessed by my being
able to say what I would assert in the face of certain singular facts. My
knowing whether I would say that my doing such-and-such in a partic-
ular situation counted as my inferring or not relies upon my knowing
the regularities that govern my use of the sentence.
What notion of w rongg inference, analogous with contravention in
game playing, does Ramsey think an account must allow? What Ramsey
sees T LPPas ruling out is the possibility of thought which fails to conform
to the form of the world, just as it rules out the possibility of inference
which fails to track the internal relations that stand between states of
affairs.1 6 There may, on that view, be mental activities which appear,
both ‘from the inside’ and to other speakers, to be thought and infer-
ence but which fail to be so by lacking the requisite conformity. What
is strikingly odd about this view is that we, as performers, are isolated
from our performances. Take two sentences of ordinary language, p and
q; then our success in inferring p from p &q is not only a matter of our
having a grasp of the internal relations that stand between the facts
expressed by those sentences, but also of its turning out that the analysis
of those sentences, a procedure that we may never be able to complete,
reveals their conformity. What we cannot see, let alone see clearly, is
what distinguishes our having a thought, our inferring, from our doing
something else, from our playing not-bridge when we take ourselves to
be playing bridge.
The Tractarian account of inference, as Ramsey sees it, is one that
shares its symptoms with the views of laws and counterfactuals already
considered which satisfy the realist impulse. That is, on that view, what
grounds the truth of my claim that I have inferred thus-and-so is a reality
which lies beyond my capacities to recognise it, and it is thus such that
the notion of correctingg my inferential practices loses all traction. While
on the one hand, there is one notion of correctness which merely implies
bringing myself into line with others, on the other, the Tractarian view –
absent some further indication of the connection between public practice
and independent truth conditions – leaves us without a passage between
the notions of correctness and of truth. So while T LPP may furnish me
with a theory of inference, it is not – in common with the realist views
considered earlier – a theory which can be of any use to me in that there
is no sense to be made of my inferential practice’s being corrigible in a

The Realistic Spirit 31
manner that connects with truth. Knowing that inference is a matter of
its being the case that the contents of my thoughts stand in a particular
relation to states of affairs cannot, in the absence of an available analysis
of those contents, translate into knowledge that what I am now doing
is inferring (as opposed to enjoying some distinct but phenomenally
indistinguishable mental state or event). And if I cannot know that, for
instance, what now appears to me to be a legitimate inference is in fact
an illegitimate one, then I cannot correct my practice. So the normative
role that Ramsey envisages for philosophy is hopeless.
What Ramsey wishes to rule in is the case where we are committing a
contravention, the case where we are purporting to infer in accordance
with logical norms – undertaking the commitments and engaging in the
activities associated with logical thought – and yet are somehow coming
up short. And since purporting to infer in accordance with those norms
is a performance that involves self-conscious recognition of regularities
in my own mental states, philosophy has a role to play when it suffers
a failure – a failure which can be discovered – which requires correction.
So philosophy may yet clarify usefully.17
1.2.3 The comfort of pretence
The Tractarian conception of thought and inference follows from the
thesis that sense must be determinate, that a proposition – any proposi-
tion – divides the space of possibilities into two mutually exclusive and
jointly exhaustive sets. There is also available a traditional, realist reading
of the text according to which it this thesis that motivates the argument
for substance, and thus Wittgenstein’s logical atomism, which in turn
leads to the inscrutability of the analysis of our sentences. The thesis
that sense is determinate is a prime example of scholasticism insofar
as it seeks to impose logical perfection on our thought and language.
But, as Ramsey points out, it does so at the expense of philosophy’s
characterisation as a normative activity since it blocks the possibility
of my ordinary modes of enquiry, which includes self-conscious reflec-
tion upon my mental states, yielding knowledge which will allow me
to correct my practice. The connection between anti-scholasticism and
self-conscious reflection as a source of knowledge is one that helps to
make sense of Ramsey’s remark that the realistic spirit must reject some
forms of ‘realism’ because the realistic spirit ‘can understand nothing’ of
the sentences that purport to express those views.
As in the case of inference, a scholastic view which pretends that
language and thought are, at core, logically perfect is a view which does
so at the risk of isolating us from having knowledge of what it is that we

32 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
are doing – what it is that we mean by a particular sentence or what it is
that some mental activity amounts to. And, for Ramsey, that is not the
kind of theory that we can r eally, genuinelyyunderstand. It is not the kind
of theory that can have sense for us.
In ‘Philosophy’, Ramsey discusses a view that attempts to analyse
perceptual reports ((Ph., pp. 266–267). What is meant when someone
says ‘This patch is red’? One answer is that ‘This patch is red’ is to be
analysed in terms of the contents of the speaker’s perceptual experience,
where I mean by ‘contents of perceptual experience’ the phenomenal
constituents of that experience. Further, what she calls ‘a patch’ is to be
analysed as a logical construction from names for the simplest possible
units of those contents. Finally, the view is Euclidian about visual space,
insofar as it holds that the perceptual field is constituted by an infinite
class of points – indivisible, extensionless, discrete locations. The claim,
made by S , that some patch is red is analysed as an existential claim:
there is some set of points partly constitutive of her visual field that are
red. The analysis will have to be more complex, as the points within
the set had better enjoy some other properties too – they had better, for
instance, be adjacent; and since a patch has (visual) extension while a
point does not, the set of red points had better be uncountable.
The theory has a familiar shape: an apparent name for a part of the
content of S ’s perceptual experience is analysed as a description, an
assertion about the existence of a suitably related range of points within
phenomenal space with which S is directly acquainted. So one imagines
that were S to have names for the points that constitute her visual field,
perhaps by way of co-ordinates, ‘This patch is red’ would reveal itself
upon complete analysis to be a claim of the form ‘ a is red and b is red
and ... and a stands in R to b and ... ’. What S called ‘this patch’ turns out
upon analysis to be a logical fiction, a construction out of the simple
objects partly constitutive of S ’s visual field.
This kind of view, says Ramsey, is the kind of view which belongs to
a science such as psychology, and not to philosophy: endorsing it is
‘giving up philosophy for theoretical psychology’ (((Ph., p. 266). And the
difference between psychology and philosophy, it seems, comes down,
first, to a difference in the kinds of data for which the two fields are
supposed to account and, second, to a difference in what will count as a
success in accounting for that data. The problems, for Ramsey, with this
kind of view are, first, that there is no replacing a p atch as it occurs in
my experience with an infinite class of points that occur in my experi-
ence. There is simply no such thing as an infinite class of points that
occur in my experience, at least not where such a class is reduced to

The Realistic Spirit 33
an extensional entity such as a set, as is required for the notion of a
logical construction. For what, asks Ramsey, would it be like for me were
just one of these points blue rather than red? And the answer is this:
it wouldn’t be like anything, since it would make no difference to the
content of my experience or to my reports concerning those contents.18
A theory on which it makes no difference to me whether I am now
seeing a patch that is reducible to a class of red points or a patch that is
reducible to a class of red points plus one blue one, where the patches
are indiscriminable, is a theory upon which it is not possible for me to
know precisely what the content of my perceptual experience is. This, it
should be noted, is not the customary form of scepticism about percep-
tion which trades upon the fact that falsidical and veridical seeing are
phenomenally indiscriminable but a novel form of phenomenal scepti-
cism in which I cannot discriminate the very phenomenal constituents
of my perceptual experience.
A second objection, and one to which I shall return in Chapter 9, is
that, on certain assumptions about meaning, grasping the meaning of
‘This patch is red’ entails understanding the conditions under which
such a sentence would be true. On the analysis that Ramsey is criticising,
such a sentence is true only if a state of affairs obtains that is describable
by an infinite conjunction of simpler sentences of the from ‘a is red and
b is red and ... ’. It is not, of course, required by the view that one be able
to articulate the infinite sentence – that would be to require the impos-
sible. But it is required that one somehow understand that for ‘This
patch is red’ to be true a certain state of affairs must obtain. But in what
precisely does such an understanding consist? Unless that question is
convincingly answered, then the proposed theory has entirely failed to
give the meaningg of ‘This patch is red’. Whatever it is that that theory is
doing, what it is not doing is revealing anything about the nature of the
claim ‘This patch is red’.1 9
What Ramsey means by theoretical psychology is a scientific theory
of mind, and as such, it would not have necessarily to be a theory
which accounted for the facts of our experience, since the aims of
scientific theorising might not include such facts in its remit. Rather,
such a theory might be concerned instead with predictive success, with
explanatory cohesiveness and with concepts open to empirical testing.
That is, it is appropriate for theoretical psychology, in discussing the
nature of perceptual experience, to endorse a m odel, where a model is a
manner of conceptualising a range of phenomena without having, as a
constraint on its goodness, to be realistic. A model is a picture, a meta-
phor: to understand a model, one has to cast aside what is irrelevant to

34 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
the question at hand and foreground what is vital to the present investi-
gation. But in so doing, there is no necessity to presume that the model
is, or seeks to be, an accurate representation of the phenomena, or all
the aspects of the phenomena, in question. The theoretical psychologist
might find the kind of Euclidian model of visual experience outlined
above to be a useful one insofar as it offers her a standard means of
capturing and communicating reports of visual experience, of quanti-
fying features of that experience and of describing theoretical and physi-
ological processes involved in vision.2 0 A model may be adopted for the
sake of simplification, only to be discarded or described as a helpful
idealisation once a system is better understood.
So here we have our two differences. Theoretical psychology aims to
account for one range of data – observable data, reports and behaviour.
Philosophy’s task is more difficult, however, as it must reconcile that
data with our nature as thinking but finite and limited beings: ‘in philos-
ophy, we analyse ourr thought’ ((( Ph., p. 266). That the phenomenal patch
is constituted by infinitely many points, or that our understanding the
claim ‘The patch is red’ involves grasping a picture of reality upon which
that sentence is true just in case infinitely many points are a certain
way, can be no part of our thought. A successful psychological theory
is one that accounts for its data by the standards of that field – by its
predictive power, explanatory success, connection with other theories
in the neighbourhood, openness to empirical verification and so forth.
A successful philosophical theory, however, is one for which it is neces-
sary that it account for phenomena as we – we just as we are – experience
them. Mistaking one for the other is like mistaking a metaphor for a fact,
or a model for reality; and the comfort of the metaphor, of the model,
with its apparent certainty and clean lines, can tempt one into pretence
and self-deception, indeed, even self-abnegation.
Now if we made [a] theory about our own mind we should have to
regard it as accounting for certain facts, e.g. that this patch is red; but
when we are thinking of other people’s minds we have no facts, but
are altogether in the realm of theory, and can persuade ourselves that
these theoretical constructions exhaust the field. We then turn back
on our minds and say that what are really happening there are simply
these theoretical processes. (((Ph., p. 266)
We can convince ourselves of the plausibility of a particular theory by
engaging in a kind of wilful ignorance, neglecting the facts of our own
experience in favour of some construction. And we can only believe it to

The Realistic Spirit 35
be true if we turn our backs on the very features of our experience that
we wished to examine in the first place. But that, I take it, is to give up
being r ealisticc (about me and about us) in favour of what Ramsey called
realism – in this case about ‘points’ as the constituents of the visual
field. It is to abandon the philosophical project and at least some of the
philosophical data in favour of a form of explanation which is merely
‘emotionally satisfying’ for the kind of mind which sees the world from
the perspective of the heavens rather than persons ((E p., p. 291).
1.2.4 Parsimony and pretending
I began by discussing a possible attribution to Ramsey of a common-or-
garden penchant for philosophical parsimony. What I hope that I have
so far made clear is that philosophising in the realistic spirit might entail
a parsimonious attitude to ontology in some particular theory, without
necessitating such an attitude for all. Ramsey’s interest is not in habitu-
ally ruling out entities from a theory on the basis of whether or not they
are surplus to its requirements, like crossing out ‘baking powder’ in a
recipe because one’s flour is already self-raising. Rather, his interest is
in assessing theories holistically for instances of the kinds of pretence
which, whilst marking such theories achievements in intellectual
aesthetics (that is, scholasticism), render them failures as meaningful
explanations which have in common audience and explanandum: us.
In GP&C, Ramsey rejects two views of variable hypotheticals which
depend upon the existence of entities which go beyond what is required
to account for the philosophical data. But note that those views are
supposed to be nonsense (not just false as one committed to parsimony
might take them to be) insofar as they are such that we ‘can understand
nothing’ of them. Why can one philosophising in the realistic spirit not
so much as understand these views? Why is our rejection of them not
grounded in truth or falsity, but in sense?
In Chapter 9, I discuss the case of infinite processes in some detail,
so here I shall focus just on the theory in which laws of nature are
explained as ‘real connections of universals’. Consider the sentence ‘It is
a law of nature that allΦs are Ψs’. What would it mean for its truth to
be dependent upon the holding of some relation between the universal
Φ–ness and the universal Ψ–ness? One thing that it would mean is
that whatever ‘It is a law of nature that all Φs are Ψs’ expresses could
be expressed by some other sentence which made explicit its commit-
ments, namely a sentence in the form of ‘ There is a relation of such-and-
such kind which holds between the universal Φ–ness and the universal
Ψ–ness’. Call that sentence Ω. Ω is not, of course, what we mean by ‘all

36 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Φs are Ψs is a law of nature’, but rather a sentence of a philosophical
theory which seeks to explicate the truth conditions of that sentence.
The question then becomes this: can we really understand Ω, and if so,
how?
At the beginning of G P&C, Ramsey identifies certain beguiling analo-
gies between the form of variable hypotheticals and a range of other
sentences that express propositions. In the same way, the sentence Ω is
analogous to a range of sentences that express propositions: sentences
that express, for instance, that some object stands in a relation to
another. So there is an explanation for why we might, at first glance,
think that Ω is all right just as it is – it looks, grammatically, just like the
perfectly ordinary sentence. That, for Ramsey, is not enough, as we must
ask a further question: am I capable of understanding a sentence like Ω
in just the same way that I am capable of understanding the ordinary
sentence? Does an account of my understanding of the latter extend to
an account of my apparent understanding of the former?
If I understand that a is redder, or warmer, or taller than b, then I also
understand at least some of the ways in which a could fail to be redder,
warmer or taller than b . Either a’s or b’s enjoying a different shade,
temperature or height might suffice for that failure. But do I under-
stand, analogously, what would suffice for Φ–ness’s failing to stand in

Φs areΨs’ might fail to be true? If the answer is that what would suffice

question in a manner analogous to the way that the first question was
addressed. After all, if my understanding of that in virtue of which ‘It
is a law of nature that all Φs are Ψs’ is true is a matter of my grasping a
proposed state of affairs, namely thatΦ–ness stands in a certain relation
to Ψ–ness, it is no explanation at all to assert that my understanding of
howw Ω might fail to be the case is dependent upon my understanding
of the negation of the initial law statement. Rather, on the view being
considered, its being the case that not all Φs are Ψs would be a conse-

of the falsehood of Ω – rather than an explanation of the conditions
under which the negation of Ω would be true.
Someone might try to answer the question analogously to the first
by saying that what would be required is that either Φ–ness or Ψ–ness

properties of Φ–ness and the ways in which they may differ, where an

Common to these accounts is the presence of a method by which we
can, for instance, explain to someone else what they should understand

should understand by Ω, and in particular, the absence of methods that
explain the ways in which it might fail to hold, shows that the analogy

we have to hand an account of how we do understand the sentence in

I want to be clear that the kinds of questions posed here are not

which demands to be questioned. Such a cashing out might – and this
is only one option – be given by a demonstration that the manner or
manners in which knowledge of the putative meanings of the expres-
sions in question is acquired make similar demands upon our capaci-
ties and that that knowledge is wholly manifested in the range of our
practices, judgements and inferences concerning the subject matter in

In this case, the pretending in question is that of pretending that the
similarity between two forms of words is sufficient for settling under-
standing in the two cases.22 But such a view outruns what we can
demonstrate, and without the demonstration, we are not entitled to the
claim that the form of words is a form that we understand. Earlier in the
chapter, I mentioned that one might see some of the forms of realism to
which Ramsey objects as satisfying an impulse for uniform treatments
of diverse phenomena. Such an impulse may, like the forms of scho-
lasticism discussed above, encourage us to suppress various data – our
behaviour, our internal states, our conceptual and epistemic capacities
and our expectations – in order to satisfy the impulse. It is this kind of
pretending – a pretending that the world must be such as to satisfy our
intellectual vanities – that the realistic spirit seeks always to check.

2
Empiricism, Solipsism and
the Realistic
The realistic spirit has been partially described through a discussion of
the ways in which someone pursuing philosophy in that spirit might
respond to a range of realist theories. Readers will have recognised in the
description some continuities with tenets of empiricism. In this chapter,
I seek to further characterise the realistic by bringing out some differ-
ences (and similarities) between it and certain empiricist theories, and I
do so by considering what is unrealistic in (some of) Berkeley and (some
of) Russell. Doing so reveals two structural similarities between those
empiricist views and a view which constitutes a plausible understanding
of the solipsism of TLP, namely a connection between the meaning of
our expressions and a perspective on the world which no human speaker
can occupy. I hypothesise that it is this solipsism that Ramsey considers
to be ‘mystical’, and so unrealistic, and that he seeks to eliminate from
his deflationary, proto-realistic ‘Critical Notice’ reading of TLP, discussed
in Chapter 4.
2.1 Empiricism and the Realistic
I have described Ramsey as criticising a number of realist views for their
willingness to endorse theories that propose the existence of entities
or make claims that are such that we cannot explain how we could
know those entities or understand those claims. Such views, I suggested,
are normatively inert since, as they offer us no means of detecting or
correcting failures in our practices relative to the postulated reality, the
very notion of correct or incorrect going on in respect of those practices
is rendered a scholastic question, impotent to affect the things that we
do or think. Empiricism has historically entailed the rejection of various
forms of realism; if one starts from the thought that our conceptual
39

40 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
repertoire can derive only from immediate experience, then the coher-
ence of views committed to entities which appear to lie beyond any
possible experience is easily denied. So that is one sense in which the
realistic spirit and empiricism may be thought to overlap.
Cora Diamond has argued that Ramsey is an empiricist of a kind that
is continuous with Berkeley. She begins by drawing a parallel between
Berkeley’s rejection of realism about matter and Ramsey’s rejection of
realism about laws of nature as resting on the realist’s being ‘taken in
by illusions which the [realistic spirit] can see to be illusions, irrelevant
to any distinction which we might have the least use for’ (1991, p. 42).
This is, in part, what Diamond takes being realistic, in Ramsey’s sense,
to mean, and I am in agreement with her. She ends by arguing that
Berkeley’s and Ramsey’s (putative) empiricism prevents them both from
being fully realistic in the way that she attributes to Wittgenstein.
I think that Diamond’s focus on Berkeley in order to diagnose what
is unrealistic in some versions of empiricism is extremely astute, and I
begin by following her lead. I shall, however, locate the unrealistic in
Berkeley in a slightly different place, and I bring it out in connection
with some of Russell’s thought in 1914; there will, I think, be parallels
detectable between these views and the unrealistic picture that arises
from a reading of T LPP discussed in the last chapter. So that ought to
help to see more clearly what is realistic in the views that I attributed
to Ramsey in the last chapter. I will then argue that even on Diamond’s
characterisation of the realistic spirit, we need not accuse Ramsey of
giving an unrealistic account of laws of nature in GP&C, though a
version of the worry that she raises will be discussed in Chapter 9.
2.1.1 Berkeley, Russell and the language of God
For Berkeley, a commitment to empiricism meant a resistance to
accounting for the world as we experience it in terms the meanings that
cannot be accounted for by reflection upon our experience. The distinc-
tion that we can do without is that between matter and sense experi-
ence, and we can do without it, holds Berkeley, because every sentence
expressing a content about the material world which the materialist
takes to be true, the subjective idealist takes to be true too. After all,
Philonous is not a s cepticc about the existence of the ‘real’ objects of which
we predicate various properties in our descriptions of the world; he seeks
instead to promote an account of the real compatible with empiricist
methodology (1996, pp. 40, 150–152). In fact, Philonous’s treatment of
the materialist Hylas rather neatly puts the latter into the position of
the sceptic when he finds himself torn between his empiricist scruples

Empiricism, Solipsism and the Realistic 41
and his commitment to the thesis that material reality must be mind
independent.
Where Berkeley and the materialist differ is in what they take to be the
truth conditions for our ordinary claims about the real. One problem
that Philonous has with matter is that he cannot see what work it is
supposed to do in a scientific account of the world; by the end of the
Dialogues, we have a theory of how material objects, order and the
laws of nature may be understood as collections of ideas organised in a
manner discoverable to us in the mind of God (pp. 172–173). Even the
very ideal of scientific discovery is preserved wholesale, not now as an
investigation into the hidden nature of material reality but as an investi-
gation into the divine – an investigation into the connections that hold
between ideas in the mind of God (p. 189). But this – the possibility of a
more parsimonious reinterpretation of our talk of the real – is secondary
to Berkeley’s claim that, really, there is no concept of matter, 1 that the
term ‘matter’ means nothing at all (p. 165).
So there are two phases to Berkeley’s campaign: first, the elimination
from our philosophical and scientific vocabulary of the term ‘matter’ on
empiricist grounds, and second, the provision of a theory of the material
world which leaves our talk of it, and all the objectivity that that talk
implies, intact. Now, Berkeley gives us nothing like a reconstructed or
reductionist semantics for our everyday talk of the material world, but
his talk of material objects as collections of ideas suggests that such a
reconstructive strategy is appropriate. Ignoring Russell’s motivations for
adopting phenomenalism at various times, we might examine his posi-
tive account of material objects under the suggestion that it presents a
view continuous in important respects with Berkeley’s.2 In Our Knowledge
of the External World, Russell proposes a programme for preserving our
talk of the material by arguing that reference to material objects is to be
understood in terms of logical constructions from features of p erspec-
tives, which Russell calls aspects.3
A private worldd is the total content of a visual experience – that is, the
total visual sense data at an instant of a particular subject. We say that
that private world is one of many perspectives. A perspective need not be
occupied by a subject; spreading out in every direction from one perspec-
tive is a continuous series of perspectives, each differing in some respect
from the first. Some of those perspectives are perceived by subjects and
are thus private worlds, but some are not and thus remain unperceived
perspectives: that some perspective are in fact perceived is neither here
nor there. The set of all such perspectives, actual and ideal, is the system
of perspectives. Perspectives are ordered by a similarity relation, and it is

42 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
this ordering which underwrites our talk of two viewpoints being nearer
or farther apart.4 So, as I feel myself to be walking towards the chair, I
pass through a series of perspectives in which the contents of my visual
experience change gradually: for instance, in each perspective that I
occupy, there is a feature of it (the chair-feature in each) which grows
larger. Crucially, the notion of space in which perspectives are arranged
is ‘totally different from the spaces inside the two perspectives. It is a
relation between the perspectives, and is not in either of them; no one
can perceive it, and if it is to be known it can only be by inference’
(1914, p. 96).
Material objects are then defined by features of different perspec-
tives – that is, individual perceptual features within the total perspective
(Russell calls these objects, but I shall use the term features in order to
avoid confusion with the reducta of the account) – which are correlated
with one another by a further similarity relation. Call such identifiable,
individuated features aspects. A material object at an instant is then the
set of aspects ordered by the above mentioned similarity relation:5 ‘a
physical thing consists, at each instant, of the whole set of its aspects
at that instant, in all the different worlds; thus, a momentary state of a
thing is a whole set of aspects’ (p. 117). What it is for a material object
to persist through change is for a series of its aspects to obey the laws of
physics (p. 115). That is, what are to count as material objects are those
isolatable features of perspectives at an instant which, over time, are
bound by causal laws.
Russell’s account is, like Berkeley’s, a reductive account of material
objects.6 For Berkeley, ideas are real, and material objects are collections
of those ideas. For Russell, only isolatable features within a perspective
are real: ‘All the aspects of a thing are real, whereas the thing itself is a
merely logical construction’ (p. 96).
It would be quite false, however, to say that on either account it is only
the objects of experience which exist because both Berkeley and Russell
require further conditions in order to account for the ordered and stable
natures of our experiences, just as the materialist explains such order
and stability by attributing various properties to matter. For Berkeley,
this condition is God. For Russell, it is the geometry of the space within
which perspectives occur.7 The features of that space ensure that, for
instance, a chain of aspects which satisfy the relevant similarity relation
may converge with another chain of aspects that satisfy that relation in
order to constitute one object. It is this arrangement of aspects within
the space of perspectives which ensures that we can say, as we travel
along one chain of aspects, that we are approaching the teacup from

Empiricism, Solipsism and the Realistic 43
above and, as we travel along the other, that we are approaching it face
on. Because the space in which perspectives are arranged is not the space
within the perspectives, and is thus no part of one’s perceptual experi-
ence, it, like God, is posited to explain a feature of our experience which
cannot be derived from that experience.
It is not relevant here that, no doubt, Berkeley intended to refer to a
deity when he used the term ‘God’, because the role that God plays in
Berkeley’s account, and that the space of perspectives plays in Russell’s,
is that of a neutral viewpoint on reality. What is achieved by that neutral
viewpoint is the following: for Berkeley a world of ideas, and for Russell
a system of perspectives, which is fixed, ordered and stable. It is the
presence of such a viewpoint, on both of these accounts, which fixes
for agents a common course of experience and which culminates in an
unrealistic but realist account of meaning.
What do I mean by this? A phenomenalist account of the truth condi-
tions for a statement such as ‘The apple is on the desk’ will proceed
disjunctively: that statement is true just in case either some person XX is
positioned such that XX enjoys certain phenomenal experiences as of the
apple on the desk, or XX is not so positioned, but were XX so positioned X
would enjoy certain phenomenal experiences as of the apple on the desk.
That is, an apparent statement of fact is reduced to a further statement
involving a subjunctive claim about conditions not now obtaining. But,
pressing the phenomenalist further, we might ask for an account of the
truth conditions of the subjunctive conditional contained in the second
disjunct. There are two ways in which she might go.
In the first direction, which I shall not pursue in any detail, she may
deny that the meaning of a subjunctive conditional is to be given in
terms of its truth conditions, and thus, she may deny also that such
conditionals obey the law of bivalence. Instead, she may hold that
statements about material objects which are not observation reports
are generally governed by conditions of assertibility, involving certain
permissible inferences from direct observation and accepted general
laws. 8
In the second direction, she may attempt to give an account of the
relevant subjunctive conditionals which is truth-conditional – that is,
which elaborates a further reduction of the subjunctive statements to
indicative or categorical statements. It seems to me that this is the route
that Russell would have endorsed because, as I have mentioned, material
objects are for him logical constructions from features of perspectives.
But perspectives exist whether they are occupied by a perceiver or not,
within an objective space of perspectives not open to experience. Thus,

44 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
any troublesome subjunctive conditional could be reduced to a further,
complex sentence which made reference to only the features of each of
a relevant range of perspectives. That is, simplifying in multiple direc-
tions, one may reduce the subjunctive conditional ‘Were XX so positioned
XX would enjoy certain phenomenal experiences as of the apple on the
desk’ to a class of sentences of the form ‘Perspective x contains a feature
as of the apple, perspective y contains a feature as of the apple, ... , and
x, y, ... are the only perspectives which contain a feature as of the apple’.9
What, I think, is manifest is that such a view is unrealistic in the sense
that I have already outlined, involving as it does a reality – an arrange-
ment of perspectives within a space inaccessible to any speaker – that
can play no part in in an explanation of our practices of making, for
instance, material object reports. What the view requires in order to
be even so much as understood as a view of the meaning of material
object reports is the occupation by a speaker of a standpoint on reality
which is outside of our ordinary standpoint on the material world that
we inhabit and for which theory is supposed to account. That is, one
is required to occupy a standpoint which is, by definition, not a stand-
point that can be occupied by any speaker. And so it is for Berkeley too;
on his view, the meaning of the statement ‘The apple is on the desk’ is
determined by how things are in God’s mind. That is, the language that
we speak is, on his view, not ours alone but a part of God’s. But how can
that be a language that we can ever know?
2.1.2 The given
Diamond’s account of how Berkeley’s view is unrealistic comes from a
different direction, and it turns upon his reliance on a notion of t he
given – a notion, that is, of there being certain mental states or cognitive
episodes which enjoy a foundational epistemic priority. In the introduc-
tion to the P rinciples of Human Knowledge, Berkeley makes the following
methodological prescription:
So long as I confine my thoughts to my own ideas divested of words,
I do not see how I can easily be mistaken. The objects I consider, I
clearly and adequately know. I cannot be deceived into thinking I
have an idea which I have not. It is not possible for me to imagine,
that any of my own ideas are alike or unlike, that are not truly so. To
discern the agreements or disagreement there are between my ideas,
to see what ideas are included in any compound idea, and what not,
there is nothing more requisite than an attentive perception of what
passes in my own understanding. (1996, p. 21)

Empiricism, Solipsism and the Realistic 45
What is unrealistic here, according to Diamond, is a view about meaning
which makes it dependent upon detectable regularities in our mental
lives about which we cannot be mistaken (1991, pp. 63–66). And what
is unrealistic in Ramsey is supposed to be exactly this too: the idea that
one might give an account of the meaning of law statements in terms of
habits of inference or general rules that govern our thought and that we
are able to grasp by reflection on our own mental processes.
There are, I think, two identifiable anxieties: the first involves the
idea that there is no giving an account of the meaning of an expression
in terms of regularities recoverable by introspection and the second is
related to the fact that saying of oneself that one cannot be mistaken
about a certain regularity entails that there is no mechanism for correc-
tion with regard to the use one makes of a word. Both of these anxieties
have their genesis in Wittgenstein’s reflections on rule-following.
Diamond, contra for example Kripke (1982), takes Wittgenstein’s
discussion of rule following to be an attempt to illustrate not the intrac-
tabilityy of a certain philosophical question about what one means by
‘go on in such-and-such a way’ but rather the i nappositeness of an atti-
tude that dictates that the answer must take a specific, ‘philosophical’
form. There is, first, a simple answer that we are all in a position to give.
If I say to someone, ‘Go on in such-and-such a way’ in respect of, for
example, some drawn pattern or arithmetical series, what is it that I do
if that person asks how she might correctly follow that instruction? I
may, and these are only examples, point out the salient features of the
pattern in front of her; I may extend the series for her; or I may correct
or approve of her attempted extensions. The, as it were, p ositive lesson of
the rule-following considerations, and what I take Diamond to intend
by the realistic spirit, is that these quite ordinary ways in which we actu-
ally demonstrate what we intend by ‘Go on in such-and-such a way’ are
wholly adequate to, indeed exhaustive of, an explication of the meaning
of instances of that expression. What is to be resisted here is a reification
of the notion of meaninggg, a realism that takes the meaning of an expres-
sion, the delineation of its correct and incorrect use, to require founda-
tions which furnish those expressions with an objectivity that outruns
the features and projects of the community of speakers in which that
expression has a life.
Ramsey’s failure to be thoroughly realistic is most evident for Diamond
in his brief discussion of what it means to say that there are unknown
causal laws and of what one might say about the possibility of a case in
which our inductive habits are disrupted by certain maddeningg singular
facts.

46 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Recall that for Ramsey, to assert a law of nature is to assert a variable
hypothetical, and to assert a variable hypothetical is to express that one
has adopted or assented to a rule for judging, arrived at via the applica-
tion of a known psychological law to singular experiences. What then of
a case in which I assert both that there is a causal law that governs partic-
ulars of a certain kind, but that that law is unknown? Here, Ramsey
holds that what is meant by such an assertion is that there exist singular
facts which would lead the speaker, according to a psychological law, to
infer a variable hypothetical concerning that kind – that is, to adopt a
rule for making judgements regarding instances of the kind in question
(GP&C, pp. 244–245.).
Now, Ramsey is aware that not just any psychological law will do;
for instance, the existence of (unknown) singular facts the experience
of which would make us mad and from which we would m adlyy infer a
variable hypothetical does not make for the existence of an unknown
causal law. What is needed is that the psychological law upon which the
inference is based be one of ‘the known laws expressing our methods of
inductive reasoning’ (G P&C, p. 245). And here, ‘known’ does not mean
that the regularity is stateable; rather, such knowledge is demonstrated
by our being able to say how we would infer upon being presented
with certain singular facts. That we are in a position to assert an appro-
priate subjunctive conditional in response to such hypothetical facts, as
discussed in the previous chapter, evinces for Ramsey the rule or habit
of judging that has been adopted.
Diamond thinks that Ramsey cannot make out the distinction that
he needs between a mad law of generalising and a known law that
expresses our methods of inductive reasoning in terms of regularities in
our mental states detectable by introspection. Her reason for thinking
so is the familiar, as it were, negative lesson of the rule-following consid-
erations: if one takes oneself to be following a rule in respect of the use
of some expression, then any way in which one goes on in respect of
that expression – any use of that expression apparently respectable to
oneself – will appear (to oneself) to be in accord with that rule. There are,
that is, no internal alarms primed to sound upon deviation, and so there
is, in respect of what is first-person detectable, no such thing as devia-
tion, and so no such thing as regularity. Here is, it is supposed, trouble
for Ramsey: if one takes one’s inferences to be governed by a rule or to
express a regularity, then every way in which one might infer, whether
madly or otherwise, will appear to be an inference in accordance with
that rule or in extension to that regularity. And so, says Diamond, ‘[o]ur
“knowledge” [of psychological laws that govern our inferences] is merely

Empiricism, Solipsism and the Realistic 47
a misleading way of putting the fact that in what we do, we are taking
ourselves to be following a rule’ (p. 63).
I think that this criticism may elide the distinction between there being
detectable psychological laws which govern our inductive reasoning and
knowledge of such laws being an active component in our theorising
about our reasoning. After all, one’s behaviour may exhibit a regularity
without its being the case that one takes oneself to be behaving regu-
larly or to be behaving in accordance with a rule. Someone presents me
with some hypothetical singular facts, and I say that I should infer in
such-and-such a way. Clearly, if it is i nferringg which I am doing here, as
opposed to some other mere doing, like guessingg or ticcinggg, then there
must be some principle or principles according to which I reach the
conclusion that I propose. I need not take myself to be following such
a principle and I need not know its content in order to do the thing
that I do. But when we credit someone with having inferred, we credit
her with having come to a new thought at least partly on the basis of
the application of some regulative principle. Further, we would be very
unlikely to say of someone that she had inferred were it not also the case
that either her conclusion was at least roughly in accordance with the
one we should reach if presented with the same hypothetical facts, or if
she were unable to articulate some reason – presumably a consideration
of further singular facts or the revelation that she had in mind some
other generalisation – that explains why her conclusion differed from
ours.
This, it seems, is all that Ramsey needs to safeguard his view from
some of the force of Diamond’s criticism because it is the existence of
regularities in inference – that is, the existence of a regularity in the ways
in which we credit one another with having inferred in some or other
way – which can make the distinction between regular laws of general-
ising and mad laws. This is not to say that our communal practice of so
crediting others is one reducible to the success of individuals in grasping
a rule governing that practice. The partial explanation I have given
above of that activity is one perfectly compatible with Wittgenstein’s
thought, endorsed by Diamond: ‘You do not yourself understand any
more of the rule than you can explain’ (p. 64); that explanation, like
the explanations of deductive inference and bridge playing presented
earlier, includes no concession to peculiarly philosophical concepts. On
that view, to say that there exists an unknown causal law with respect
to phenomena of kind XX is to say that there are certain singular facts
that would lead someone to generalisationΨ such that we would credit
them with having inferred Ψ from those facts were she to encounter

them, all within the context of our practice of crediting persons with
inferential success.
Given that there evidently is such a context in which that activity
takes place, we can say that the existence of singular facts that would
lead to a mad generalisation does not constitute an unknown causal law,
because someone so generalising within that context would not be cred-

that would cause us a ll to start generalising madly, and nor would the
ensuing generalisations count, on this view, as unknown causal laws,
because the relevant context is this one (the one that we are now in): the
one from which we would judge such a circumstance to b e mad.
It is true that Ramsey does speak of the psychological laws that govern
our inductive practices as being detectable, but he ought really to have
said manifestable because what counts as knowing those laws is simply
knowing what to say in the presence of certain actual singular facts or
knowing what one would say when presented with certain hypothetical
singular facts. That is, the notion of knowledge in use here is that of
implicit knowledge of such laws, knowledge manifested by one’s saying
what one does say in the presence of the facts. And that we believe
such knowledge to play a role in inference is evinced by the difference
that we find between our practices of crediting persons with inferential
success as opposed to crediting them with less rationally meritorious
achievements, such as guessing or ticcing.
If what I say is correct, then there is nothing in Ramsey, or at least in
his discussion of variable hypotheticals, which relies on a notion of the
given. There is a connection here to what Ramsey says about degrees
of belief, discussed in the next chapter, which is, in short, this: in our
actions, we make manifest that we believe certain relevant propositions
to a certain degree, and we do so, in general, entirely independently of
what is available to us via the sensations of relative strength or convic-
tion which attend our beliefs when we reflect upon them. That is, there
is a psychological law which governs the relationship between our
actions, our desires and the degrees to which we believe relevant propo-
sitions. That we know, at least tacitly, this law is exhibited by our puzzle-
ment when S accepts a bet at 10:1 against the fair coin coming up heads
and the range of hypotheses we credit as admissible in our attempts to
explain her behaviour while preserving her rationality: she likes to lose;
she believes the coin is loaded; she lives for the thrill; and so forth. We
each know the law in the sense described above, although Ramsey is
adamant that we do not detect it by introspection, which is what I think
would be required in order for Diamond’s criticism to hold. Now there

is, I think, in the vicinity of Diamond’s criticism of Ramsey’s account of
variable hypotheticals another objection (which may, indeed, after all
be the same objection) which relates to a tension between Ramsey’s idea
that philosophy should have normative import and the possibility that
the psychological laws that govern our thought and the meanings of
our expressions are not necessarily open to view. That criticism connects
with Wittgenstein’s rule-following considerations in just the way that
Diamond envisages. I take it up in the second half of Chapter 9.
2.2 Solipsism and the Realistic
I shall argue in Chapter 4 that an early manifestation of the realistic
spirit is evident in CNN, where Ramsey replaces Wittgenstein’s Tractarian
sign-symbol distinction with an account of propositions which proceeds
via the typing of propositional-sign tokens according to their sense.
What Ramsey thereby takes himself to avoid are certain ‘mystical impli-
cations’ of TLP. Nowhere does Ramsey explain whyyhe rejected the sign-
symbol distinction; nor does he give any reason for his distaste for the
‘mystical implications’ of Wittgenstein’s claims. But what C NN notice-
ably fails to mention (and not even in the last sentences where Ramsey
summarises the remainder of the book) are those passages of TLPP which
concern solipsism.
There are several available accounts of how one ought to understand
Wittgenstein’s discussion of solipsism.1 0 I do not wish here to elaborate
upon any such account, but I will merely borrow from McGinn what
one might regard as the positive conclusion of that discussion. As she
has it, what the discussion of solipsism is intended to show is that the
relation between subject and world is not, as Russell conceived of it,
directional – that is, a relation of the sort that might be described propo-
sitionally – but is instead internal, a precondition for the possibility of
any system of representation, such as language or thought.
Wittgenstein’s aim it to make clear that the idea of logic as the limit
of the world cannot be understood in the sense of a boundary, but
is to be understood in the sense that there is no representation of
a world without logic. It is now clear that the idea of the subject as
limit of the world has to be understood in the same way. The world is
not conceivable independently of propositions that stand in a projec-
tive relation to the world; whenever there is representation of the
world in propositions there is a subject who is in a position to say ‘I
think ... ’. Thus the notions of the subject, logic and world stand as

50 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
correlates to one another; they cannot be understood, or made intel-
ligible, independently of one another. (2006, p. 276)
The world, so understood as essentially represented, ‘is my world insofar
as I represent the world to myself, but this relation of representing is not
one of ownership and it is not exclusive’; rather, it ‘is within the cogni-
tive grasp of anyone who understands this language’ (p. 277).
What this might suggest is that what is common to all who under-
stand a language is, in some sense, a single subject – not, once again,
in the sense of an object standing in a relation to the world but in the
sense of a common mode of cognising the world, a common method
of projection, a common standpoint. The metaphysical subject is thus
connected up with the representing features of any language at all; it
is both a precondition for and the subject of any representation, and
thus, it is the subject for which the world is a represented world and in
virtue of which it is the same represented world for all who understand
the language. It is a universal perspective, that from which the world is
represented for any user of language.11
What this picture leaves intact is a conception of propositions –
symbols – as entities whose independence from the activities and capaci-
ties of ordinary, ennatured speakers and thinkers, now conceived of as
empiricallor p sychological subjects (‘the human soul with which psychology
deals’), is a precondition of representation. What propositions there are is
determined by the necessary conformity of all and only propositions to the
general form of the proposition. To see what proposition a propositional-
sign expresses is to see the symbol in the sign. And to see the symbol in
the sign is, in some way or another, to manifest the metaphysical subject,,
to have come to share a method of projection with other members of
one’s linguistic community (and, indeed, any linguistic community).
I do not wish to propose that this is the correct way to read TLP. But
I do wish to propose as a plausible hypothesis: this is how Ramsey read
it in 1922, before he wrote CN. Consider what Ramsey does not discuss
in CN: he does not discuss value, religion, ethics, the will or natural
laws. In TLP, each of these topics is connected with what lies within the
limits of the world and what lies outside the limits of the world, what
is bound by logic and what is not. This, for Ramsey, is the mystical, ‘the
feeling that the world is not everything, that there is something outside
of it, its “sense” or “meaning”’ (CNN, p. 286). Likewise, according to the
above reading, the metaphysical subject is construed as something lying
outside of the world. But philosophy, done in the realistic spirit, can
understand nothing of what is ‘outside’ o urr world.

Empiricism, Solipsism and the Realistic 51
A realistic account is one which dispenses with myth and metaphor
and which instead places human beings – finite, fallible and yet extraor-
dinarily functional – at its heart. According to the broad sketch of an
account of the metaphysical subject that I gave above, such a notion is
required in order to transform mere signs into representational elements,
namely symbols, accessible to all who have linguistic capacities. But
accepting such a notion is to endorse a form of realism, a realism about
not only that subject itself but symbols (in the Tractarian sense) and
propositions. That is, to endorse that form of realism is to adopt a picture
which sits as a close-cousin to Frege’s view of Gedanke, on which there
is a mystery about how we can express and interact with such timeless
entities, intuit their logical connections and apprehend them in cogni-
tion. The view in the account that I gave merely replaces one mystery
with another. And even rejecting the notion of the metaphysical subject
leaves one with the Fregean or quasi-Fregean view in which symbols
stand behind signs, in some ghostly third-realm – somehow intuited,
somehow apprehended.
It is the presence of such mysteries – mysteries which flow from the
adoption of these forms of realism – that someone doing philosophy in
the realistic spirit cannot tolerate, cannot make sense of. In a paper deliv-
ered to the Apostles in 1925, and posthumously published as ‘Epilogue’,
Ramsey contrasts two ways of seeing the world and the place of persons
within it. On the one hand, there are those who are ‘humble before the
vastness of the heavens’ (((E p., p. 291). These are the varieties of realist,
their scheme dominated by entities, processes and perspectives that are
wholly remote and yet strangely within our ken and capacity. On the
other, there is Ramsey for whom ‘the foreground is occupied by human
beings and the stars are as small as threepenny bits’. There is, of course,
a sense in which this might indicate a mere matter of taste. But there is
also here a statement of the aims, and therefore the methods and means,
of philosophy. Philosophical explanations of phenomena are explana-
tions of ourselves to ourselves, and they must thus be such as we can
understand, not merely analogically, but directly and free of pretence.
In Chapter 4, I discuss Ramsey’s treatment of Wittgenstein’s sign-
symbol distinction which proceeds in terms of types and tokens of prop-
ositional-signs. That account leaves it as yet unclear what the relation is
between some propositional-sign token and the sense that it expresses in
virtue of which it belongs to the type that it does. But that, I believe, is
one feature of TLPP that Ramsey wished to further develop. In Chapter 6,
I discuss ‘Facts and Propositions’ and attempt to show how the account
given there is one which is acceptable to the philosopher who intends

52 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
the realistic spirit to inhabit her work. What that account involves is
close attention to the mental states of individuals and to our ordinary,
human capacities. The things we can say – the propositions there are –
stem from our constitution as worldly beings embedded in a natural
world and from our having in common certain natural responses to that
world. But first I turn to consider what of Ramsey’s notion of the real-
istic is owed to a family of views with close affinities to his own, namely
pragmatism.

3
Pragmatism and the Realistic
It is often claimed that Ramsey was a pragmatist, or took a pragmatic
turn in his later work. While it is evident that Ramsey admired Peirce and
was significantly influenced by some of his work, it is less obvious that
Ramsey should be described as a pragmatist, especially as, if one of the
theses of this book is correct, Ramsey’s realistic conviction can be traced
to his earliest work, which was produced at a time which preceded his
reading of Peirce. At any rate, I will here be concerned ultimately with
trying to understand both what someone might mean by claiming that
Ramsey was a pragmatist and whether that claim is true. Before doing
that, however, I will discuss some of Ramsey’s work in which explicit
reference is made to Peirce, both as a contribution to this book’s exeget-
ical task and in attempting an answer to the question at hand.
We know that Ramsey read Peirce’s Chance, Love and Logic, which was
not published until 1923, because he took seven pages of notes on its
contents (((H L 005–30–001). Every reference to Peirce made by Ramsey,
with just one exception, is attributable to this collection (indeed, to just
Part I). The one exception is a reference to Peirce’s type-token distinc-
tion in Ramsey’s ‘Critical Notice’, which comes from Peirce’s 1906 article
‘Prologomena to an Apology for Pragmatism’. Ramsey read at least some
of this article, as a transcription of pages 510–518 as well as notes of
the remaining pages of the article, written by C.K. Ogden in 1911, are
contained amongst his papers in the Hillman archive ((HL 007–05–01).
In his notes on C hance, Love and Logic, what interests Ramsey is
Peirce’s discussion of logic, probabilistic reasoning and rationality. It is
thus unsurprising that it is in Ramsey’s ‘Truth and Probability’ ( T&P),
where he gives a treatment of all three of these topics, that one finds the
clearest debt to Peirce. There are further references to Peirce scattered
through a number of papers and notes. Of these, the most substantial

Truth (O TTT).
Below, I give a short account of the content of T &PP before considering
what it might owe to Peirce. In the next section, I briefly touch on the
references in GP&C and OTT; I do so briefly because some of these themes
are picked up in later chapters. As it receives sustained treatment in the

3.1 Probability
T&PP begins with a discussion of Keynes’ account of probabilistic infer-
ence in A Treatise on Probability. According to Keynes, an assignment
of probability to a proposition p is a statement regarding the degree
of belief that an agent attaches to the proposition in question (1921,
p. 2). And what makes holding a belief to degree dd in p against some
background knowledge of q, rr, s ... rational is that there exists an objective
probability relation between q, rr, s ... and p which has the value d. Thus,
rationality in respect of probability is evinced by a capacity to correctly
intuit the probability relation that holds between a set of propositions
and a conclusion and thereafter calibrating one’s degree of belief in the
conclusion accordingly. 2 There are thus two detachable components to
Keynes’ view: first, that which argues that a probability assignment is an
expression of a degree of belief and, second, that which attempts to give
an account of what might be meant by a rational degree of belief.
In respect of the first, Ramsey adopts the subjectivist component of
Keynes’ view, agreeing that, at least in most usage, the statement by S
that p has probability PP is to be understood as a statement to the effect
that S believes p to degree d . However, whereas Keynes gives no method
for determining the degree of S’s belief in p and holds that the degree of
the probability relations correlated with rational degrees of belief may
not always be amenable to numerical measure, the provision of such a
measure is central to Ramsey’s view. In respect of the second, however,
he rejects Keynes’ account of what constitutes a rational or r easonable
degree of belief.
I shall begin by discussing the details of Ramsey’s subjectivist view
and his formal theory of degrees of belief. This owes very little to Peirce.
Thereafter, I turn to his and Peirce’s account of rationality in respect of
degree of belief, and of logic and enquiry in general, where the influence
is clearer.

Pragmatism and the Realistic 55
3.1.1 Degrees of belief
The core of Ramsey’s view regarding degrees of belief (and this much is
not original to him) is that the degree to which a subject believes p can
be determined by the odds that the subject would accept in placing a bet
that p . While Ramsey holds that the betting method is ultimately sound,
it requires modification so as to avoid certain confounding factors that
involve the bettor’s psychology: does she care about the money that
she gambles, is she is overly cautious, does she enjoy the sympathy of
losing more than she values winning or does she thrill to the existential
recklessness of staking all on a single toss of a coin? Further, money has
diminishing utility – a fixed sum means, ceteris paribus, less to someone
with a lot of money than it does to someone with very little. To accu-
rately determine the degree of her belief, one must thus protect against
what might be taken for granted in the act of monetary betting per se
and develop a more general notion of betting in which outcomes are the
satisfaction of certain preferences, whatever they might be: that is, one
needs also to have knowledge of other of the subject’s mental states, in
particular, what outcomes she most prefers. Ramsey here endorses the
psychological view, already at the heart of the betting method, which
states that the state of a subject’s belief with regard to some proposi-
tion p can be determined by how they act given the outcomes that they
happen to prefer.
But why not simply ask an agent the degree to which they believe that
p? Sahlin claims that ‘it is Ramsey’s basic pragmatic outlook that prevails
here’ (Sahlin 1990, p. 16). In the absence of an account of what consti-
tutes a ‘pragmatic outlook’, I am not sure how to take this comment, but
I return to this question in the last section of this chapter. At any rate,
what Ramsey says against introspection has no obvious connection to
any uniquely pragmatist thesis: we rarely, he holds, have a direct experi-
ence of the strength of a belief, but rather, we come to a view only indi-
rectly by considering how we might act in hypothetical circumstances
(note the connection to the discussion of knowledge of the psycho-
logical laws that govern our inductive practices in Chapters 1 and 2).
Further, probabilistic reasoning is an aspect of practical reasoning and
thus enjoys an intimate connection with action, so that even if we could
accurately measure the feelings that attend our beliefs, such measures,
divorced from our actions, could not serve as a suitable basis for an inter-
pretation of probability (T&P, p. 171).
Ramsey makes no judgement as to the ethical or prudential qualities
of a subject’s preferences – all that matters is determining, for a range of

is a proposition such that the subject does not care either way whether
