3.1.2 Peirce and probability
The above is mostly at odds with Peirce’s view of probability. In ‘The
Doctrine of Chances’, Peirce endorses a novel version of the frequency
view.5 The view is novel because, unlike the traditional frequentists,
Peirce denies that a statement of the probability of some proposition
p is a statement about the relative frequency of whatever it is that p
concerns. Rather, he holds that the probability of p is related to the
type of argument by which p has been arrived at as the conclusion.
Probability is a measure of the frequency with which arguments of a
certain kind having true premises lead to true conclusions relative to
the total number of arguments of that kind.6 Probability does not, then,
attach in a straightforward way to propositions simpliciter but rather
only to a proposition relative to the argument form or rule of inference
that led to it (1923, pp. 66–69, 76).
In ‘The Probability of Induction’, Peirce argues against ‘conceptualist’
views that render probability subjective.7 But even Peirce’s conception of
a conceptualist view is far-removed from Ramsey’s treatment of partial
belief. Peirce identifies a degree of belief (though not belief itself) with
‘a feeling of believing’ which ‘does and ought to vary with the chance
of the thing believed’ (1923, p. 87). Connecting this up with his posi-
tive view, what he means by ‘the chance of the thing believed’ – let us
say that the thing believed is p – is a measure of, for every argument
A, B , ... that I have for p as conclusion, the total frequency with which
arguments of the types to which A , B, ... belong lead from true premises
to true conclusions.8 Since this notion of chance is connected to my
background knowledge, it ‘is incontestable that the chance of an event
has an intimate connection with the degree of belief in it’ (loc. cit.).
Nonetheless, even if there were a law-like relation between measurable
degrees of belief, understood as sensations, and chances, the view will

Pragmatism and the Realistic 59
not do for Peirce, because of certain normative constraints it imposes on
the relation between belief and evidence. For instance, call the intuitive
principle that one should apportion the degree of one’s belief to the
strength of one’s evidence W eighting. It is an axiom of probability theory
that P ((p) = 1-P(not-- p). If probability is to be interpreted as degrees of
belief, then our degrees of belief should obey this axiom. But it is irra-
tional, argues Peirce, to apportion the same degree of belief to p across
all cases where there is merely the same proportion of evidence for and
against it. One has, in general, less evidence justifying a belief of degree
0.5 in p in the case where one has one piece of evidence in favour of it
and one against, as in the case where one has fifty pieces of evidence in
favour of it and fifty against it. In the second case, one appears to have
far better grounds for believing p to 0.5 than in the first. So if degrees of
belief are to obey the above axiom, then we must commit a sin against
rationality and reject Weightingg (pp. 89–91).
Conceptualist views have traditionally also been committed to the
Principle of Indifference: if one has no evidence (or insufficient evidence
to form a judgement) either in favour of or against p, one should believe
p to degree 0.5. Peirce argues that this principle, combined with the
axioms of probability, leads to paradox. Imagine a colour spectrum chart
in which I have arbitrarily circled an area A. To what degree should you
believe the proposition p: ‘The first non-terrestrial intelligent beings
encountered by humans will have blood the colour of which falls within
A’? Since you have no evidence either way, according to the Principle
of Indifference, argues Peirce, you should believe it to degree 0.5. Now I
arbitrarily circle another area B; according to the principle, you should
believe to degree 0.5 the proposition q : ‘The first non-terrestrial intelli-
gent beings encountered by humans will have blood the colour of which
falls within B’. If I now circle a new, larger area C which includes both A
and B, the principle dictates that you should believe to degree 0.5 that
the colour will fall within C. But how could the probability of the colour
falling with C be just the same as the probability of it falling in A and the
probability of it falling in B? Given that the area is larger and includes
both A and B , one expects that the probability the colour falling within
C would be greater than the probability of its falling within either A or
B (((pp. 91–92).
Peirce’s criticisms of conceptualist views may have influenced Ramsey
to develop a version of such a view which is immune to Peirce’s objec-
tions. Ramsey is at pains to point out that his view avoids Indifference,
and it does so because, unlike Peirce’s target conceptualist, Ramsey makes
no prescriptive claims about the degree to which anything should be

60 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
believed: the laws of probability, interpreted as concerning degrees of
belief, ‘do not depend for their meaning on any degree of belief in a
proposition being uniquely determined as the rational one; they merely
distinguish those sets of beliefs which obey them as consistent ones’
( T&P, p. 182). That is, everything he writes about the determination of
degrees of belief is at the level of the descriptive and involves no norma-
tive concepts such as truth, reasonableness or success. In particular,
Ramsey’s account at no point issues the edict, ‘Under such-and-such
circumstances, your degree of belief in p should be x’. The only constraint
that Ramsey places on a subject is that of consistency – consistency of
preference, insofar as her preferences are capable of a stable ordering, and
consistency of partial belief, insofar as they obey the laws of probability
and so preclude the possibility of a Dutch book being made against her
( T&P, pp. 182–183). Ramsey’s view is thus a conceptualist view which
answers Peirce’s criticisms by rejecting normative principles such as
Indifference and Weighting. It is, for instance, no part of Ramsey’s view
that every belief m ustt have a determinate degree.
Many contemporary subjective probabilists define rationality with
regard to degrees of belief as being in some sense constituted by a prag-
matic concern to avoid being taken in by a Dutch book. They then argue
that since degrees of belief that obey the laws of probability guarantee
that no such book can be made against a subject, a subject has a coherent
set of beliefs (what Ramsey calls consistentt) just in case they obey those
laws. That is, a subject has a merely prudential interest in rationality so
characterised. It is not obvious that this was Ramsey’s position, since
while he recognises that it is a consequence of a subject’s degrees of
belief obeying those laws that no Dutch book can be made against the
subject, he nowhere makes the constitutive claim.9 Instead, he takes it
that the normative force of so ordering one’s beliefs is s ui generis and as
one with the normativity of deductive logic in general. Ramsey divides
‘arguments into two radically different kinds’, following Peirce: (1)
‘explicative, analytic, or deductive’ and (2) ‘ampliative, synthetic, or
(loosely speaking) inductive’ (T &P, p. 186; Peirce 1923, p. 92). Induction
belongs to the second class, but probabilistic inference belongs to the
first. The laws of probability, like the laws of logic, are ‘merely a method
of arranging our knowledge and eliminating inconsistencies or contra-
dictions’ and ‘the theory of probability is in fact a generalisation of
formal logic’ (T&P, p. 186). Peirce also categorises probabilistic inference
with deduction: probabilistic reasoning is ‘mere explicative reasoning,
and is evidently inadequate to the representation of synthetic reasoning,
which goes out beyond the facts given in the premises. There is therefore

Pragmatism and the Realistic 61
a manifest impossibility in so tracing out any probability for a synthetic
conclusion’ (1923, pp. 93–94).
It is because Ramsey so characterises probabilistic inference that he
thinks it a virtue of his theory that it does not endorse Indifference; like
the laws of deductive inference, the laws of partial belief are neutral as to
the content and status of premises and conclusion, and the normativity
of both the laws of deduction and of probability stems wholly from the
protection they afford against contradiction and inconsistency. They are
‘concerned simply to ensure that our beliefs are not self-contradictory.
We put before ourselves the standard of consistency and construct these
elaborate rules to ensure its observance’ ( T&P, p. 191).
3.1.3 Rationality, enquiry and reasonableness
According to Keynes, what justifies one believing p to degree dd is the
existence of an objective probability relation of degree dd between p and
the subject’s premises. Having rejected such a view, and having argued
that the laws of probability are concerned not with truth but with
consistency, Ramsey owes an account of what, beyond mere consist-
ency, makes it rightt for a subject to have a particular degree of belief in
a proposition. In the last section of T&P, Ramsey turns to consider the
logic of truth – that is, the norms governing which amongst a variety of
consistent sets of propositions we o ughtt to believe. His concern here is
to answer the question: what is it to say of a subject that her degree of
belief in p is reasonable?
It is at this point that the article takes a realistic turn; in order to
answer the question, we shall need ‘to consider the human mind and
what is the most we can ask of it’ (p. 194). Ramsey credits his views here
as being ‘almost entirely based on the writings of C.S. Peirce’ and cites
the two papers already mentioned (loc. cit.). However, as we shall see, it
is not Peirce’s account of the source of the normativity of probabilistic
reasoning (the answer to the question, what is it reasonable to believe?)
that influenced Ramsey here; rather, it is Peirce’s inferential-frequentist
account of the meaning of probability itself.
Ramsey takes it that the human mind makes inferential connections
between propositions on the basis of general rules. Indeed, it is, he
takes it, constitutive of inference that it be bound by rules; propositions
A and B arbitrarily connected in thought do not constitute an infer-
ence, because inferring B from A is, in part, the recognition that A and
B together display a form which legitimises our saying that B follows
(and I do not mean only deductively) from A . This is still no answer to
the question, however, since what we want to know is in virtue of what

62 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
the form displayed by A, B legitimises our saying that B follows from
A, as opposed to saying that, for instance, A follows from B . Why is it
right to say that B follows from A and wrong to say that A follows from
B? The answer that Ramsey wants to give is wholly realistic; it must be
given in terms of a collective choice that we make between different but
equally viable rules for ordering our thought and regulating our theo-
rising about the world, and it must explain a preference for cultivating
one kind of cognitive habit as opposed to another. When the question
is restricted in this realistic way, it can be put as Ramsey puts it: which
rules ‘in a general sense would it be best for the human mind to have?’
(loc. cit.).
Ramsey’s answer is that the inferential rules we ought to adopt are
those for which the frequency with which they lead from true premises
to true conclusions is highest. In the case of partial belief, the degree
to which we ought to believe the conclusions of such inferential rules
should match the frequency with which they lead from true premises to
true conclusions (p. 196). So what one ought to believe, and the degree
to which one ought to believe it, is intimately connected to that part of
Peirce’s account of probability that associates the correct degree of belief
in a conclusion with the frequency of success amongst inferences of the
relevant kind. But it is, of course, n ott Peirce’s account per se, because
Ramsey, unlike Peirce, does not identify such frequencies with the prob-
ability of the conclusion’s being true relative to the argument type in
question.
For Peirce, one’s belief that the probability of p is PP is rendered correct
or reasonable by one’s knowing that the argument by which one has
arrived at p is of a form which is successful (( PP × 100) percent of the time;
that is, one’s belief is justified by its conformity to the relative frequency
with which arguments of the kind that have led one to p turn out to lead
to truth over the long run.1 0
A problem arises for Peirce (and any frequentist) in respect of single
cases: what ought a subject to believe in respect of p given an argument
of type A if, for instance, this is the only argument of type A that she has
entertained? Misak puts the point well: ‘only if the agent can ground
a judgement in knowledge of relative frequencies can she have knowl-
edge of a probability. But the frequency theory provides no grounds for
thinking that the probability on a single trial is the same as the long run
success rate – and it is the long run success rate that determines validity
on Peirce’s account’ (1991, p. 108). Hookway formulates the problem in
terms of the general explanation of why such reasoning may be consid-
ered rational: ‘If reliance upon “probable deductions” is defended by

Pragmatism and the Realistic 63
arguing that, in the long run, the policy of drawing such inferences will
serve us well, then it is hard to see how employing this policy on a single
occasion can be defended’ (2002, p. 227).
Peirce’s solution to this problem is ingenious. The truly logical subject
does not restrict his assessment of the frequency of the success of some
inference kind to his own experience or concern himself only with
his own interests in cases of practical action. Rather, he should adopt
the perspective and attitude of ‘the hero’ whose interests ‘embrace the
whole community’ because ‘he who would not sacrifice his own soul
to save the whole world, is, as it seems to me, illogical in all his infer-
ence collectively. Logic is rooted in the social principle’ (p. 73). It is this
capacity to adopt the perspective of the ideal thinker, to ‘regard his own
[inferences] as being only so far valid as they would be accepted by the
hero’ (pp. 73–74) that justifies our probability assessment in the single
case. ‘We are warranted in making probability assignments or inferences
which depend on a relative frequency in the long run because we can
see that, if everyone made them, then, in the long run, they would be
correct’ (Misak 1991, p. 109). I am warranted in choosing A over B in
the single case because I can see that, in the long run and abstracting
from the particular interests and conditions of particular individuals
(including my own) – that is, assuming the perspective of the heroic
reasoner – if everyone reasons as I have reasoned to arrive at A, then
the community as a whole would be epistemically better off. It is my
capacity to understand how the ideal reasoner, free of bias or self-in-
terest, would reason that warrants my reasoning in accordance with the
long-term frequencies in the short-term case.
Ramsey rejects as unrealisticc the role of idealisation in justifying a
degree of belief in a proposition:1 1
In this ultimate meaning it seems to me that we can identify reason-
able opinion with the opinion of an ideal person in similar circum-
stances. What, however, would this ideal person’s opinion be? As has
previously been remarked, the highest ideal would be always to have
a true opinion and be certain of it; but this ideal is more suited to God
than to man. ( T&P, pp. 193–194)
The point, while not explicitly aimed at Peirce’s heroic reasoner, may,
I take it, be made as follows: how reallyyam I to assume such a perspec-
tive? Assuming that perspective can be said to warrant my reasoning
only if I have correctly assessed that the heroic reasoner or ideal person
would reason as I have. But if I can know that, then what role is the

64 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
idealisation playing in the warrant that attaches to my inference? After
all, the outcome is supposed to be that I reason according to the kind of
argument that I know w ill succeed with the highest relative frequency.
That, ultimately, is the position that the idealisation is supposed to put
me in, that of seeing that in the long run inferences of kind A will be
more frequently correct than those of kind B. Certainly, that would be
the best way to reason in the single case, but Peirce’s account leaves it
mysterious how I could have the requisite knowledge, and once the idle-
wheel of idealisation is removed, it amounts to no more than the exhor-
tation to reason according to the inference type which will in the long
run be best. But that is precisely the kind of knowledge that ‘is more
suited to God than to man’.
Ramsey does not directly address the single-case problem, but I think
we can discern an answer he might have given.12 It is true that Ramsey
identifies as a reasonable degree of belief in p that which accords with
the relative frequency with which the argument type (or rule) by which
one arrived at p yields true conclusions. But in the case of a single judge-
ment, ‘we can only praise or blame it on the ground of truth or falsity’
(T&P, p. 196). That is, in the absence of statistical information which
would enable me to make a judgement about the appropriate degree to
which p should be believed given the rule that I have employed, there
is no assessment in terms of reasonableness to be made. All I can do is
treat the judgement as an experiment, the outcome of which will consti-
tute data that enables me to assess, in future, the rule now employed.
A connected point that Ramsey makes in some later notes on reason-
able degrees of belief is that what is going to count in an assessment of
whether a degree of belief in p is reasonable is what background infor-
mation we take to be relevant to the formation of the judgement. This
comes up as part of a discussion about characterising the content of
the term ‘reasonable’ independently of its use as a more-or-less rhetor-
ical term intended to be synonymous with either ‘my’ or ‘scientific’, as
in when I claim that some opinion is reasonable simply because it is
mine or when I claim that it is reasonable because it is, in some sense,
confirmed by the scientific method ((F C, p. 199; see also T &P, p. 193).
In these notes, Ramsey concludes that while the right account of the
reasonableness of a degree of belief in p is roughly the relative frequency
with which the rule of inference that led to p results in truth, there is
really no point in attempting to precisify the notion any further. Such
an account of reasonableness is of use in only the very simplest cases
because in more complex cases we shall have to assess the judgement
in the context of what the subject took to be the relevant background

Pragmatism and the Realistic 65
information against which the judgement was made. At any rate, such
a question ‘is one asked by a spectator not by the thinker himself: if the
thinker feels a thing relevant he can’t dismiss it; and if he feels it irrel-
evant, he can’t use it’ (((FC, p. 201).
The point of this discussion, and the discussion of the single-case
example, is that the norm of reasonableness that we take to guide the
degree to which we ought to believe some proposition is, at best, a
partial guide, first because there are cases to which it does not apply, and
second because it does not lend itself to useful precisification (and also,
such precisification is not necessary for its usefulness). There may thus
be, in some case, no fact about what would be reasonable to believe (or
to what degree it would be reasonable to believe it). Certainly, it would
not be, as for Keynes, a matter of logic. Nonetheless, it is a norm which
guides our inferential activity towards success because it is one which
encourages us to exercise, in Peirce’s term, ‘self-control’,13 to reflect not
just ‘on the evidence immediately before us, but to stop and think of
all else that we know in any way relevant’ (((F C, p. 201) and to generate
data by experimenting when we have none. The man who does not,
for instance, infer inductively ‘would be unreasonable’, but all that this
means for Ramsey is ‘that he had not got a very useful habit, without
which he would be very much worse off, in the sense of being much less
likely to have true opinions’ (T&P, p. 197). Thus, Ramsey’s account of
reasonableness in relation to degree of belief is ‘a kind of pragmatism:
we judge mental habits by whether they work, i.e. whether the opinions
they lead to are for the most part true, or more often true than those
which alternative habits would lead to’.
Unlike Peirce’s account of reasonableness in respect of degrees of
belief, which is assimilated to a property had by beliefs which are prop-
erly related to a probability measure (the relative frequency of success of
the inference kind in use), Ramsey’s treatment presents reasonableness
as a pragmatic normative concept. It is one that encourages reflection
on our inferential habits, careful consideration of the available evidence
and the regulation of our practices in the interests of developing habits
which lead to judgements which are in the most part true.
I have tried to show that while Ramsey was clearly influenced by
Peirce in respect of the distinction between the logic of consistency and
‘human logic’, or the logic of truth, there are also significant points of
departure. They differ radically about how probability is to be under-
stood but also about the role that relative frequency is to play in a
general account of probability, as well as in a characterisation of how we
ought to conduct ourselves in respect of probabilistic reasoning. Most

66 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
striking, for my project, is Ramsey’s apparent rejection of what is unreal-
istic in Peirce’s account as unrealistic, namely the idealisation introduced
to account for the single-case problem. The notion of reasonableness
that results on Ramsey’s view is one closely connected to the ongoing
regulation of those of our practices and habits that have truth as their
end. As such, it is the philosopher’s job ‘to consider methods of thought
and discover what degree of confidence should be placed in them, i.e.
in what proportion of cases they lead to truth’. That is, it is the philoso-
pher’s job to conduct both empirical and a priori investigations into our
habits of inference, and thereby to provide practical guidance for those
in search of truth. This is thus one way in which philosophy must turn
out to be useful.
3.2 Truth
Ramsey twice mentions Peirce with regard to truth, and each time, he
endorses something of Peirce’s views on truth and meaning. The first
instance occurs in a preliminary draft of a chapter for his projected book
on logic and truth, probably written in 1927 or 1928 and published in
Rescher’s and Majer’s invaluable collection of his notes On Truth. The
second occurs in G P&C.
3.2.1 O n truth
In both earlier and later drafts of the opening chapter to his book, Ramsey
argues that ‘truth is primarily an attribute of thoughts and opinions
and only derivatively of sentences’ (1991, p. 84; see also pp. 6–7). The
model mental state upon which his account will focus is that of belief
because such mental states exhibit two characteristics which are neces-
sary for our attributing truth to the thinker. Believing, in common to
states such as desiring, hoping, wondering whether and so on, exhibits
what Ramsey calls p ropositional reference: ‘A belief is necessarily a belief
that something is so-and-so, for instance that the earth is flat; and it is
this aspect of it, its being “that the earth is flat” that I propose to call
its propositional reference’ (p. 7). Simply thinking of something does
not have this feature; I may, for instance, think of my brother without
thinking that such-and-such is the case with him. Philosophers almost
universally refer to this character of belief as p ropositional, but this is a
term Ramsey explicitly wishes to avoid in order that his account not be
taken to endorse the existence of propositions (and unfortunately, his
choice of the expression ‘propositional reference’ may mislead if one
understands his use of ‘reference’ in terms connected to the existence of

Pragmatism and the Realistic 67
a referent). At any rate, as Ramsey points out, even if there were propo-
sitions, what would make them of interest to us is their propositional
reference, that in virtue of which they are a boutt certain aspects of the
world being a certain way. The propositional reference of a belief (and of
a hope, desire and so forth) is thus that feature of its content that makes
it a neutral representation of a (possible) state of affairs.
Believing, as distinct from desiring, hoping and wondering whether,
also exhibits ‘what may be called an affirmative or assertive character’
(p. 8). It is this characteristic of belief that Ramsey takes to explain our
attribution of truth to beliefs as a special class of mental state, because
while we may say that what John hopes for or desires is already the case
or not the case, this feature being its propositional reference, we may
not say that John has a true hope or desire (at least, not in the same sense
in which we say that John has a true belief). To believe that p, however,
is to state that p, is to make a claim on the world, namely that it is in
conformity with p , and it is the presence of at least some degree of this
assertive character that transforms a neutral representation of a possible
state of affairs into a representation that invites assessment in terms of
truth.
These two features are importantly distinct. The first concerns that to
which we attribute truth when we attribute truth, namely the propo-
sitional reference of a subject’s mental state, and the second concerns
the conditions under which it is appropriate to attribute truth or falsity
to the propositional reference of a subject’s mental state, namely when
that mental state is the state of believing. The importance of the distinc-
tion is that it is what grounds that aspect of Ramsey’s thought which has
sometimes been called a redundancy theory of truth. This is a misleading
name in that Ramsey’s observations concerning the redundancy of the
truth predicate are not intended to do any theoretical work other than
to shift the focus of attention from the predicate to the propositional
reference of the mental state. Here is Ramsey’s schematic analysis: S ’s
belief that p is true if and only if S believes that p and p (pp. 9, 11, 87).
Here, ‘‘p’ occupies a sentential position, and its substitution instances
are used and not mentioned in instances of the analysis. It is only when
we read the final ‘‘p’ as having names of sentences as its instances (that
is, a mention rather than a use of the sentence in question) that English
grammar requires the addition of a predicative verb. When the sentence
is used, however, the required verb already occurs within the sentence,
which is the substitution instance the variable in a particular instance.
It is also vital that one sees ‘is true’ in the definiendum as modifying S ’s
belief that p rather than the sentence which takes the place of ‘‘p’ in an

68 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
instance of it, so that each instance of ‘S’s belief that p’ is a term of which
‘is true’ is a (wholly eliminable) predicate.1 4
I shall not say much more about Ramsey’s treatment of truth here
since I return to it in greater detail in later chapters, except that I hope
that it is clear that the redundancy that Ramsey endorses with regard
to the truth predicate is very much situated within the context of his
thinking that particularr beliefs are the objects to which truth is primarily
attributed. S has a true belief that snow is white just in case S believes that
snow is white and snow is white. The sentential occurrence of the truth
predicate is, for Ramsey, derivative of the belief occurrence: ‘the truth or
falsity of statements depends on their meaning, that is on what people
mean by them, the thoughts and opinions which they are intended to
convey’. A locution such as ‘“snow is white” is true’ is to be analysed
in terms of the belief of someone who asserts it: her belief that snow
is white is true just in case she believes that snow is white and snow is
white. A complete understanding of the truth predicate would thus be
furnished by a complete grasp of the schema given in the definition.
The pertinent question is, thus, what is required for a complete grasp of
the schema? And the answer is that it remains to be explained what it is
for a belief to have the propositional reference that it does. That is, what
is it for S’s belief that p to be a belief that p.
Ramsey puts this division of labour in the form of two questions.
Question I is, ‘Given propositional reference, what determines truth?’,
and Question II is, ‘What constitutes propositional reference?’ (p. 90).
The answer to Question I is, on Ramsey’s view, given by the redundancy
component of his view which is captured by the schematic defini-
tion. This he sees as a simplification of a correspondence view of truth,
one which seeks ‘to eliminate all mention of correspondence’ (p. 91).
It reflects what is obviously correct in a correspondence view without
introducing unexplained metaphysical commitments to relations of
correspondence and indeed also to entities such as facts.
Ramsey does not give the answer to Question II in any of his draft
chapters for the book,1 5 but I shall argue, in Chapter 6, that we can find
the beginning of an account in ‘Facts and Propositions’, so I shall defer
the main discussion until then. But it is in respect of this second question
that Peirce is mentioned; Ramsey summarises with approval an amalgam
of views from ‘How to Make our Ideas Clear’ and ‘The Fixation of Belief’:16
‘A belief that A is B, being roughly a belief leading to such actions as will
be useful if A is B, but not otherwise’ (p. 91). He also, however, makes
it clear that this is no more his view of propositional reference than the
correspondence theory is his view of his truth. Nonetheless, ‘it gives

Pragmatism and the Realistic 69
one element’ in the analysis of propositional reference; the idea at the
heart of a pragmatic treatment of truth, which connects the content
of a belief with the utility of that belief given its truth, is ‘in complete
harmony with my account of truth’. Note, however, that the kind of
answer a correspondence theorist about reference (such as Wittgenstein
in the TLPP) might give to Question II – namely that to believe that A is B
is to ‘have in your mind an entity or entities corresponding to or repre-
senting A being B’ – is also a part of a correct account of propositional
reference. Thus, what we should expect of an account of propositional
reference, and what we will get in Chapter 6, is a mixed view, one that
contains elements of both the correspondence and pragmatist theories.
The correspondence answer to Question I and the pragmatist answer
to Question II each succeed in addressing just one platitude inherent
in the connected concepts of truth and meaning. The correspondence
theory focuses upon that feature of truth which we might, speaking
only loosely, characterise in terms of a relation which holds between a
belief and the world when truth is present and fails to hold when it is
not. That platitude, ‘the evident connection between truth and refer-
ence that a belief “that p” is true if and only if p ’ (p. 92), is captured by
the second conjunct of Ramsey’s definition. The pragmatist (Peircean)
theory of meaning, on the other hand, begins by noting that feature
of the contents of our beliefs that makes them both accountable to the
world and responsive to the place of our activities and projects within it.
The platitude here is that it is good for us to have true beliefs, where that
good is not of a peculiarly epistemic character but is firmly connected to
our ends.17 What is wrong with the Jamesian extension of the Peircean
idea,1 8which acknowledges that there is a connection between truth and
utility, to the relativistic claim that utility in general suffices for truth is
that it sacrifices the first platitude, captured by the correspondence view,
in favour of the second. As we shall see in Chapter 6, Ramsey takes it
that the Peircean component ‘has a considerable contribution to make’
(loc. cit.) in answering the challenge, posed earlier, of explaining what is
it for S ’s belief that p to be a belief that p, but o nlyywhen combined with
one of Wittgenstein’s central theses in the TLP.
3.2.2 Truth and enquiry
Perhaps the claim regarding truth for which Peirce is most widely known
is this:
All the followers of science are fully persuaded that the processes
of investigation, if only pushed far enough, will give one certain

70 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
solution to every question to which they can be applied. ... Different
minds may set out with the most antagonistic views, but the progress
of investigation carries them by a force outside of themselves to one
and the same conclusion. This activity of thought by which we are
carried, not where we wish, but to a foreordained goal, is like the
operation of destiny. No modification of the point of view taken, no
selection of other facts for study, no natural bent of mind even, can
enable a man to escape the predestinate opinion. The great law is
embodied in the conception of truth and reality. The opinion which
is fated to be ultimately agreed by all who investigate, is what we
mean by the truth, and the object represented in this opinion is the
real. That is the way I should explain reality. (1923, pp. 56–57)
In GP&C, Ramsey appears to endorse this Peircean thought. In Chapter 1,
I argued that Ramsey’s discussion of the strawberry abstainers is supposed
to show a certain redundancy in realist construals of counterfactuals and
statements of law and to sustain the claim that to assert a variable hypo-
thetical is to express that one has adopted a certain rule of thought. An
obvious objection to this, and one that Ramsey considers, is that such
a view lands us with relativism. If the people who believe that all straw-
berries are poisonous never eat a strawberry, then their rule accords with
their experience: their system fits the facts. But since their system fits the
facts of their experience and since our system fits the facts of ours, and
in the absence of the purchase on reality that the realist conception of
truth supplies, are they not both equally legitimate rules to adopt? No,
says Ramsey.
We do, however, believe that the system is uniquely determined and
that long enough investigation will lead us all to it. This is Peirce’s
notion of truth as what everyone will believe in the end; it does not
apply to the truthful statement of matters of fact, but to the ‘true
scientific statement’. (G P&C, p. 253)
Where Ramsey and Peirce differ is in respect to what they take to be
the goal of enquiry. For Peirce, it is a body of settled opinion which
is, ultimately, impervious to refutation – what could such beliefs be
other than true? But for Ramsey, it is a ‘scientific statement’ – that is,
a ‘system’ of rules of judgement which constitute a scientific theory –
from which we derive a body of beliefs. And, as discussed in the last
section, that system is constituted by rules which ‘it would be best for
the human mind to have’, namely those with the highest frequency

Pragmatism and the Realistic 71
of correct predictions. Where the strawberry abstainers go wrong is in
having failed to experiment, in having settled upon a body of opinion
too soon; they have failed to exercise the ‘self-control’ characterised by
reflection upon all available information and the generation of new data
by experimentation.
Note also that while Peirce is, on a familiar reading (though see
Misak 1991, 2008, and forthcoming for a more sophisticated account),
committed to a uniquely determined body of opinion ‘fated’ to be
eventually agreed upon by all inquirers, Ramsey is not. Certainly, we
believe that the true system is uniquely determined, and it is this belief
which motivates continual enquiry when two systems compete. But
in ‘Theories’, Ramsey proposes an account of scientific theories upon
which there is a common primary system constituted by the language
of empirical experience which describes ‘the facts to be explained’ (T h.,
pp. 212–213). A secondary system – which consists of the laws and exis-
tential claims (the axioms) that we hypothesise to order that experi-
ence, plus a dictionary converting singular claims couched in empirical
vocabulary into singular claims couched in theoretical vocabulary – is
introduced. A scientific theory is then the deductive closure of such
a secondary system, and those consequences of the axioms, singular
claims and dictionary which are amenable to retranslation into empir-
ical terms are its predictive or observational claims. Given a primary
system, there are multiple possible secondary systems, and so, the possi-
bility of a disagreement arises. However, says Ramsey, genuine disagree-
ment between theories must involve a disagreement in content and
not merely in form: two theories A and B may be such that the first
has as a theoretical consequence Fa and the second not-Fa, but unless
the content of ‘F a’ is identical across both theories, there is not here
a genuine contradiction (Th., pp. 232–234). But the content of the
consequences is, in part, determined by the meaning of the axioms,
the dictionary which introduces the theoretical terms and the singular
judgements from the primary system which one selects to translate into
theoretical claims. That is, the language of the secondary system is to be
understood holistically – the meaning of its terms changing as new laws,
particular judgements or theoretical terms are introduced. Just as there
is thus not necessarily any sense in saying that F a and not-F a are contra-
dictory when derived from two different theories, so it makes no sense
to speak of some consequence being t rue independent of the theoretical
system by which it is entailed.19
What this picture suggests is that it is not disagreementt, characterised in
terms of truth, that is the source of tension between two or more theories

72 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
which are empirically equivalent but rather c ompetition, characterised in
terms of the appositeness of those theories, what Ramsey sometimes
refers to as the s atisfactoriness of a scientific system. What constitutes
satisfactoriness is a question that he does not address, but one might
imagine here an appeal to theoretical virtues (what Ramsey refers to as
‘merits, which may be called in a broad sense aesthetic’ (1991, p.33)), as
well as to psychological facts about human enquirers. Even so, there is
no reason to suppose that such competitions need ever be decided – the
possibility of equally satisfactory, empirically adequate theories is a live
one, in which enquiry is continually driven by the belief that something
will decide between them. Whether there is an endd of enquiry, in the
sense of a determinate completion (as I think there is for Peirce), is thus
an open question, but the end, in the sense of aim, now of enquirers is
what drives the ceaseless activity, independently of whether the prize
exists. As in the case, discussed in Chapter 1, of our activities of infer-
ence and assertion involving counterfactuals and laws, the activity of
scientific enquiry and theorising may be explained without recourse to
realism about the content of scientific theories.
3.3 Ramsey as pragmatist
Wanting to know whether Ramsey was a pragmatist might be wanting
to know whether Ramsey was especially influenced by one or more of
the classical pragmatists. Presumably, however, if that is what one takes
a pragmatist to be, it is at least necessary though still perhaps not suffi-
cient for the title p ragmatistt that he should have been influenced in a
way that is distinctive of pragmatism. Or it might be wanting to know
whether there is anything in Ramsey’s thought – any commitments of
a specially pragmatistt character – that would invite that label. Of course
there may be a causal relation between the first and the second kind of
answer.
With regard to the first question, I recommend Cheryl Misak’s forth-
coming Cambridge Pragmatism: From Peirce and James to Ramsey and
Wittgenstein. Misak is concerned about giving a proper account of Peirce’s
influence on Ramsey and of Ramsey’s role as an early progenitor of prag-
matism in Great Britain. The strongest arguments in favour of the thesis
are to be found in her work, and she gives a much better account of the
full extent of that influence than I am able to do here.
While I have acknowledged in the previous sections a great deal of
Peircean influence in some of Ramsey’s work, I also think that a commit-
ment to the realistic is detectable very early on, plausibly before he read

Pragmatism and the Realistic 73
much Peirce. As we shall see in the next two chapters, Ramsey’s first
paper, C NN, is constantly concerned about reading TLPP through realistic
eyes. That paper was published in the summer of 1923; Ramsey’s refer-
ence in the CNN to the type-token distinction is almost certainly due
to Ogden’s notes on ‘Prologomena to an Apology for Pragmatism’. The
distinction, as I explain at length in Chapter 4, is put to use in an attempt
to offer a deflationary reading of Wittgenstein’s account of propositions,
but a more general scepticism about propositions is present in Ramsey as
early as 1921.20 However, the view offered in CNN is incomplete as it fails
to give, in the absence of the usual work done by the idea of a proposi-
tion, an account of what it is for a propositional token (a sentence or
thought) to have the meaning that it does. Filling out that account, I
shall argue in Chapter 6, is the whole point of F&P.
Of the Peirce that he read, however, Chance, Love and Logicc – published
in 1923 – best captures the Peircean picture, and Ramsey later makes
explicit reference to it. Given its year of publication, it is, I think, unlikely
that Ramsey read this book before he wrote CNN, and so, it is wrong to
attribute the source of his developing commitment to the realistic even
then to his having read Peirce since we see its presence so early. It seems
to me much more plausible to suggest that Ramsey found in Peirce a
writer whose view of philosophy came close to his own. For instance, his
notes on the volume begin with the following line: ‘Let us not pretend
to doubt in philosophy what we cannot doubt in our hearts’. The senti-
ment expressed here is strikingly continuous with the methodological
exhortation expressed in ‘Philosophy’, almost the inverse of Peirce’s
instruction, against philosophical theories which engage in certain
kinds of pretence and which might be put like this: Let us not pretend
to endorse in philosophy what we cannot endorse in our hearts.
F&PP is supposed to be a rich source of evidence in support of Ramsey’s
pragmatism; indeed, Ramsey himself makes reference to the pragmatic
component of his view, which he attributes to Russell (though see
Misak, forthcominggg, for an explanation). Unfortunately, most commen-
tators have focused upon that section of the article which discusses what
Ramsey called ‘chicken-beliefs’ – that is, one way in which we attribute
beliefs to others in order to explain their behaviour and actions. But
Ramsey is very clear that he does not regard this as the only notion of
belief and, further, that what is really important is giving an account
of beliefs which occur to a thinker in the form of words or symbols. It
is this notion of belief – first-person and occurrent – as opposed to the
preferred pragmatist notion – third-person and dispositional – that is the
focus of his account. It is also to that notion of belief that the question

74 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
about the nature of propositional reference, discussed earlier, applies. As
I shall argue in Chapter 6, it is the F&PP account, which involves a causal
and thus potentially pragmatist element, that is intended to complete
the deflationary, Tractarian theory presented in C N. That account is
embryonic; it seems plausible to me that its fuller development would
have supplied the missing chapter of O n Truth.
It is true that Ramsey certainly availed himself of some of the insights
that Peirce saw as flowing out of his pragmatist maxim. But this wider
sense of Peircean pragmatism is not at all amenable to ready characteri-
sation, and it would presumably involve the selection of a handful of
‘central’, defining ideas on some principled basis nonetheless reflective
of a pre-existing conception of what pragmatism entails.
At any rate, taken in this wider sense, it may be correct to call Ramsey
a pragmatist where that term is defined in a defensible manner, so long
as one is prepared also to acknowledge that he was no mere disciple of
Peirce’s but instead approached his philosophy with a magpie mind,
taking up those ideas which assisted in the development of his own
distinctive philosophical outlook. The development of that conception
of philosophy, articulated in the previous chapters, must also be recog-
nised as arising primarily from a deep engagement with Wittgenstein’s
TLPP and certain problems that arise from the theory presented there. In
the next two chapters, I turn to Ramsey’s discussion of TLPP in CNN, and I
identify two criticisms which find their impetus in the realistic spirit as
I have attempted to characterise it.

CNNwas published in Mindd in October 1923. A mere 14 pages long, it is
an illuminating critique of some of the major themes of TLP. Ramsey,
who was only 20 years old at the time, had already had a significant
hand in its translation into English and was deeply influenced by the
work. In September 1923, he went to visit Wittgenstein in Puchberg,
Austria, where the latter was working as a schoolteacher. During their
two weeks together, Wittgenstein spent ‘4 or 5 hours a day’ explaining
TLPP to Ramsey, who began to consider ideas for ‘its further develop-
ment’ (McGuinness and von Wright 1995, p. 186).
This chapter, while largely exegetical, is aimed primarily at justifying
some claims I shall make about what those areas of T LPP that Ramsey
sought further to develop were. In order to support those claims, I
expound some of the very compact arguments that Ramsey made in C NN,
in the course of his treatment of some technical notions in T LP.
The first part, ‘Pictures’, is concerned with Ramsey’s discussion of
the Tractarian account of representation – the picture theory –, of
propositions and of truth. The central topic of CNN is the picture theory
and the connection of that theory with a notion of sense. I begin with
‘Representation and Sense’ and explain what Ramsey understands both
by a picture and picturing. Unlike several commentators, and perhaps
Wittgenstein himself, Ramsey is a non-cognitivist about the relation-
ship between a picture and what is pictured: seeing t hatt something
is a picture is just seeing what it pictures, and no additional mental
‘doings’ are required to take a subject from the former to the latter.
Accordingly, the reading of TLPP I presented in Chapter 2, according
to which representation is the product of the activities of a subject, is
rejected. I then discuss what Ramsey understood by representational
and logical form.

The second part, ‘Propositions’, takes up the non-cognitivist idea,
and it discusses, in the absence of a subject as active representor, the
direction in which Ramsey’s thought begins to move in CN. The subject
of ‘Types, Tokens, and Thoughts’, is Ramsey’s type-token distinction,
which replaces Wittgenstein’s sign-symbol distinction. What we shall
see is that, for Ramsey, a proposition is a type of propositional-sign tokens
which share a sense; propositions are, therefore, reducible to proposi-
tional-sign tokens with a sense. Since significant propositional-sign
tokens are prior to propositions, a question arises around a gap revealed
in the TLP: what is the relation between a propositional-sign token and
its sense?
In ‘Truth and meaning’, I discuss complex propositions and explain
why Ramsey thought that the picture theory was not extendable from
atomic to complex propositions. In support of Ramsey, I point out a
weakness in Wittgenstein’s discussion of negation. This is a second gap.
It is to these two gaps, but particularly to the first, that ‘Facts and
Propositions’ responds, and I return to them in Chapter 6.
4.1 Pictures
The notion of sense deployed in TLPP is both like and unlike a Fregean
sense. The two notions are alike insofar as they are both connected
with understanding and meaning. I mean by this the distinction that
Dummett has drawn, in respect of Frege’s philosophy, between sense
as a component of meaning and reference as a component of a theory
of meaning (1981, p. 84). It is the (Fregean) sense of an expression that
plays a role in understanding – to understand a sentence (to grasp its
sense) is to know what its truth conditions are, in the sense of knowing
what would be the case were it true. The aim of the picture theory is to
provide a wholly general account of how such knowledge is possible
and therefore of what it is to grasp the sense of a proposition – to do
so is to see what it is that a proposition pictures, where ‘pictures’ has a
particular meaning which is made clear in the discussion that follows.
It is this notion of ‘picturing’, and the attendant basic relation of refer-
ence which holds between names and objects, which underwrites the
Tractarian theoryy of meaning.
The Wittgensteinian notion of sense differs from the Fregean in two
ways. First, for Frege, the sense of a complete sentence is a function
from the senses of the expressions it contains, and second, the sense
of an expression, including a complete expression, determines its refer-
ence. For Wittgenstein, only propositions, and not their component

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 79
expressions, have sense, and the sense of an elementary proposition is
determined by the relationship between the components of a proposi-
tion and the elements of the world that they stand for. So reference
is prior to sense. The senses of propositions are explained in terms
of the components of a proposition that share with their referents a
form which limits precisely the ways in which those components may
be meaningfully combined: propositional representation is tethered
to the world – and is thus genuinely representational – by its pictorial
form – that is, its inheriting from its components a range of permissible
arrangements which is identical with the range of possible arrange-
ments of the referents of those components. Pictorial form is what
any representation must have in common with what it represents, and
propositions are a limiting case of representation insofar as they have
in common with what they picture the limiting case of pictorial form,
namely logical form.
Similarly, Wittgenstein has no cognate notion of reference for prop-
ositions, or for complex expressions. As I have already said, sense in
the Tractarian theory of meaning is characterised by the notion of
‘picturing’. But just as the component expressions of an atomic propo-
sition lack the complexity required to picture anything, so too must
a proposition which succeeds in picturing in virtue of its complexity
lack the simplicity required for reference. Frege’s mistake, in assimilating
sentences with (logical) names was essentially that of subsuming the
complex to the simple; but the complexity of a sentence is seen from
its interaction with, for instance, negation. As Wittgenstein points out,
there is no negating a name.
While the above synopsis holds that reference is e xplanatorilyy prior
to sense in a Tractarian t heoryy of meaning, it is important, for now,
not to allow that priority to illegitimately morph into the stronger
claim that the relation between a referent and the component of an
atomic proposition is prior simpliciterr to the sense of a proposition.1
The Tractarian theory of meaning is, as I have so far characterised it,
agnostic as between realism and anti-realism: While we account for the
possibility of meaning in terms of an upwards movement from refer-
ence to sense, there must yet be a further discussion if we are to hold,
as realism demands, that the reference relation is basic and the rela-
tion between sense and Tractarian reference derivative of it. That is,
we are to hold apart the precedence of reference to sense in a theory
of meaning from the precedence of reference to sense as an aspect of
meaning. That discussion must now be held off – first until later in this
chapter, and then resumed in Chapter 6.

4.1.1 Representation and sense
CNN proper begins with the now familiar complaint that Russell’s intro-
duction is mistaken in its contention that ‘in the part of [Wittgenstein’s]
theory which deals with symbolism, he is concerned with the conditions
that would have to be fulfilled by a logically perfect language’. Ramsey
rightly rejects the view that the Tractarian conception of symbolism is
onlyy tied to logically perfectly languages, without endorsing the stronger
view that it is not at all interested in them. He notes that if Wittgenstein’s
aim is to characterise the fundamental mechanism of meaning, the
generality of this goal simultaneously heightens the interest while dimin-
ishing the plausibility of the resultant thesis. In particular, it diminishes
the plausibility of any specific claim which is intended to be true of
language in general, such as that which Russell describes as ‘the most
fundamental thesis of Mr. Wittgenstein’s theory’,2 namely that ‘in order
that a certain sentence should assert a certain fact there must, however
the language may be constructed, be something in common between
the structure of the sentence and the structure of the fact’.
Beginning with the notion of a picture, Ramsey says this of the cognate
notions of representation and sense:
A picture is a fact, the fact that its elements are combined with one
another in a definite way. These elements are coordinated with
certain objects (the constituents of the fact of which the picture is
a picture). These co-ordinations constitute the representing relation
which makes a picture a picture. This representing relation ‘belongs
to the picture’ (2.1513); this I think means that whenever we talk
of a picture we have in mind some representing relation in virtue
of which it is a picture. Under these circumstances we say that the
picture represents that the objects are so combined with one another
as are the elements of the picture, and this is the sense of the picture.
And I think this must be taken to be the definition of ‘represents’ and
of ‘sense’; that is to say, that when we say that a picture represents
that certain objects are combined in a certain way, we mean merely
that the elements of the picture are combined in that way, and are
coordinated with the objects by the representing relation which
belongs to the picture. ( CNN, p. 271)
In Ramsey’s view, every picture is a fact since if it were not for the fact that
its components are arranged in a particular way, and that those compo-
nents are correlated with objects, we could not say that it represented
at all. And for Ramsey, what makes a picture a picture, as opposed to a

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 81
mere arrangement of, for instance, patches of colour, is that it succeeds
in representing something else. It follows that every picture has a sense
because the fact that its components are arranged in such and such a
way is understood as indicating that the correlates of those components
are arranged in just that way. Grasping the sense of a picture is under-
standing the manner in which the picture represents the correlates of its
components to be arranged.
Now some authors have objected that the assimilation of pictures to
facts is extreme: Anscombe points out that ‘a picture is not like a prop-
osition: it doesn’t say anything’ (1959, p. 64). And Potter notes that
‘what Wittgenstein means by a picture cannot be a pictorial complex,
an arrangement of things on a canvas or whatever; it must rather be a
certain fact that we see exemplified in the arrangement when we look at
it a certain way’ (2009, p. 226).3 Anscombe’s objection is to a simplistic
assimilation of propositions to pictures, while Potter’s is to the idea that
an arrangement of things on a canvas – a complex – might constitute a
fact without its being looked at in a certain way. That is, Potter’s view
seems to hold that facts emerge from complexes by being looked at in
the right kind of way; since pictures are facts, pictures emerge from
complexes by being looked at in the right kind of way. On his view, there
is a cognitive step between seeing a complex as a complex and seeing
it as exemplifying a certain fact. Likewise, on Anscombe’s view, there is
a cognitive step between seeing something as a picture and seeing it as
picturing that something is so.
Granted, there is a use of ‘picture’ which is non-representational, in
which I might speak of the Rothko on my wall as a picture or the paint
smears made by a child as a ‘pretty picture’. But these cases may be
safely ignored; the cases we are interested in are those in which the
noun ‘picture’ applies to a construction that says that something is a
certain way or, and this is a nod to Anscombe, can at least be used to say
that something is a certain way.
Potter’s concern is with a difference to be made out between the
picturing analogy in TLPP and cases such as a simple photographic
portrait or a painting. What is present to us in such cases is, on his view,
a complex, an arrangement of shapes or shades. A Tractarian picture,
however, is a fact, and a fact is not a complex. Rather, when we look
at the complex in the right kind of way we i dentifyy the facts contained
therein.
Can the photograph qua complex really be said to represent Tom,
while failing to signify anything about Tom? That is, is there really a way
of seeing a picture of Tom a s a picture of Tom without seeing immediately

82 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
that, for instance, that the image of Tom’s iris is coloured blue repre-
sents that Tom has blue eyes? For Potter, an arrangement of things on a
canvas cannot say that things are thus-and-so until we pick out from the
complex particular arrangements that we recognise to exemplify certain
facts; presenting me with a picture of Tom qua complex is not enough
for me to see it as having as sense, as saying that Tom is thus-and-so.
Rather, first there is the complex and then there is m y discerningg from
the complex that confronts me a fact-like arrangement of things which
I recognise as having a sense, as saying how Tom is.
While clearly we must look at a distribution of things on a canvas in
a particular way in order to see that distribution as a picture, once we
have done that, there is in general no further requirement to look at it
in a certain way to see that it is a picture with a sense; in most cases,
we cannot help but see a certain arrangement of brush strokes which
have a certain colour as representing the sea, the clouds and so on. It
requires an act of will to see those strokes as representing something else
or even, indeed, as the kinds of objects that they actually are. Its being
transparent to us that a picture says that things are thus-and-so is what
we mean, in these cases, of recognising the complex as a picture.
Potter’s suggestion that we must ‘look at things in a certain way’ is
reminiscent of what is wrong with the argument from illusion. There,
the sense data theorist holds that only the postulation of a perceptual
object which stands as an intermediary between the world and me can
explain the possibility of illusion. Since the straight stick looks bent to
me when submerged in water, it cannot be the case that the object of my
perception is all that there is to the content of that perceptual experi-
ence, because if it were, the content of my perceptual experience would
be of a straight stick. So the content of my perceptual experience must
be of some perceptual object distinct from the object of my perception.
Where this argument goes wrong is in the claim that all there is to the
content of my perceptual experience is that of a bent stick. There is a
way of reflecting upon my perceptual experience in which I can isolate
the appearance of a bent stick, but to do so is to deviate from the manner
in which I ordinarily appreciate the contents of my perceptual experi-
ence. Those experiences do not come to me requiring interpretation; I
do not first have the experience of a bent stick and infer the existence
of a straight stick in water. The content of my perceptual experience
is of a straight stick; it is only very unusually, perhaps when someone
draws my attention to it, that I would notice that it appears bent. That
is, it is only when I engage in a particular way of reflecting upon my
own perceptual experiences – perhaps by ignoring or suppressing the

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 83
conceptual content of those experiences – that any such phenomenon
becomes apparent. Likewise, there is a way of seeing a picture as non-
representational: the picture comes to me as a picture of the sea, the
clouds and so on, but I can, of course, with some effort, see it otherwise,
as a mere arrangement of things on a canvas. But this way of seeing is
the derivative, and not the dominant, way. If there is any extra step in
our ordinary ways of appreciating a picture, it is the backwards step from
seeing the sense contained in a picture to seeing the senseless complex.
Of course, not every picture comes to me in this way. Some pictures
require more information; I may not know that, for instance, the line
on the graph represents mortality among smokers. And even if I knew
that, I might not know that the y-axis represented age at death and the
x-axis the population size rather than the other way around. It is not,
however, a particular way of seeing that allows me to appreciate what
the graph represents but rather knowledge of what correlation exists
between its objects and other objects, in this case smokers and their
properties. Once I know this, however, I do not need to see the graph in
any particular way in order to know what facts it represents: the fact that
the line has the curve that it does – the curve that I saw even before I
knew anything about its correlations – is sufficient for me to know what
(purported) fact it represents.
Anscombe’s discussion of the picture theory is highly complex.4 Her
conclusions are intended to offer a resistance against certain earlier read-
ings of T LP, as well as to draw out what is ‘powerful and beautiful’ in the
theory, in spite of which qualities she at any rate takes it to be wrong
(1959, p. 77). I cannot consider the complete view here, but I wish
simply to bring out the cognitivism apparent in Anscombe’s view.
Ramsey’s view is that to say of something that it is a picture is a lready
to have seen what sense it has. Now Anscombe’s view is not at the oppo-
site extreme, namely that a picture may be a mere cipher: she does not
think that while understanding that the photograph is a representation
of Tom is a matter of understanding that the image stands to him in a

In both Potter’s and Anscombe’s views, that an arrangement becomes
a picture is the result of a cognitive act by a subject: seeing it in a partic-

quasi-Cartesian conception of the mind at work in the idea of an actively
representing subject which pre-exists any representation, a mind which
precedes thought in order to produce it. The reading of the solipsism
of TLPP presented in Chapter 2 may be thought to contain just such a
commitment, and so it is no surprise to find similar (though hardly
identical) readings present in both Potter and Anscombe. Ramsey’s view
may be seen as a rejection of that picture, positing instead a mind consti-

nothing more to grasping the sense of a picture than seeing that it is a

it as a picture may require that one first be furnished with information
regarding correlations, but in most cases, that step is not required. Why
that step is not required will have to be filled in with an account of how
it is that particular signs are correlated with particular objects independ-

matter of mere isomorphism; if it were, then any particular sequence
of objects must be said to represent any number of facts – the three
books on my desk, one sandwiched between the other two, would then
represent, just as a matter of accidental isomorphism, the fact of three

connected with the books’ being isomorphic to those objects; but the
fact of their arrangement is not sufficient for their representing that

he writes of the elements of a proposition being ‘coordinated with the
objects b yy the representing relation which belongs to the picture’ (CNN,

brute; I resume the discussion below.

Having established that for one fact to be a picture of – that is, to repre-

there is something in common between a proposition and the fact that
it pictures. His hope is that we may gain an understanding of pictorial
form by considering what Wittgenstein has to say about form in general.

Names and objects
Let us return to a question raised earlier, which concerns the status
of the relation between a name and an object. There I cautioned that
we should remain agnostic about whether such reference relations are
brute. But once it is clear that what a picture must have in common
with a fact is the combinatorial possibilities of the correlated objects of
each, we can dispense with the requirement for brute correspondences
between signs and object. As Sullivan has it, without this identity of

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 89
combinatorial possibilities the picture theory requires ‘a leap of faith,
or even a kind of superstition’ (2001, p. 100) because a proposition’s
picturing a fact will then rest just on there being brute correspondences
between the constituents of the proposition and the constituents of the
fact. But this assumption leaves us with the unanswered question of
how it is that a particular element of a proposition may be said to corre-
spond with a particular element of a worldly fact: what secures the rela-
tion between these constituents?9
To unravel this, one must work backwards from a thought from
Wittgenstein that is clearly influenced by Frege’s context principle: ‘Only
propositions have sense; only in the nexus of a proposition does a name
have meaning’ (T LPP 3.3). From a Fregean perspective, both complete
sentences and the expressions that compose those sentences have senses,
but the route to the sense of a particular expression is via the sense of
the sentences in which that expression can occur. Put another way, one
grasps the sense of a particular expression by becoming cognisant of the
contribution that that expression makes to the whole sentences in which
it occurs. Part of grasping its sense is thus becoming cognisant of how that
expression can be put to use in new sentences to express new thoughts –
one cannot be said to have grasped the sense of an expression unless one
is able to employ that expression in this way, just as one cannot be said
to have grasped a language unless one is able to form sentences other
than those that one has already heard. It is whole sentences, and not
individual words, which are the primary bearers of meaning.
One way to understand T LPP 3.3 is as follows: a written sentence is a
string of characters. That the characters are combined thus-and-so to
produce the string in question is a fact. Since it is a fact, there is a form,
and that form is the possibility of those characters qua simple characters
being combined thus-and-so to produce that string. But a sentence is,
in virtue of being a sentence, more than a string of characters; it is a
fact which is semantically significant. Its semantic significance is due
to its pictorial form. The form of the elements of the string-fact is quite
different from the pictorial form of the sentence since the characters of
the string-fact might have been arranged in a way which failed to yield
a sentence. But the pictorial form of the sentence is such that every
linguistically permissible arrangement of the parts produces a significant
sentence. Those arrangements which are thus not permissible are not an
aspect of the sentence’s pictorial form, since such an arrangement would
fail to yield a sentence. Sullivan makes, I think, the same point when he
writes: ‘To talk of the pictorial form of a proposition is to draw attention
to the fact that any particular propositional structure is an actualisation

90 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
of possibilities of use built into the forms of its constituent expressions’
(2001, p. 102). Such actualisations will be delimited by the rules of use
of those expressions – that is, by the rules which govern the relevant
language. But since the only rules that govern the use of expressions are
the rules of the language of which they are a part (i.e. rules that tell us
how to go about forming sentences in which those expressions occur),
the form of a particular expression is determined just by the possible
combinations with other expressions that the rules of the language
permit it to enter into in order to form sentences.
So far, we are no further along. After all, what right have we to think
that the possible combinations that an expression can enter into with
other expressions in order to yield a proposition should mirror the
possible combinations that objects can enter into in order to yield a
fact? Why shouldn’t the rules that govern the combinatorial possibil-
ities of expressions drift apart from the combinatorial possibilities of
objects? It seems that the short answer must be something like this: the
very idea of one fact picturing another is senseless unless either there
is an alignment between the two sets of combinatorial possibilities or
there exist the sort of brute correspondences between names and objects
that aroused suspicion. But since we are committed to the principle that
what gives an expression a form is its rule-governed role in forming
significant propositions, we can dismiss the view that the name-object
correspondences are brute since such connections are dependent on
the relevant language rules. So we are left with the conditional claim:
if a proposition is to picture a fact, then there must be an alignment
between the combinatorial possibilities of the objects that constitute the
proposition and the objects which constitute the pictured fact. That is,
there must be an alignment between the pictorial form of the proposi-
tion and the form of the elements of the fact.
Alignment between combinatory possibilities for names and objects
is a condition of the representing relation. ... There can be no mystery
over why the significant combination of names in a proposition
should present a state of affairs which is likewise a possibility for the
objects named. Unless it did so there would be nothing in common
between the proposition and the reality, so there would be no
picturing relation holding between the two; and then the ‘names’
would simply not be names of those objects. (ibid. , p. 103)
Wittgenstein suggests that there must be more than a mere alignment
of possibilities.
