express a function from a proposition p to some other proposition must
be shown to express that the proposition p is being signified by a sign.
Ramsey writes that Wittgenstein here
b. explicitly reduces the question as to the analysis of judgement, to
which Mr. Russell has at various times given different answers, to the
question ‘What is it for a proposition token to have a sense?’ This
reduction seems to me an important advance. ( CNN, p. 274)
Russell’s multiple relation theory of judgement held that the correct
analysis of a propositional attitude ascription would show that a judger
stood in a relation, not to a proposition but to each of the components
of a judgement. Thus the correct analysis of ‘A believes that B hates C ’
would show that there exists a relation between A and B , C and hate.
Wittgenstein objected that this theory could not work. Judging that B
hates C is not just to stand in a relation to the elements of the proposi-
tion ‘ B hates C’ but rather to judge it as a fact – that is, it is to judge that
B and h ate and C stand combined in some way which makes clear that
hate is a relation and that B and C are objects that stand in that rela-
tion to one another. Wittgenstein wrote in the N otes on Logicc that ‘every
right theory of judgement must make it impossible for me to judge
that this table penholders the book. Russell’s theory does not satisfy
this requirement’.1 1 As Potter puts it, ‘Russell’s theory did not satisfy
the requirement because in it all the components of what is judged,
including the verb, occurred as terms. Russell therefore did not have
the resources to distinguish, in what is judged, between terms (such as
“similarity”) which derive from verbs and those (such as “penholders”)
which do not’ (2009, p. 122). On Russell’s view, my judging that B hates
Cis no more legitimate than my judging that hate B s C; that is, there is
no distinguishing my judging sense from nonsense.
Russell attempted to amend the theory in the light of this criticism so
that the judging relation included not only the judger and the elements
of the judgement but also the form that the judgement is to take. Note
the similarity to the move against which Ramsey’s argument above was
aimed and which resulted in the objection that the logical form of a
proposition could not be a component of the proposition. There, the
idea was that one fact could not picture another if the logical form of

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 97
the proposition was a part of the proposition, because if it were, the
proposition reduces to a mere list. Here Russell is suggesting that the
logical form of a judgement should be a part of the judgement and,
though Wittgenstein’s response is not recorded, Potter’s reconstruction
of it suggests that it was similar to Ramsey’s (ibid., pp. 122–125). The
problem with including the form as an element in the judgement is
that a relation, such as judging, takes names as arguments, so that each
element within the brackets of J (S, f 2, B, hates, C ) is to be regarded as
a name. But if ‘f 2’ is a name that refers to the form of the proposition,
namely that it involves a two-place relation, then what is judged reduces
to a mere list.
The multiple relation theory of judgement renders what ought to be
a verb – for example, ‘hates’ in ‘B hates C ’ – as a substantive (a name)
so that the judgement becomes a list. Likewise, unless a proposition has
a logical form, we cannot but regard the combination of names in it as
a list. And adding the form of the judgement, or the logical form, as a
component of the judgement, or of the proposition, does nothing to
alleviate this difficulty.
The point that Ramsey is making in (a) is that the form of a proposi-
tion is not an additional element: the way in which we are to understand
talk of a picture having its logical form in common with the pictured
fact is in terms of there being a correspondence between the types of the
elements in the picture and of the types of the objects in the world. After
all, what more is there to a proposition’s having a particular logical form
than for it to consist of elements which are of the appropriate types to
combine in a way which yields a meaningful proposition? In the propo-
sition ‘ aRb’, that is achieved when ‘ R’ appears as a transitive verb and
not as a name. And cognisance of the grammatical types of ‘a ’, ‘b’ and
‘ R ’ in ‘aRb’ shows us that the types of the entity that each designates can
combine in the same way as the elements of the proposition, namely as
a relation relating two objects.
Why then does the question of judgement reduce to the question of
what it is for a token proposition to have a sense? Because what it is
to judge that aRb, then, is simply for a propositional token, composed
of some or other signs but expressing that aRb, to occur in one’s mind
‘accompanied by a feeling of belief’ (((F &P, p. 144). There is no additional
relation required between a judger and that proposition or the compo-
nents of the proposition. In this way, the elements of the proposition
will always occur as of the correct grammatical type since it will never
be the case that what ought to be a verb is forced to occur as a term in a
relation. Thus, as(b) holds, the correct analysis of ‘ S believes that p’ will

98 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
in the end just give the content of a particular propositional-sign ‘‘p’, and
so it will be of the form ‘““p ” says p’.
What Ramsey saw in this was both an end to the difficulties that had
plagued Russell’s views, as well as the result that the picture theory and
the attendant theory of judgement entailed that there need not be a
difference between a theory of judgement and a theory of meaning. For
me to judge that a Rb is just for the names for the components of that
fact to be organised in the correct way in my mind so as to express the
proposition a Rb; what I have judged will then be entirely dependent
upon the sense of the token ‘aRb’. So the place where the real work needs
to be done is in explaining the relation between token propositional-
signs of a particular language (of thought, perhaps) and the senses that
they express.
4.2 Propositions
4.2.1 Type and token
In CNN, Ramsey puts forward an interpretation of Wittgenstein’s account
of propositions which deviates significantly from T LP, mainly by
neglecting all discussion of Wittgenstein’s sign-symbol distinction in
favour of a discussion made in terms of the type and token terminology
borrowed from Peirce. One reason for this might have been simply a pref-
erence for a more established distinction which nonetheless appeared
to supply all that Wittgenstein required of the sign-symbol distinction.
However, I think that such a claim is misleading unless one already has
a minimal conception of the role that this distinction is supposed to
play in a Tractarian theory of meaning. A better theory is that it, at least
as understood by some commentators, commits one to the cognitivist
account of representation that I diagnosed in Anscombe and Potter,
and which Ramsey rejected. That account is related to the positing of
a subject of that cognitive activity that I discussed in Chapter 2, and
which I argued was likely to have been something that Ramsey regarded
with suspicion.
Sentential complexes and propositional-signs
A sentence, Ramsey notes, may be thought of in two ways: as ‘some-
thing of the same nature as the words of which it is composed’ and as
a propositional-sign (C NN, p. 274). How the former is to be understood
depends very much upon how we take words to be individuated, a char-
acterisation which may resist ready formulation.12 For Ramsey, a word

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 99
is an object, and a sentence understood in the former way is a ‘class
of objects’ – that is, a complex – whereas a propositional-sign is a fact,
namely the fact that the words which constitute it are combined in a
certain way. But unless Ramsey’s use of ‘sentence’ deviates from ordi-
nary usage, this account cannot be correct, because a sentence is not
merely a string of words but a string of words which is also grammati-
cally admissible.
Let us distinguish a sentential complex from a propositional-sign,1 3
here a sentential complex is a grammatically admissible string of words,
whereas a propositional-sign is a syntactical parsing of that complex.
Consider, for instance, this sentence: ‘Afghan hounds like hunting
dogs’. This string of words is a sentential complex in virtue of the gram-
matical admissibility of the string, unlike the string of words ‘like dogs
Afghan hunting hounds’ – which although it is a complex, it is not
a sentential complex. But ‘Afghan hounds like hunting dogs’ is open
to two syntacticc parsings: different propositional-signs can be isolated
within it depending upon which elements we take to be the nouns and
which the verbs. So we have:
1. Afgghan hounds like huntingg doggs.
NP-Subj. Verb NP-Obj.
2. Afgghan hounds like huntingg doggs.
NP-Subj. Verb NP-Obj.
Assume that this is the distinction that Ramsey wishes to draw. What
is important to Ramsey’s characterisation is that a sentential complex
need not be significant, even though it is grammatically well formed,
whereas a propositional-sign, being a fact which is also a picture, must
have significance – a sense – in virtue of its being a picture at all.
I take it that Ramsey’s hope is that this taxonomy will capture
exactly Wittgenstein’s distinction between sense and nonsense without
requiring that this be understood in terms of the transformation of a
sign into a symbol. Those sentential complexes which are parsable as
propositional-signs will thus be a subset of those which are grammati-
cally well formed, and the mistake made when taking nonsense to be
sense will be simply that of taking grammatical well-formedness to indi-
cate significance.
Like sentential complexes, propositional-signs may be differentiated
as tokens or as types, insofar as a propositional-sign type will have as
its instances all of those propositional-signs which share what I shall
call the same word-wise constitution. We shall take ‘word’ here to be a

100 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
grammatical unitt which has a canonical physical representation; that is,
following the customary distinction, words are types of physical tokens.
Taking a word to be a grammatical unit also allows that I can say that in
the sentential complex ‘Afghan hounds like hunting dogs’, there are two
propositional-signs as opposed to one.
Thus, both written and spoken tokens of the propositional-sign ‘The
quad is lawned’ share their word-wise constitution, while the tokens
‘The quad is lawned’ and ‘The quad is grassed’ do not. The latter example
shows that this is not the only way in which propositional-signs fall
into types; after all, propositional-sign tokens which fall under different
types with regard to their word-wise constitutions may fall under the
same type with regard to their sense. That is, Ramsey characterises a
Tractarian proposition as a type whose instances are all the proposition-
al-sign tokens that share a particular sense. So the type-token ambiguity
that a Tractarian proposition has which a Russellian proposition does
not have results from the importance that Wittgenstein gives to proposi-
tional-signs, which are, for Ramsey at any rate, essentially sentential and
which are typed into propositions by the sharing of sense. For Russell,
on the other hand, since a proposition has as its components the refer-
ents of the words, there can be no question of a type-token ambiguity.
Propositions are always tokens, made up of the relevant objects, and
the words used to express the propositions are of no relevance to the
identity of the entity.
On Ramsey’s view, talk of propositions must always be reducible to
talk of classes of token propositional-signs which share their sense. But
now this is a radical departure from anything like a Fregean conception
of the sense of a sentence as a thought the existence of which is inde-
pendent of its being expressed, because what propositions there are will
be a function of what propositional-signs are possible – that is, a func-
tion of the ways in which names may be combined in order to picture
other facts.
On many contemporary views of propositions which are the heirs of
Frege’s views, propositions enjoy an existence which is independent of
the linguistic units with which we express them. Indeed, on Frege’s later
view, thoughts are timeless, abstract entities. So there lurks nearby a
puzzle about the nature of our access to them and the ability of our utter-
ances to express and communicate them, a puzzle which is obscured by
analogical reference to ‘grasping’ a proposition. Of course, reversing the
order of dependence does not render the terrain puzzle-free, because
while propositions are demystified if conceived as the types of which
propositional-signs which share a sense are tokens, it remains mysterious

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 101
how a propositional-sign comes to have the sense that it does have. This
is, of course, merely to reiterate the demand with which I left the last
section, namely for an account of the relation between token proposi-
tional-signs and their senses.
Signs and symbols
Why did Ramsey think that a proposition was a type whose tokens were
propositional-sign tokens? Why not say that the tokens of a proposition
were propositional-sign types? Since propositional-sign tokens which
share their word-wise constitution fall under a propositional-sign type,
and propositional-sign tokens which share a sense constitute a proposi-
tion type, the most elegant way to correlate propositional-sign tokens
with propositions is via their types; if it were the case that every like
arrangement of words had like sense, then a propositional type would
be a grouping of propositional-signs which share not only their word-
wise constitution but also their sense. A proposition would then be a
function from propositional-sign t ypes which share a sense.
In natural language, however, not all tokens of a propositional-sign
type do share their sense, since the manner in which individual signs
are used to construct propositional-signs may vary according to context
or convention. This observation would not, however, stand against the
claim that in an ideal language, one in which each individual sign was
correlated with a particular entity without contextual or conventional
variation, the correlation of propositional-sign token with propositions
could occur in the elegant manner described. In that case, propositions
would be just propositional-sign types since a particular sense would be
expressed by all and only the propositional-sign tokens of the same type.
But if our interest lies in natural language, then there can be no hope
of its instantiating the elegant structure, for the following two reasons.
First, natural language is riddled with s emanticc ambiguity: ‘The north
bank is richer than the south bank’ is one propositional-sign token, but
it may be understood as a comment either on the varying fortunes of
offices in the financial district or on the socio-economic disparities in a
city divided by a river.
Second, languages are (at last partially) inter-translatable, and yet if
we attempt to discuss propositional-sign types across languages, we run
into the difficulty of having to admit that while ‘Schnee ist weiss’ and
‘Snow is white’ share a sense, they do not share their word-wise consti-
tution, as they do not share their words. Since words are individuated
by their canonical representations and since canonical representations
will be language relative, there is simply no asking whether ‘Snow’ is

102 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
the canonical representation of the word type under which the token
‘Schnee’ falls. More pressingly, what are we to say of thoughts? As has
already been discussed, Wittgenstein conceived of thought occurring in a
language,1 4 but he remained agnostic as to the nature of that language.15
Let me take each of these worries in turn.
Ambiguity
Defusing semantic ambiguity is one of the functions of Wittgenstein’s
sign-symbol distinction: the same sign may symbolise differently – that
is, contribute variably to the sense of a propositional-sign. If, following
TLP, a proposition is a propositional-sign seen as a symbol, then our
grasping the two different propositions expressed by the sentence ‘The
north bank is richer than the south bank’ is a matter of our seeing the
signs ‘the north bank’ and ‘the south bank’ as each being two different
symbols. Note that this is not the kind of ambiguity that arises from
there being two different ways of seeing the sentential complex itself, as
in a sentence which is open to readings de re and de dicto.16 For instance,
the sentence ‘She wanted the biggest house in Wales’ could be disam-
biguated by the introduction of an operator to distinguish the one
reading from the other, in effect illustrating that what we took to be
one propositional-sign is in fact two distinct propositional-signs. But no
such syntactic device can resolve the ambiguity of the first sentence.
Attempting to resolve that ambiguity, however, by suggesting that the
signs are different symbols seems less a resolution and more a remark
on the fact that we can read the sentence both ways. Ramsey dispenses
with talk of symbols in favour of our being able to make out the distinct
senses that the propositional-sign may express; granted, this is still no
resolution until there is an explanation of how we are able to distin-
guish them but anything that Wittgenstein might say about the means
by which we see the correct symbol in the sign – that, for instance, the
symbol becomes apparent when a context of use is included – could
be said by Ramsey about how we understand the propositional-sign as
expressing one sense rather than the other.
Translation
The sign-symbol distinction also explains how the same symbol may be
expressed by different signs: how, that is, ‘Schnee ist weiss’ may symbolise
what ‘Snow is white’ symbolises and how also I may think that snow is
white in virtue of there being some thought sign which symbolises what
is symbolised by ‘Snow is white’. But how do we articulate the relation-
ship between some set of signs and the sense that they all express? On

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 103
Ramsey’s view, each of these signs is a token of a proposition. But which
proposition? Saying that it is the proposition expressed by a certain set of
propositional-sign tokens offers no assistance in determining its content
unless I have some independent means of grasping the sense expressed
by those tokens. And it is implausible to suppose that my grasping the
sense of ‘Snow is white’ is a function from my knowing what proposi-
tional-signs express that sense – that is, from knowing a wholly articu-
lated disjunction of propositional-signs capable of expressing that sense.
Even were I to know all actual languages, I could not know all possible
ones or indeed the nature of the signs employed by different individuals
in thought.
Later, Ramsey considers whether what I know when I know what the
proposition ‘Snow is white’ expresses is not what signs do in fact share
a sense with that sign, but rather what rule of construction would allow
a sign to express that sense relative to a symbolism (C NN, p. 278). That
is, my knowledge of the symbolism of a language allows me to know,
of some sign ‘α’, whether or not ‘α’ couldd express what ‘Snow is white’
expresses. But as Ramsey points out, this will not do: I would not be
able to analyse ‘ A believes that p’ as ‘“α” says p’, because whether ‘α’
does express p will be determined by whether or not the rules of the
symbolism of which ‘α’ is an expression allow that it should say p .
What I could assert is that ‘ A believes that p’ is to be analysed as ‘“α” in
symbolismΦ says p’ if I know the symbolism that governs the thought
of A . But, says Ramsey, this cannot be the right view, since I may know
that my German friend believes that snow is white without knowing
anything about the symbolism of his thought – my assertion that he
believes pis just that, and not the assertion that his belief that p goes via
a particular symbolism.1 7
Do these criticisms apply to the sign-symbol distinction as Wittgenstein
intended it or only to Ramsey’s type-token reinterpretation of that
distinction? If the original distinction is to do the work required of
it, Wittgenstein must have something to say about the nature of the
relation between a sign and a symbol and, indeed, about the nature of
symbols themselves. Griffin proposed that, since Wittgenstein defines a
sign as what can be perceived of a symbol, a symbol is ‘more than but
nonetheless includes a sign’ (1964, pp. 128–129). This is poor reasoning:
a Cartesian may think that a body is what is perceived of a person while
disagreeing that a body is a part of or is included in the person, and more
parochially, a glint may be all that can be perceived of a dagger on a dark
night without the dagger having that glint as a part of it. For Griffin, the
sign by which a symbol is expressed is ‘an essential part of the symbol,

104 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
and symbols are signs-plus-sense’, so that symbols are differentiated by
difference of sign. But Wittgenstein is explicit that, for instance, in the
three different signs ‘~~p ’, ‘~ ~ ~~p’, ‘~~p (cid:5) ~~ p’, there are not three different
symbols but one symbol, since they share a sense (TLPP 5.512).
Additionally, it is not just propositional-signs which symbolise but also
parts of propositions which are symbols; but since only proposition(al-
sign)s have a sense, symbols which are parts of propositions cannot be
characterised as signs-plus-sense.
A better account is given by Potter, who says that our seeing what a
sign symbolises is akin to the ‘familiar experience of reading’, where
‘I hardly notice which words are actually being used’, instead seeing
through the marks on the page to the meaning that they represent
(2009, p. 215). On his view, the notion of a symbol is an analogue of
a Fregean sense ‘mediating the transition from sign to object, not as
in Frege’s case, to make good a conception of objects as multifaceted,
but nonetheless for a purpose that is still recognisably that of Frege’s
sense, namely that of allowing language to represent a world whose
complexity it cannot hope to match’. What is not clear is in what
sense the notion of a symbol is able to fulfil this task unless it reflects
the fact that the multifaceted nature of objects leaves us hostage to
a posteriori necessities. What complexity is it that the notion of a
symbol enables our language to overcome? Potter is, I think, partly
right that ‘the Tractatus not only does not eliminate the mediating
role of symbols but in a certain sense identifies that role with the
mystical’ (p. 216). What is right about this is the negative claim, but
what seems to me wrong is the identification of the role that symbols
play with the mystical. What is mystical is thatt a symbol can play that
role, and what is mysterious is the account of how it can do so. But
that is to say nothing of the nature of symbols or of their relation to
signs. Potter is clear that for him, symbols are in ‘a different realm.
[They] are not worldly, nor are they of anything like the same nature of
signs’ (p. 215). This amounts to the admission that the theory of TLP
fails to move us on from the difficulties lately mentioned about Frege’s
theory, in particular the independence of the realm of symbols from
our worldly signs and the question of our access to the denizens of that
realm. It should be no surprise, then, that we hit a wall when we try
to discuss the relation between a sign and a symbol without appeal to
metaphor or analogy.
Ramsey’s attempt to map the sign-symbol distinction to Peirce’s type-
token distinction is an attempt to give a realistic account of the rela-
tion between propositions and propositional tokens, one that dissolves

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 105
those difficulties. If a proposition is a type under which various token
signs fall, then there is nothing odder about a proposition than that
there are two letter types such that four of their tokens appear in the
word ‘Mississippi’. The first criticism regarding ambiguity is pertinent
to both Ramsey’s and Wittgenstein’s respective accounts of the relevant
distinction, though it raises different questions for each. The second
criticism, however, appears to apply to only Ramsey’s way of making out
the distinction, and it raises this question: since I do not know the signs
involved in another’s thought, what is it that I know when I know what
proposition someone else believes? What is required is an account of
howw I can know the proposition – sign type – of which their mental sign
is a token if I do not know what their mental propositional-sign token
is. We shall come to that account in Chapter 6.
While this latter difficulty is not directly applicable to Wittgenstein,
not least because Wittgenstein fails adequately to elucidate the relation-
ship between signs and symbols, it is nonetheless a source of dissatis-
faction that Wittgenstein makes no attempt to address the question of
communication and understanding. Nowhere in TLPP does Wittgenstein
show the least interest in determining how we are able to understand
one another. What we have instead is a dismissal of this difficulty which
is part and parcel of the wholesale dismissal of the psychological self
as an entity of no philosophical interest (T LPP 5.641). Someone might
suggest that this accusation is unfair; Ramsey’s difficulty arises precisely
because he has misjudged the Tractarian project as being concerned
with the mechanisms by which particularr propositions are understood
and conveyed and by which particularr languages fulfil the function of
communicating thought. This person would say that Wittgenstein is
engaged in the more profound project of determining the conditions for
linguistic representation in general; how must the world be, how must a
sign be, and how must we be in order that representation be a possibility
at all? Such a response would be short-sighted; after all, what good is the
general account unless it serves also as an account of the particular facts
of our own experience? In Chapter 6, we shall see how Ramsey extends
his account, which is already more r ealisticc in this respect, in order to
answer these questions.
4.2.2 Truth and meaning
Ramsey attributes to Wittgenstein the insight that the question of
judgement reduces to the question of what it is for a proposition to
have a particular sense, describing it as ‘an important advance’. The
next sections of CNN are taken up with expounding and criticising

106 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Wittgenstein’s answer to the question – one I have raised several times –
of determining the relation between propositional-sign tokens and their
senses.
Truth
Ramsey begins with a thought that he returns to many times in later
writing, namely that the truth predicate is redundant; just as the picture
theory shows that the question of judgement is misguided, so it also
shows that any question regarding the designation of the truth predi-
cate is likewise muddled. Once we see that the role of a proposition is
to picture reality, then a proposition is true when its signs are arranged
just as the correlated worldly objects are arranged and false when their
arrangement differs from that of the correlates. It may seem that this
suggests a correspondence theory of truth: ‘is true’ predicated of a prop-
osition indicates that that proposition instantiates a certain property,
namely that of correspondence between its parts and objects, as well as
correspondence between the arrangement of its parts and the arrange-
ment of the worldly correlates. Indeed, Ramsey sometimes wrote as
though he considered the theory to be a version of a correspondence
theory:
Although we have not yet used the word ‘correspondence’, ours will
probably be called a Correspondence Theory of Truth. For if A is B we
can speak according to the common usage of the fact that A is B and
say that it corresponds to the belief that A is B in a way which if A is
not B there is no such fact corresponding to it. (1991b, p. 11)
But Ramsey never embraced a genuine correspondence theory, for three
reasons. First, he expressed scepticism as to there being a single, simple
relation of correspondence which held in all cases of truth. Second,
a (genuine) correspondence theory of truth is not straightforwardly
compatible with a Wittgensteinian account of the constants:
If a belief is disjunctive as it is when Jones thinks that Smith is either
a liar or a fool, are we to say that it is made true by a disjunctive fact?
(loc. cit)
Most important, Ramsey saw the relation between a propositional-sign
and what it represents as far more complicated than that allowed by the
dyadic nature of the relation usually associated with a correspondence
theory. Thus, the theory of T LPP may be seen as committed to a minimal

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 107
correspondence theory of truth insofar as there is something to be said
about the relation between propositions and facts. But what can be said
is such that it can be eliminated in favour of talk of the relations that
hold between the constituents of propositions and the constituents of
facts. That is, talk of correspondence can be eliminated in a single stroke
with elimination of talk of propositions and facts, qua singular entities,
altogether.
Picturing and complexity
Ramsey raises two objections to the picture theory, both intended to
show that it cannot adequately determine the senses of all propositions.
Each of these objections relates to unanalysed proposition tokens: to
those propositional-signs which do not share their logical multiplicity
with the pictured fact.
The first kind of proposition that Ramsey considers are those which,
while they may be elementary, are not completely analysed. Ramsey
gives the example of a propositional-sign sharing its sense with ‘a Rb’
but in which one sign is used for the relation ‘having R to b’ (CNN, p. 275.
See also U n., pp. 118–120). Assume that the sign is ‘φ’, so that ‘φa’ shares
its sense with ‘a Rb’. But now how can ‘φa’ picture that a Rb since ‘φa’
and the fact do not share their logical multiplicity? But if ‘φa’ does not
picture aRb, how does it have a sense?
Ramsey’s defence of Wittgenstein amounts to the claim that the possi-
bility of such signs is a feature of the complexity of ordinary language.
In a perfect language, every proposition would either be completely
analysed or contain signs introduced into the language via definitions
in which the definiens are themselves completely analysed propositions,
so that no such difficulty could arise; the sense of every proposition
would be determined by the senses of analysed propositions, that is,
in accordance with the picture theory. And one might think that, in
the example, ‘φa’ does have a sense only because we introduced the
sign ‘φ’ by way of the completely analysed proposition ‘aRb’, so that,
as Wittgenstein puts it, the sign ‘φ’ ‘signifies via the signs that serve to
define it’ ( TLPP 3.261).18
But this defence misses the point in that Ramsey here uncovers a
difficulty with the Tractarian picture that goes to its core as a philos-
ophy of language. When we learn a natural language, a predicate ‘φ’ is
introduced to us, not by way of a definition but by observing how it is
used in the sentences that we encounter. And since few, if any, signs in
natural language are introduced to a speaker by way of a definition that
contains a completely analysed proposition, it is entirely unclear how

108 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
one determines the sense of a natural language sign. Further, we do not
even know which, if any, of the propositions of natural language are
completely analysed, since we do not know what the simple objects are,
and so we do not know what the simple names are. But without knowl-
edge of which are the elementary propositions, all of natural language
is such that its logical structure is opaque to us – every natural language
sign is just like ‘φ’ with the additional defect of not having been intro-
duced to us by way of an e xplicitt definition. If TLPP is concerned with
uncovering the fundamental requirements on any language whatever,
it leaves us quite in the dark as to how the senses of our sentences,
which are not elementary or completely analysed propositions, are
determined.
The second kind considered are complex propositions, those
containing logical constants. According to T LP, logical constants (and
by this I mean the signs that occur in propositions) do not correspond
to worldly entities but are operations on propositions. That they do not
refer to anything Wittgenstein regarded as his fundamental thought
( TLPP 4.0312). Ramsey’s point in drawing our attention to this class of
propositions is not that Wittgenstein fails to deal with them (as perhaps
he does when it comes to the class of propositions discussed above) but
rather that in dealing with them in the manner in which he does, the
notion of sense as applied to a complex proposition differs unsatisfacto-
rily from the notion of sense already characterised in terms of picturing.
And this difference leaves an unhappy gap in the system.
The notion of sense that Ramsey has already identified is that the
sense of a proposition is how it represents the world as being with regard
to the correlates of the names that it contains. Since this notion of sense
is to be wholly general, applying to all pictures, it ought to apply to
complex propositions too. But in the 5s of T LP, Wittgenstein regards
the sense of a complex proposition not as given by how it represents the
world as being but rather as being given simply by its agreeing or disa-
greeing with certain permutations of truth-possibilities of the elemen-
tary propositions which constitute it. It is this conception that I now
consider before turning to Ramsey’s criticisms.
Complex propositions
The truth-value of a complex proposition is, for Wittgenstein, deter-
mined by a function from a particular permutation of possible truth-
values of the component elementary propositions to a truth-value. Each
elementary proposition is such that what it pictures may be either an
existent or non-existent atomic fact; in other words, objects are arranged

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 109
in accordance with its sense, in which case the elementary proposition
is said to be true; otherwise, it is false. Then, given that each elementary
proposition may be either true or false, for any n elementary proposi-
tions there are 2n distinct permutations of what are called truth-possi-
bilities that correspond to the 2n different possibilities of existence and
nonexistence of the pictured atomic facts.
Each truth-function yields a unique permutation of truth-values when
the truth-possibilities are given as arguments; for n propositions, there
are 22 n unique permutations of truth-values. The truth-table notation
is just one way of illustrating the relevant function: the following illus-
trates the truth-function that corresponds to disjunction.
p q
T T T
T F T
F T T
F F F
An alternative illustration is provided by the notation that Wittgenstein
also occasionally uses, such that ‘(TTTF)(((p , q )’, for example, is a sign for
the same truth-function as the truth table for disjunction, as is ‘‘p (cid:5) q’.19
Let us call this the bracket notation. Now an elementary proposition is
true when what it pictures is the case, so that the truth of a complex
proposition will be dependent upon two conditions: first, whether or
not what each component elementary proposition pictures is the case
or not; and second, what truth-function is, as it were, activated by
the complex proposition. Thus, the truth of a complex proposition is
dependent upon the truth of its atomic constituents; but is the sense of a
complex proposition similarly dependent upon the senses of its atomic
constituents?
Complex propositions are built up from elementary propositions or
from other complex propositions by the application of truth-opera-
tions. As operations can be applied to both elementary and complex
propositions, Wittgenstein uses the term b ases to refer to the proposi-
tions that compose a complex proposition. Truth-operations are distin-
guished from truth-functions in that, while a truth-function takes as
its arguments truth-values and yields a truth-value as its value, a truth-
operation takes propositions as its arguments and yields a proposition as

110 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
its value. A truth-operation is a function from the senses of a number
of propositions to a sense of a single proposition. 20 We can then think
of the logical connectives – Wittgenstein uses disjunction, negation,
material conditional and conjunction – as indicating truth-operations
on propositions.
Different combinations of these operations indicate which truth-
function determines the truth of the resultant proposition, so that, for
example, (((p (cid:6) q) & (q (cid:6) p) correlates with the truth-function expressed
by ‘(TFFT)(((p , q)’. In this way, we see that the logical connectives do
not themselves represent anything; what they symbolise is just what is
symbolised by both the truth-table notation and the bracket notation
for particular truth-functions. We also see that different complex prop-
ositional-signs constructed using different connectives may express the
same proposition since what is relevant to the proposition is the truth-
operations, and hence the truth-functions, employed in its construction.
That is why, as Ramsey points out, ‘(q (cid:6) p ) & (~q (cid:6) p)’ and ‘~(~~p (cid:5) ~~p )’
both have the same sense, namely p.
According to Wittgenstein, a complex proposition expresses agree-
ment or disagreement with the truth-possibilities of elementary propo-
sitions ( TLPP 4.4), and its sense is its agreeing and disagreeing with the
existence of the corresponding atomic facts (TLPP 4.2). Now this notion
of sense still seems quite close to our original notion, where the sense
of an atomic proposition is its picturing that the world is a particular
way. In the case of a complex proposition, we can extend that notion to
capture (4.2), so that the sense of a complex proposition is its picturing
that the world is a particular way in accordance with the truth-function
that the proposition activates. If our proposition is ‘‘p(cid:7) q’, where (cid:7) is
an arbitrary connective, the sense of that proposition is that the sense of
p and the sense of q are combined so as to picture the world in accord-
ance with the distribution of Ts and Fs in the bracket (or truth-table)
notation which corresponds to that indicated by (cid:7). That is, its sense
will be that the atomic facts pictured by p and q either exist or do not
exist, as the relevant truth-function determines that the propositions p
and qare true or false.
In the case of conjunction at least, such an extension is unproblem-
atic; if the proposition is to be true, the world must be as both elemen-
tary propositions picture, so that one may hold that the sense of ‘aRb &
bRa’ is that aRb and bRa. But what is pictured in the case of propositions
that involve the other connectives? In the proposition ‘a Rb(cid:5) bRa’, there
is not one but three arrangements of objects in the world that would
make the proposition true; it could be the case that aRb or that bRa or

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 111
both. Should we then say that the sense of ‘aRb (cid:5) bRa’ is one of either
that a Rb, or that b Ra, or that aRb and bRa? Not only would such a view
be false since only under certain circumstances is the sense of ‘ aRb (cid:5)
bRa’ that aRb, but it also cuts against Wittgenstein’s commitment to the
determinacy of sense. Further, it runs counter to the notion of a truth-
operation being a function from senses to a single sense because a func-
tion must always yield a single value from its arguments.
Alternatively, we could think of it as picturing a disjunction of ways in
which objects are to be arranged in the world. That is, the sense of ‘a Rb
(cid:5) bRa’ is that [aRb or b Ra or [aRb and bRa]]. This, however, is just to say
that ‘ aRb(cid:5) bRa’ pictures a disjunctive fact. But if there were disjunctive
facts, then the constant would have to represent something, namely that
the fact that it pictured has a particular form, which would be precisely
to deny Wittgenstein’s ‘fundamental thought’. So this cannot be the
right way to understand him.
It seems that what must be given up is the picturing notion of sense
for complex propositions.
Every proposition is a truth-function of elementary propositions, and
many differently constructed propositional-signs are the same prop-
osition, because, expressing agreement and disagreement with the
same truth-possibilities, they have the same sense. (C NN, p. 277)
The sense of a complex proposition is given by b oth the senses of
its component elementary propositions and the distribution of truth-
values to those propositions indicated by the connectives involved in
its construction. But that is to move beyond the idea that the sense
of a proposition is its picturing how things stand because the sense of
‘ aRb (cid:5) bRa’ is not that things stand in such and such a way but rather
that things stand in one of several ways. T hatt is why, as Ramsey notes,
the notion of picturing, while readily extendible to conjunctions, which
might be thought to picture just one way in which things stand, cannot
be extended to other complex propositions. In the case of a complex
proposition, the propositional-sign is not ‘completely constituted by the
names that occur in it, for in it there may be logical constants which are
not co-ordinated with objects and complete the determination of the
sense in a way which is left obscure’ (CNN, p. 278).

Negation
One way out of this difficulty would be to exploit the fact that a language
that contains only conjunction and negation is expressively adequate.2 1
Since conjunction presents no difficulty for the picturing notion of
sense, all that would be required is a similar account of negation. This,
however, is not possible. Consider the following:
1. The sense of ‘~~p ’ = ‘‘p’ is false.
Now if the picturing notion of sense is to be defended, then we ought to
be able to move from (1) to:
2. The sense of ‘~p’ = that q .
Being able to do so would be to give an account of the sense of negated
propositions which fits with the basic schema for sense given at 5.542:
2′. The sense of ‘‘p’ = that p. (i.e. ‘‘p’ says p.)
But it is precisely the step from (1) to (2) that cannot be made clear via
the notion of picturing, since there is no single fact of which ‘~~ p’ may
be a picture. If ‘‘p’ is ‘the milk is on the table’, what fact must obtain for
its negation to be true? Clearly that the milk is n ott on the table, but how
is that to be pictured? What particularr arrangement of objects is it that
makes thattthe case?
It might be thought that all I need is (1): understanding ‘~~p ’ is a matter
of understanding that ‘‘p’ is false. But such a view denigrates what it is to
understand a complex proposition, since I need know only that, if ‘~~p ’ is
true, then ‘‘p ’ – the propositional-sign – takes the value false. This is what
Ramsey means when he complains that
it is really only an account of what senses there are, not of what prop-
ositional-signs have what sense. It enables us to substitute for ‘““p”
says p ’, ‘““ p ” expresses agreement with these truth-possibilities and
disagreement with these others’; but the latter formulation cannot be
regarded as an ultimate analysis of the former, and it is not at all clear
how its further analysis proceeds. (C NN, p. 277)
Understanding a negation – what such a proposition says – cannot be
delegated to the metalinguistic level. Wittgenstein’s answer is that the

Ramsey and Wittgenstein: First Encounters 113
sense of ‘~~p ’ contains the sense of ‘‘p’ – that is, that the sign ‘~’ represents
an operation on the sense of ‘‘p ’ such that, where we understood ‘‘p ’ as
indicating that the fact that it pictures obtains, we now understand ‘~~p ’
as indicating that p – the very same sense – is not how things are. But
what is utterly unclear is what it is that we understand when we under-
stand that p is not the case if not simply that ‘‘p’ is false. Ramsey took
the picture theory to solve the problem of truth on the condition that it
could provide a general answer to the question, ‘what is it for a proposi-
tion token to have a certain sense?’; it is, however, hard to see how it
does so if we must make additional appeal to truth and falsity in refer-
ence to answering that question for complex propositions (CNN, p. 275).
We have so far been given an account of sense and thus of under-
standing, which is essentially positive: to understand a proposition is
to see how things are if it is true, where this is to mean how the objects
correlated with the simple signs are arranged if it is true. That was how
we understood the notion of picturing. But now we see that under-
standing ‘~~p ’ is not a matter of understanding how things are arranged
but rather of how they aren’tt arranged. Of course, if ‘~~p ’ is true, then
one or more of many propositions may be true in place of p, but it is
important to see that none of them can have the sense of ‘~~p’: ‘the
milk is not on the table’ does not share a sense with ‘the milk is in
the fridge’. 22 What is wanted, if the picture theory is to be saved for
complex propositions, is an account of what it is that we understand
when we understand a negated proposition which is couched in terms
of the arrangement of the correlates of simple signs. But of course no
such account can be forthcoming, since it would serve only to obliterate
what is distinctive about negation, namely its being used not to assert
that something is the case, but rather to assert that something is not
the case. The essentially positive nature of the picture theory of sense
appears to give rise to an impossible demand if we see it (as Ramsey did)
as requiring an extension to an account of the sense of negated proposi-
tions: if the negated proposition has a sense, then it ought to picture
that something is the case, but what a negated proposition says is that
something is not the case.
Anscombe is sanguine about this matter. While she admits that
‘what is mysterious about negation is that something’s nott being the
case should be capable of being something that is the case’, she claims
merely that ‘the non-existence of a configuration of things is a clear
and intelligible idea’ (1959, pp. 70–71). Her lack of discomfiture arises,
I suspect, from the cognitivism that I have already criticised, which
licenses her conclusion that the picture theory is readily extendible to

complex propositions. For Anscombe, the negation sign is something
like a mental trigger, instructing us to s ee what is pictured by ‘‘p ’ from, as
it were, the other direction, to read it along the negative as opposed to
the positive pole. Our being able to see what is pictured by ‘‘ p’ both posi-
tively and negatively is just what it is for ‘‘ p’ to be a picture at all. But this
is really a theory about judgement in that on her view understanding
a negated proposition amounts to some kind of mental operation on a
non-negated proposition, a determination, for instance, to not assert
or judge that p. What that leaves out, however, is a bridging of the gap
between not asserting or judging that p and asserting or judging that
not-- p; that is, a bridge between (1) and (2).
Anscombe’s account accords, at least in part, with Wittgenstein’s:
Every proposition must a lreadyy have a sense: it cannot be given a
sense by affirmation. Indeed its sense is just what is affirmed. And the
same applies to negation, etc. (TLPP 4.064)
Thus, ‘‘ p’ and ‘~~ p’, far from having differentt senses, have just the same
sense, which is in the one case affirmed and in the other negated.
But if affirmation is a mental activity, then so too is negation, which
is quite contrary to the idea of negation being a logical operation on
propositions.
The source of the difficulty in Anscombe’s case, and thus perhaps also
in Wittgenstein’s, is that she infers that since it is, for Wittgenstein, essen-
tial to a proposition that it be bipolar, it is sufficient for our grasping the
negation of a proposition that we see ‘the occurrence of one picture in
two senses’ (p. 71). For a proposition to be bipolar, however, is just for
it to be capable of being true or false and not capable of being neither
true nor false. And one of the great advantages of the picture theory is
that it is able to explain, without appealing to negative facts, how a f alse
proposition can have a sense.
One might, nonetheless, accept that ‘‘p ’ is such that it is true if things
stand as ‘‘p ’ pictures them and otherwise false – that is, assert its bipo-
larity – without at the same time holding that one’s saying that ‘‘p ’ is
false furnishes one with the sense of ‘~~p’. Saying that ‘‘p’ is false leaves
it quite indeterminate h oww things are. But if the sense of a proposition
is to be given, as suggested by 5.542, according to the schema (2′), then
its sense can leave nothing indeterminate in this manner. The pressing
question is how the metaphorr of one picture occurring in two senses is
supposed to be cashed out, and that is quite independent of the fact that
‘‘p ’ could be false.

Ramsey confessed that he was unable to see how the logical constants
(he considers ‘(cid:5)’ and ‘~’) could contribute to determining the sense of
a complex proposition while remaining true to the picture theory. And
he considered that Wittgenstein affirmed (as Anscombe does) that the
picture theory was naturally extendable to these cases, rejecting the
Fregean view I have discussed above:
[Wittgenstein] does seem to hold that a proposition token resembles
its sense somehow in this sort of way. Thus he says (5.512), ‘That which
denies in “~~p ” is not “~”, but that which all signs of this notation,
which deny p have in common. Hence the common rule according
to which “~~p ,” “~~~~p ”, “~~p(cid:5) ~~p,” “~~p & ~~p,” etc., etc. (to infinity) are
constructed. And this which is common to them all mirrors denial.’
I cannot understand how it mirrors denial. It certainly does not do
so in the simple way in which the conjunction of two propositions
mirrors the conjunction of their senses. (CN, p. 279)
Ramsey may have too readily conflated ‘resembles’ with Wittgenstein’s
use of ‘mirrors’, but more importantly, as he has rejected the sign-symbol
distinction, he cannot see that what Wittgenstein means by ‘that which
is common to them all’ is the symbol which is common to each sign.
Using Ramsey’s distinction renders this passage entirely unhelpful since
the proposition type of which each sign is a token is not a candidate for
resemblingg anything.
Nonetheless, I have tried to show that Wittgenstein’s account of nega-
tion, particularly as summarised by Anscombe, is quite inadequate to
explain the sense of complex propositions in a manner continuous with
the picture theory, a point which Ramsey was keen to draw. Ramsey’s
rejection of the sign-symbol distinction left him unable to appreciate
exactly what Wittgenstein may have intended, but even had he adopted
that aspect of the theory of TLP, the general objection would, or so it
seems to me, still have stood.

5
The Mystical
In the previous chapter, I attempted to clarify a number of Ramsey’s
commitments with regard to T LP: his understanding of sense, his
conception of logical form, his rejection of the sign-symbol distinction
in favour of a type-token distinction and his disavowal of the cogni-
tivism regarding propositional meaning that this entails. We have seen
that Ramsey’s view leaves something as yet unexplained, namely the
relation between a propositional-sign token and its sense. But we have
also seen that if Ramsey’s reconfiguration of the sign-symbol distinction
in terms of tokens and types is to succeed, he must also have some-
thing to say about which sentential complexes are n ott propositional-
sign tokens and why.
I pick up the first question in Chapter 6, but the second I shall discuss
now. What, for Ramsey, demarcates sense from nonsense, propositional-
sign tokens from sentential complexes without a sense? Answering this
question will involve examining the way in which Ramsey addresses
some of the consequences of the ‘mystical’ components of Wittgenstein’s
view and, in particular, the notion of nonsense. Ramsey’s strategy is to
give an account of nonsense which is stripped of any mystical overtones,
and a large part of this chapter will be occupied with discussing how
he does so. I end by discussing what Ramsey’s treatment of Tractarian
nonsense reveals about his conception of what could constitute a theory
of meaning.
5.1 Ramsey and the mystical
Ramsey’s discussion of the mystical elements of TLPP is closely connected
with his criticisms of Wittgenstein’s conception of philosophy and thus
revolves around an investigation into the nature of pseudo-propositions
116

The Mystical 117
and the concept of ‘clarity’ as an end of philosophical reflection ( TLP
4.112). In order to see what Ramsey takes Wittgenstein’s view of philos-
ophy in TLPP to be, we need to turn to the end of C N. There he quotes
4.112:
The object of philosophy is the logical clarification of thoughts.
Philosophy is not a theory but an activity. A philosophical work
consists essentially of elucidations. The result of philosophy is not
a number of ‘philosophical propositions’, but to make propositions
clear. Philosophy should make clear and delimit sharply the thoughts
which otherwise are, as it were, opaque and blurred.
Ramsey complains that we cannot make much of this claim ‘without
some further explanation of “clarity”’, one which accords with the
system of TLPP as a whole (CNN, p. 283).
5.1.1 Internal properties
In Ramsey’s view, a sentence enjoys a degree of clarity in direct propor-
tion to the degree to which its visible properties correlate with – s howw–
the internal properties of its sense: ‘I think that a written sentence is
“clear” in so far as it has visible properties correlated with or “showing”
the internal properties of its sense’ (loc. cit). Recall that, for Ramsey,
a proposition is a type of propositional-sign token, namely that type
constituted by propositional-signs which share a sense.
Now since many different propositional-sign tokens may share the
same sense while differing widely in their form, it is not implausible to
suppose that one might apply an ordering to those tokens in terms of the
degree to which they most perspicuously represent the internal proper-
ties of the sense that they express. What this requires is an account of
internal properties, but for the moment it will be helpful to have in mind
the somewhat rough and ready notion that the internal properties of a
proposition are those features of the proposition that make it t hatt propo-
sition as opposed to another one. And since propositions are types of
propositional-sign tokens, it follows that for a token to be a token of that
type, as opposed to another – that is, to express the sense that it does – it
also must somehow manifest those properties. As Ramsey puts it,
the internal properties of a proposition are those properties of the
token which are, so to speak, internal not to the tokens but to the
type; that is, those which one of the tokens must have if it is to be a
token of that type. (C NN, p. 283)

118 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
What is an internal property of a proposition? In TLP, Wittgenstein
begins his discussion of internal properties and relations by reiterating
that while propositions can represent the whole of reality, what they
cannot represent is what they and reality must have in common for
such representation to be possible (T LPP 4.12). That is, propositions
cannot represent logical form. Nonetheless, propositions can showw the
logical features of reality – the logical form of this or that bit of it – in a
number of ways (TLPP 4.121): by, for instance, containing names which
show us what a proposition is aboutt, by following from one another,
by contradicting one another and by standing in certain s erial relations
(TLPP 4.1211 – 4.1252). And a proposition’s possessing such internal
properties is a feature of its picturing a fact since its possessing those
internal features is inherited from the internal properties of the fact that
it represents (TLPP 4.125). Of course, f acts do not follow from one another
or contradict one another; nor are facts aboutt anything or arranged in
the form of a series. But a proposition’s contradicting another shows that
both facts cannot simultaneously obtain, while one’s following from
another shows that the second obtains in every situation in which the
first does. And a proposition’s being about a shows that a is constituent
of the represented fact, while propositions’ standing in a series shows
that the facts that they represent enjoy a structural relation of a partic-
ular form.
Such properties of a proposition are all that we need in order to indi-
viduate them: if two propositions enjoy all of the same internal proper-
ties, then in virtue of what further property could they be different? As
Ramsey makes clear, however, the internal properties of a proposition
are not the internal properties of a propositional-sign token. I might
individuate the sentence ‘Socrates is wise’ in terms of its word-wise
constitution, noting that it contains the words ‘Socrates’, ‘is’ and ‘wise’
arranged in a particular order. That sentence could not be thattsentence
were it otherwise constituted; that is, the internal properties of a prop-
ositional-sign token are of a different kind to the internal properties of
the proposition that it expresses. Since the individuation of a proposi-
tional-sign token is made by wholly syntactic means, it cannot be those
properties which ‘show’ the internal properties of its sense. Indeed,
there is no internal property of a propositional-sign token which can
characterise its sense: as Ramsey points out, there is no necessity for
the token ‘Socrates is wise’ to have the sense that it does, no internal
property of that token which ensures that ‘Socrates’ means what it does
( CN,p. 283).

5.1.2 Making clear
What Ramsey says next is very hard to follow:
If a sentence says fa it is not an internal property of the sentence
that there is something in it somehow connected with a; but this is
an internal property of the proposition, because the sentence could
not otherwise belong to that proposition type, i.e. have that sense.
(loc. cit.)
That a sentence may express that something is the case – that is, that
Socrates is wise – without containing any element that shows that the
sentence is about Socrates, is of course a commonplace. ‘The teacher of
Plato is wise’ is just one example. Nonetheless, so Ramsey thinks, were
it not the case that the proposition expressed by that sentence has as
an internal property that any sentence expressing it have a component
which is connected in the appropriate way with, in this case, Socrates,
then there would be no explanation of how that sentence couldd express
that proposition (nor of why some sentences could not). If the sentence
‘Socrates is wise’ expresses that Socrates is wise, then it is a property
(but not an internal property) of that sentence that ‘Socrates’ in that
sentence refers to Socrates. And it is an i nternal property of the p roposi-
tion that if some sentence, such as ‘Socrates is wise’, is to express it – is
to be a token of that type – then thatt token must possess precisely the
property that some component of it refer to Socrates.
What is going on here? As Ramsey considers propositions to be types of
propositional-sign token, those which share a sense, talk of propositions
is always reducible to talk of token propositional-signs. If, then, there is
a class of propositional-sign tokens which say that Socrates is wise, then
it follows that some component of each of those tokens must stand in
a referential relation to Socrates. But further, and more important, for a
sentence to have thatt sense – to be a propositional-sign token of thatt type –
it must possess certain properties which allow that it may exhibit the
internal properties of the proposition that it expresses. The structure of
that sentence must enable a range of syntactic transformations allowing
for the production of new sentences which track the inferential relations
that characterise that proposition’s internal properties. Put another way,
a range of propositional-sign tokens cannot express a particular sense
unless those sentences enjoy structures capable of evincing the internal
properties of that proposition. Propositional-signs may express only
those senses for which their articulacy is sufficient: a propositional-sign
token must have ‘exactly as many parts distinguishable as there are in

120 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
the state of affairs, which it represents. They must both possess the same
logical (mathematical) multiplicity’ (T LPP 4.032, 4.04).1
The internal properties of propositions are not visible properties in the
way that the internal properties of propositional-sign tokens are (note
that Ramsey uses ‘visible’ here as he takes a written propositional-sign
token to be the canonical case. But ‘sensible’ might have been a better
choice of word, covering as it does both spoken and thought tokens, as
well as written ones.) But since propositions are merely types of prop-
ositional-sign tokens, the internal properties of propositions cannot
float free of the visible properties of their tokens; what is available for
expression is constrained by the degrees of multiplicity made available
to a range of signs by whatever restrictions govern their construction.
Clarity, as a property of a propositional-sign token, is achieved when
that token’s i nternal properties – that is, its components and composi-
tion – make visible a ll of the internal properties of its sense. Philosophy,
conceived of as having clarity as its end, is thus concerned ‘to facilitate
the recognition of their [propositions’] logical properties by expressing
them in language such that these properties are associated with visible
properties of the sentence’ (CNN, p. 284).
5.2 Ramsey and nonsense
We now require a clear view of what Ramsey takes nonsense to be. In
CNN, Ramsey addresses one species of Tractarian nonsense only: sentences
that attempt to say something about internal properties and relations.
Such nonsensical sentences, or pseudo-propositions, are thought by
Wittgenstein to stand, he says, ‘in some obscure relation to something
inexpressible’ (CNN, p. 280), and it is this feature which is taken to be
the source of their nonsensicality. What Ramsey proposes instead are
piecemeal explanations (though they conform to a common type) of
why we utter nonsense and why we mistakenly take it to be significant,
explanations ‘which have no mystical implications’.
Ramsey considers four examples of pseudo-propositions, all of which,
he claims, arise from the fact that it is always grammatically admis-
sible to replace a definite description with a name. Indeed, it is usually
logicallyy admissible to do so, for the simple reason that, in general, the
analysis of a sentence of the form ‘The (cid:8) is F’ reveals that its significance
relies upon the significance of a sentence of the form ‘(cid:9)xFx’, which in
turn depends upon the significance of ‘F a’ for some a. In general, then,
the significance of definite descriptions is dependent upon the signifi-
cance of sentences of singular reference.2 Pseudo-propositions are then

The Mystical 121
the grammatically admissible instances of such substitutions – senten-
tial complexes – which are not propositional-signs, because they yield
non-logical necessities – that is, sentences which, were they to be signifi-
cant, would fail the bipolarity condition for sense.
5.2.1 Existential statements
The first case is ‘The (cid:8) exists’, the analysis of which contains no conjunct
which is an instance of singular reference: ‘There exists exactly one (cid:8)’.
At any rate, if ‘a ’ is a significant (simple) name, then ‘a exists’ is senseless
because it admits of no negation; as the bipolarity condition for atomic

Flawed as some of Ramsey’s treatments of the above classes of sentences
are, they do reveal the possibility of a Ramseyan response to the reflex-

pseudo-proposition results when we unthinkingly substitute a name for
a definite description in sentential contexts where such substitutions
produce a sentence which purports to state a non-logical necessity.
Nonetheless, there is, in general, a strategy of semantic ascent available
whereby one couldd form a significant sentence which expresses what one
had attempted, badly, to express by the substitution. Whereas ‘a = b’ is,
if true, arguably a non-logical necessity, ‘What “a ” refers to = What “b ”
refers to’ is not, since it is not necessary that ‘a’ or ‘b’ refer to the objects
that they do.
