contents. A view that has tended to concentrate only on the pragmatist
element of F &P, and even then only selectively, is success semantics.
Success semanticists seek to give a reductive account of belief contents
in terms of a nomological relationship between action, desire and
success. On their view, to believe that p is to be in a state such that p’s
being the case is necessary and sufficient for the success of any action
based upon that belief combined with a desire. In common, at least to a
degree, with Ramsey, success semanticists hold that belief contents are
individuated on the basis of their causal role; unlike Ramsey, they hold
that this is so because they take the content of a belief to be exhausted
by the causal role of that state. Success semantics faces a host of difficul-
ties, both as a view in its own right and as an interpretation of Ramsey.
In particular, advocates of success semantics are, to my mind, generally
overly optimistic about the ability of their view to account for a wide
range of belief-kinds held by humans. Simply put, many of our beliefs
have, prima facie, no direct relationship to our actions and desires:
theoretical beliefs, deeply held yet private religious or moral convic-
tions, taboo beliefs, aesthetic beliefs, counterfactual beliefs and so forth.
An excellent example of the kind of belief not e x hypothesi amenable
to success semantics is the famous case from Iris Murdoch (1970) of
the polite mother-in-law (on which more later). Presumably, a success
semanticist must hold such a case to be incoherent, but I should like to
hear the argument.1 I reserve more detailed criticisms of success seman-
tics for another time, except to say that regarding the attribution of the
view to Ramsey, success semantics takes off from some comments that
Ramsey made about what he calls ‘chicken-beliefs’. But, qua interpreter
of Ramsey, what the success semanticist fails to notice is that Ramsey
carefully draws our attention to the ambiguous manner in which the
word ‘belief’ is used. In one case, statements attributing beliefs to others
(and to non-linguistic creatures) are made in order to explain actions
and behaviour. In another case, statements attributing beliefs to others
(and never to non-linguistic creatures) and, canonically, to ourselves,
are made in order to report the contents of their or our mental states. I
shall call cases of the first kind e xplanatory attributions and cases of the
second kind c ontent attributions. Ramsey is quite clear that in the case of
content attributions, the nature of a belief is not to be identified with
its causal role. While S’s believing that p may have causal consequences,
consequences which are the data in explanatory attributions, Ramsey’s
interest is, for the most part, in what constitutes S’s belief that p – that is,
what fact about S makes it the case that she now believes that p. And it
is that kind of account which is of deepest philosophical interest. Thus,

Truth and Meaning 135
for Ramsey, content attributions of belief take priority over the explana-
tory attributions which constitute the chicken case. That is why it is
not ‘chicken-beliefs’, but the latter kind of belief – ‘those expressed in
words’ – that are ‘the most proper subject for logical criticism’ (((F&P,
p. 144). I am thus in complete agreement with Sullivan that the ques-
tion for Ramsey is, ‘What kind of thing is going on, or what kind of fact
is it, when a man believes something?’ (2005, p. 68).
6.1 Facts and judgement
While Frege’s conception of the nature of the content of an assertoric
sentence changed from his earlier to later periods, one feature of his
account of linguistic meaning remained constant, namely that a sentence
expresses a content and that a judgement is a relation of a privileged sort
between a thinker and what it is that a sentence asserting that judge-
ment would express. In ‘The Thought’,2 Frege complains that thought
and judgement are insufficiently distinguished from one another. For
him, a judgement is a particular mental attitude towards a thought, and
the scientific enterprise is to be characterised, in part, by the changing
mental attitude that the scientist has to the self-same thought over
time. First, she apprehends a thought – she thinks it. Then, when she
has completed her investigations, she forms a judgement insofar as she
recognises (or takes herself to recognise)3 the truth of that thought. And,
finally, she may assert that thought sententially and so make her judge-
ment as to its truth accessible to others. That is, to claim that a thought
is true is to express something about one’s own mental states: a willing-
ness to assert it or the fact that one has judged it to be so. For Frege, a
thought which is true is a f actt (1956, p. 307).
Frege’s account raises many questions; primarily, the notion of grasping
a thought, conceived of (at least by the time of D er Gedanke) as an entity
inhabiting a third realm, distinct from the physical and the mental, is a
metaphor, an analogy which is unexplained and which is left without even
an attempt at elimination. And the ready assimilation into philosophical
theorising of the term ‘grasp’ helps to disguise some troubling aspects of
that picture. Frege is not unaware of this difficulty. While characterising
his use of ‘apprehension’ as ‘merely metaphorical’, he makes little effort
to elucidate what our relationship to entities of this kind might be (1956,
pp. 307–310). There is, of course, an innocuous use of the word ‘grasp’,
as when it is a synonym for ‘understand’. But understandingg something is
a phenomenon which needs to be explained, and it is precisely the non-
innocuous use of ‘grasp’ which is wheeled out in order to explain it. In

136 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
that case, pretending that that use is just supposed to be synonymous with
‘understand’ is to render the explanatory view inert.
Frege’s conception of truth as a primitive property of objective
thoughts renders that property without any explanatory role with
regard to, for instance, our preferring correct to incorrect judgements.
After all, what could it matter to me whether I have correctly judged that
pis true, if so judging is merely correctly attributing a property to a self-
subsistent thought? Further, Frege’s account of judgement or assertion is
an account that puts a thinker in a relation to an object, a thought. On
a Fregean analysis, the semantics of ‘S judges that p’ is rendered as the
satisfaction of a two-place function, the referent of ‘__ judges that __’,
by an object, S and the referent of ‘‘p’, which in this sentential context is
the customary sense of that expression as it occurs on its own, namely
the thought expressed by ‘‘p’. But such an account tells us nothing about,
for instance, the relation between one’s judging that p and one’s disbe-
lieving that p , one’s asserting it and one’s denying it. All that we may say
is that in each case a thinker stands in a relation of a particular character
to a thought, which sheds no light upon, for instance, the logical, as
opposed to merely psychological, incoherence of someone’s simultane-
ously denying and asserting that p.
Thus, this beguiling picture leads quite naturally to the construal
of so-called propositional-attitude reports as affirming a binary rela-
tion between a thinker and an object. And the first pages of F &PP are
concerned with making the problematic nature of such a construal clear.
When, at the beginning of the paper, Ramsey says that in our thought
about judgement, assertion and so forth there is a ‘fundamental distinc-
tion’ to be drawn which is ‘hardly open to question’ between the mental
factors and the objective factors involved in a judgement, he does not
intend what Frege intends by objective (((F&P, p. 138). All that Ramsey
intends are factors which are independent of the mental activity of the
particular thinker in question: factors which are to be distinguished
from the mental doings of someone which constitute the various a cts of
judging, asserting and so forth.
Ramsey begins by considering three accounts of what the objective
factor in a judgement might be. The first, Russell’s early view and in
many ways also Frege’s view, that propositions are the objects of judge-
ment and that they have as an unanalysable property truth or false-
hood, Ramsey dismisses (as Russell did) for the reasons that it leaves
mysterious what the difference between a proposition’s being true and
its being false consists in, and that it postulates the existence of ‘objec-
tive falsehoods’ to stand as a relatum for false judgements.

Truth and Meaning 137
The next two accounts concern the thought that the object of a judge-
ment might be a fact. In the first case, what Ramsey has in mind is the
idea that our talk of facts is to be cashed out in terms of complexes: ‘the
facttthat the knife is to the left of the book’ is construed as a simple name
for the complex knife-to-the-left-of-the-book, ‘the fact that Caesar did
not die in his bed’ a simple name for the complex the-murder-of-Caesar-
in-the-Theatre-of-Pompey. This is Russell’s 1910 theory of judgement,
and at this stage, Russell is advocating a multiple-relation theory of judge-
ment: the judgement ‘I see a knife to the left of the book’ is construed
as a multiple relation in which I stand to the knife, the book and the
relation being to the left offf. This judgement is true, says Russell, because, if
I do see a knife to the left of the book, then there exists a complex, knife-
to-the-left-of-the-book. And the existence of that complex is sufficient
to guarantee that the objects to which I stand in the judging relation
are related just as I judge them to be. Such a complex is characterised by
Ramsey (and indeed by Russell) as a f act. As Russell puts it, the complex,
whether the object of a perceptual judgement or a judgement arrived at
via inference ‘is still the necessary and sufficient condition of the truth
of the judgement’ (1910, p. 151). What this means is that while the
judgement itself is not to be understood as a relation which takes the
fact – the complex – as a relatum, the existence of the pertinent fact is
all that is required for the truth of the judgement, analysed as a multiple
relation between the judger and the components of the fact. Likewise,
false judgements are false insofar as there is no fact which corresponds
to the judgement – that is, no complex which is named by ‘the fact that
(cid:8)’ when S judges that(cid:8).
Ramsey finds this account unacceptable, and he presents the following
argument against it. Imagine that I say ‘John perceives that the knife is
to the left of the book’. Now, as it happens, I cannot see the knife or the
book, and in fact the knife is to the right of the book, so that my asser-
tion is false. Nonetheless, argues Ramsey, my statement is significant:
‘John perceives that the knife is to the left of the book’ means some-
thing, and whatever it means is just what it would mean were it true.
But if what the statement means is that there is a relation of perception
which holds between John and a particular complex, knife-to-the-left-
of-the-book, of which ‘the fact that the knife is to the left of the book’
would be a simple name, then it cannot be meaningful, since there is no
object that the ‘the fact that the knife is to the left of the book’ names,
and so no such complex to stand in the relevant relation to John.
The second account is Russell’s 1921 theory. By the time of T he
Analysis of Mind,4 Russell had changed his view of judgement, under the

138 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
influence of Wittgenstein (1995, p. 230).5 Here he writes that a judge-
ment is a relation between a thinker’s mental representations and a fact.
That I believe that it is raining is to be understood as there being first
of all certain mental images or signs – the imagining of rain falling, the
phrase ‘it is raining’, the sense-impression of falling rain – which consti-
tutes the proposition believed. The meaning of that proposition – its
objective reference, a fact – is a function of the meanings of its indi-
vidual components (words, pictures and so forth). Second, there is the
relation which holds between that proposition, entertained in the mind,
and the fact that is its objective reference.
To borrow Russell’s example, assume that A believes the proposi-
tion expressed by ‘Today is Tuesday’, while B believes the proposi-
tion expressed by ‘Today is not Tuesday’. Assume further that today is
Tuesday. The objective reference of both A ’s and B’s beliefs is the fact
that today is Tuesday, but what makes A ’s belief true and B’s false is that
A’s belief points towards the fact that today is Tuesday, and B’s belief
points away from it (loc. cit.). But what Russell actually means, as he
makes clear, is that the word ‘belief’ is not really doing any work here
(p. 231). Rather, it is the meaning of the proposition that points either
away from or towards the fact that today is Tuesday. This is why Ramsey
(at F &P, p. 139) carefully notes in a footnote that on Russell’s view a
belieff is not a relation between any number of things but rather only
the mental component of some other relation, namely the relation of
meaning between a proposition (by which Russell really means a prop-
ositional-sign) and a fact. So we have here something Tractarian in that
the account of ‘S judges that p ’ is really given as an account of what it is
for ‘‘ p’ to say p .
Russell is quite clear that the objective reference of a proposition – the
fact, positive or negative, that it picks out – is a function of the meanings
of the parts of the proposition, which would, at face value anyway, rule
out its being a simple name. Nonetheless, Russell does see the meaning
relation as binary, having as its relata on the one hand a complete prop-
osition which, following Wittgenstein, he takes to be a fact, and on the
other, another fact which is its objective reference. And the meaning rela-
tion will differ in its direction of pointing depending upon whether the
fact, negative or positive, that would make the proposition true exists or
not. In other words, what Russell is pressing is a correspondence theory
of truth. This can be illustrated as follows. Let someone think ‘aRb’, and
let it be the case that ~aRb. Then, the meaning of ‘aRb’ is determined
(i) by its having ~aRb as its objectual reference and (ii) by the meaning
relation which holds between the sign and the fact pointing away from

Truth and Meaning 139
~a Rb. Now, let someone else think ‘~ aRb’. This sign has as its objectual
reference just what ‘a Rb’ has as its, but the meaning of ‘~a Rb’ differs from
that of ‘ aRb’ in that the meaning relation holding between ‘~aRb’ and
the fact points towards the latter. So what is different about the meaning
of the two propositions is that one is true and the other false, and this
consists in the nature of the relation holding between the proposition
and the sign. That is, in the case where the proposition thought is true,
it corresponds to a (in this case, negative) fact, and in the case where it
is false, it fails to correspond to any fact.
Since in this case ‘that the knife is to the left of the book’ is not a
simple name but a description, one amenable to Russellian analysis,
Ramsey’s original argument is ineffective since the analysis would
render the troublesome statements false rather than meaningless.
Taking Ramsey’s example, assume that both ‘the death of Caesar’ and
‘the fact that Caesar died’ are descriptions of some event, the latter a
mere notational variant of the former. Analysis would reveal that their
logical form involved a claim that there is some event E, and E satisfies
such-and-such predicates, and E is the only event that satisfies those
predicates. Then the analysis of ‘John believes that Caesar died in bed’
would be that there is a relation between John and some unique object
that satisfies that description. Since there is no such object, John’s belief
is false but meaningful.
Ramsey has, however, a stronger objection against the view that a
judgement is a relation between a thinker and an object denoted by
a description, which is simply this: ascriptions of belief, and other
propositional attitudes, are intensional. But definite descriptions, if
non-empty, are extensional insofar as when one denotes an object (I
am using the term to cover events), it is the objecttthat one denotes and
not the object-plus-description under which it falls. Assume that John
believes that Caesar died. Then the sentence ‘John believes that Caesar
died’ is analysed as ‘John stands in a believing relation to some event E
such that E is an F, and E is the only F’. But now, since ‘the murder of
Caesar’ picks out the same object as ‘the death of Caesar’ when both are
analysed as descriptions, it follows that John believes that Caesar was
murdered, which rules out the very cogent possibility that John does
believe that Caesar died, but also believes that Caesar died in bed, and
hence was not murdered.
He could quite well be aware that Caesar had died without knowing
that he had been murdered, so that his awareness must have for its
object not merely an event but an event and a character. (((F &P, p. 141)

140 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
And the objection carries over to the 1921 view. If ‘John believes that
Caesar died’ is analysed as involving a m eaningg relation between two
arrangements denoted by a description that involves John’s mind and
another that involves the death of Caesar, then, if Caesar was murdered,
it will follow that John believes that Caesar was murdered. Worse, let
the arrangement of signs in John’s mind be ‘Caesar died’. Then, if that
arrangement stands in a m eaningg relation to the unique event E of
Caesar’s death, and if Caesar was murdered, ‘Caesar died’ m eans both
that Caesar died and that Caesar was murdered, an entirely untenable
result.
So both of Russell’s views – Ramsey’s version of the 1910 view,
according to which a judgement is a relation between a thinker and
a complex-object, a fact, and the 1921 view according to which the
meaninggof a mental propositional-sign is a relation between it, qua fact,
and another fact – are rejected. At root, the rejections turn upon the
instability of the views which attribute to expressions such as ‘the fact
that Caesar died’ the role of either naming or describing a fact conceived
of as object-like. What Ramsey takes this to show is that an expression
of the form ‘the fact that a Rb’ will have to undergo an analysis which
reveals that what is being talked about is not an entity of some kind but
rather the proposition expressed by ‘ aRb’. That is, our talk of facts is to be
eliminated in favour of talk of propositions qua types of propositional-
sign tokens and their properties.
There are, I think, two lessons to be learned from Ramsey’s attacks.
The first is that, while Russell’s 1921 view comes close to a Tractarian
position, it fails to go far enough to resolve the difficulties that Ramsey
presses because it fails to see that what is required for meaning is not a
simple relation, directional or otherwise, between two complex objects –
two facts. Ramsey saw this and endorsed a multiple-relation theory of
judgement, but he argued that Russell’s own multiple-relation theory of
judgement did not go far enough.6
We are driven, therefore, to Mr. Russell’s conclusion that a judgement
has not one object but many, to which the mental factor is multiply
related; but to leave it at that, as he did, cannot be regarded as satisfac-
tory. There is no reason to suppose the multiple relation simple; it may,
for instance, result from the combination of dual relations between
parts of the mental factor and the separate objects. (((F&P, p. 142)
In other words, Russell’s multiple-relation theory of judgement continues
to suppose that what is involved in a judgement is, again, a simple

Truth and Meaning 141
relation between, this time, a thinker and the variety of objective items
which constitute the proposition judged. But while we have already seen
the objection that Wittgenstein made to this view, and which led to its
abandonment by 1921, Ramsey’s criticism is focused elsewhere. It is not,
as it was for Wittgenstein, that Russell’s view does nothing to rule out
our judging nonsense but rather that it fails to characterise the nature of
the relation in which the thinker stands multiply related to the objects
of his thought in any enlightening way.
A theory of descriptions which contented itself with observing that
‘The King of France is wise’ could be regarded as asserting a possibly
complex multiple relation between kingship, France and wisdom,
would be miserably inferior to Mr. Russell’s theory, which explains
exactly what relation it is. (((F &P, p. 142)
What we shall see is that the non-simple, multiple relation that Ramsey
envisages as providing an adequate characterisation of judgement will
be that of TLP, namely that it will rest upon an adequate account of
‘““p ” says p ’. And what this account will not involve is anything like a
correspondence theory of truth; it will not involve the brute correla-
tion of one fact – a propositional-sign – with another – some complex-
object – but it will involve the correlation of two facts by means of the
correlation of their objects (TLP 5.542). That is, what will do the work
is the relationship between the components of facts – the objects which
are arranged in the manner which constitutes the facts; and what that
means is that our talk of ‘facts’ will, ultimately, drop away altogether.
The second lesson is the importance of accounting for the inten-
sional nature of propositional-attitude reports. While this may seem a
redundant prescription quite generally, it takes on renewed force if we
consider the kind of analysis that I have already hinted that Ramsey
will offer us. If ‘S judges that p ’ is to come to ‘““p” says p’, and if the
account of the latter is to be given in terms of the relations between the
objects that constitute the two facts, then names, qua signs, will have to
turn out to be intensional entities. After all, if a judgement is analysed
without reference to the existence of some meaning-altering relation
between a thinker and some other item, then the explanation of the
intensional context created by attributions of cognitive states such as
judging, believing, asserting and so forth will have to arise from the
account of meaning which sustains and supports the entire effort. Note
that this thought is continuous with Ramsey’s proposed solution to
the semantic paradoxes. In ‘The Foundations of Mathematics’, Ramsey

142 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
argues that the semantic paradoxes ‘come in with the symbols we use
to symbolise the facts in variously complicated ways’ (FoM, p. 49). His
solution is to stratify the meaning of ‘means’, relating each stratification
to an orderr at which a symbol is formed. What the view comes down
to is that there may be a range of symbols which all express the same
propositions, but which do not express it in the same way, but rather, to
borrow a term from an earlier quote, have a different c haracterr, such that
the way in which they mean what they mean varies with the order of
their construction. The semantic paradoxes are dissolved by unmasking
the order of the various symbols involved in the construction of para-
doxical sentences, such unmasking revealing that two symbols which
express the same proposition or propositional function do so differently,
and thus that their uniform substitution may not be salve veritate in all
contexts.
6.2 Judgement
6.2.1 Chicken-Beliefs
Ramsey’s positive view of judgement begins with a claim that has
received little attention, namely that what will constitute the mental
factors in a belief will depend ‘on the sense in which we are using the
ambiguousterm beliefff’ ((( F&P, p. 144. Italics mine). There follows a short,
but influential, discussion of the beliefs of a chicken with regard to a
poisonous caterpillar: influential because this discussion has given rise
to success semantics, amongst other pragmatist views. But what is made
abundantly clear in the discussion that follows is that Ramsey is not
proposing a view to account for our use of the word ‘belief’ as we apply
it in explanations of action but rather proposing an account of what
constitutes someone’s believing that p, an account of the use of the word
‘belief’ as it occurs in both first-person reports of belief states and third-
person attributions of belief states to others. That is, Ramsey is interested
in analysing what it is for someone to believe something s impliciterr,
what it is that we are saying of someone, or of ourselves, when we say
that they or we have a particular belief. And while such reports may
serve a role in explanations of action, that is only one feature of their
value within the currency of our talk; this divergence I recorded with
my earlier distinction between belief attributions which are explanatory
attributions and belief attributions which are contentt attributions.
Ramsey draws our attention to one way in which we speak of beliefs:
when I observe that a chicken refuses to eat a certain kind of caterpillar, I
might say that the chicken believes the caterpillar to be poisonous. What

Truth and Meaning 143
I mean when I say that, however, is simply that the chicken, perhaps
because it was made ill by that kind of caterpillar in the past, is now
averse to eating other caterpillars with the same markings. According
to the view that Ramsey has already pressed about how an analysis of
judgement should look, the analysis of the claim ‘The chicken believes
those caterpillars are poisonous’ ought to involve a relation between
the chicken, the mental factors of that belief and the objective factors –
the caterpillar and its toxicity. But it is rather hard to understand
what Ramsey means when he says that the mental factors involved in
the analysis of that attribution are ‘parts of the chicken’s behaviour’:
scratching, pecking, recoiling, withdrawing and so forth seem unlikely
candidates for the mental. I take it that what is meant is that, in that
kindd of belief attribution, it is parts of the chicken’s behaviour which
stand in for – which replace or replicate – the mental factors which are
involved in content attributions. That is, when I attribute a belief to a
chicken in order to explain its behaviour, I am not attributing a c ontent
to its mental state in the way that I am attributing a content to your
mental state when I say ‘You believe that the caterpillar is poisonous’.
On Ramsey’s view of the latter kind of belief, to believe a certain content
is to stand in a multiple relation to some wholly mental elements which
stand in a complex relation to some wholly worldly elements. When I
attribute the belief to the chicken, however, no part of that attribution
involves asserting the existence of a relation between the chicken and
any mental elements at all: when I say that the chicken believes that the
caterpillar is poisonous, I do not mean that the chicken thinks that that
is the case, whereas I do mean (at least in some contexts) that you think
that something is the case if I assert that you believe that the caterpillar
is poisonous. In the chicken case, all that I am asserting is that there
exists a relation between the chicken, its behaviour and some worldly
elements. And, following the sketch of the analysis that I think Ramsey
gives for content attributions, the analysis of the attribution of a belief
to the chicken will involve a s imple relation between a chicken and parts
of its behaviour which stand in a complex relation to worldly items.
The simple component first: the relation between the chicken and
elements of its behaviour. Well, the behaviour in question is i ts behav-
iour. More specifically, the relation between the chicken and elements
of its behaviour is the relation between the chicken and certain bodily
movements such as scratching, pecking, recoiling and withdrawing,
namely the relation that holds between a body and the movements –
scratching, pecking, recoiling and withdrawing – that belong to it. Now,
there is an intentional character to the manner in which I am describing

144 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
those movements, but I think that, at least in chicken cases, such a char-
acter could, with effort, be eliminated. We could, for instance, describe
as ‘scratching’ a range of movements that involve not only the chicken’s
claw but also her head (is she looking at the ground?), her beak (does she
peck after scratching?), her environment (is the ground concrete, or is it
likely to yield food?) and so forth. Of course, after all that, it could be the
case that the chicken is not s cratchinggg, because it is actually unconscious
and is merely having its brain manipulated by a biologist. But if that
were the case, I think we would resist attributing even a chicken-belief
to that glove-puppet chicken; such a case would not show the analysis
to be incorrect, merely that such an explanatory attribution was not
appropriate. At any rate, I am not convinced that it matters whether the
analysis of a chicken-belief attribution involves attributions of purposive
behaviour to chickens: the job of the analysis is not to say what kinds of
things, if any, go on in the minds of chickens but rather what it is that
we are saying when we say that a chicken believes such-and-such.
The trickier relation to characterise is that between parts of the
chicken’s behaviour and the worldly elements – the caterpillar and its
toxicity. Ramsey does not attempt to give a detailed account of the rela-
tion: ‘an exact analysis of this relation would be very difficult’ (((F&P,
p. 144). Instead, he suggests that the relation between the relevant parts
of the chicken’s behaviour, on the one hand, and the caterpillar and
its toxicity, on the other, is that that behaviour is u seful just in case the
caterpillar is toxic:
CB: Any set of actions for whose utility p is a necessary and sufficient
condition might be called a belief that p , and so would be true if p,
that is, if they are useful. (loc. cit.)
What is being called a b elieff here is the chicken’s behaviour since that
behaviour is the set of actions that will be useful to the chicken just
in case the caterpillar is poisonous. Since Ramsey is now proposing an
account of the complex relation which holds between behaviour and
the objective factor, it is not the chicken’s behaviour which features in
the analysis: that part of the belief-ascription is dealt with by the fact
that the behaviour belongs to the chicken. Rather, it is a quite general
proposal regarding the truth-conditions of explanatory belief-ascrip-
tions: x believes that p just in case x ’s actions are such that p is necessary
and sufficient for x ’s actions’ being useful to x .
Much detail is required if this is going to be anything like a convincing
analysis of explanatory belief attributions. For instance, the nature of a

Truth and Meaning 145
belief will be relative to the k indd of creature to which the belief is attrib-
uted since what set of actions will prove useful in the same circumstance
will vary across kinds. So a chicken-belief that p will be quite different
from an elephant-belief that p. Indeed, it seems likely that there will
have to be a great deal of relativisation even within a kind: what actions
prove useful to a well-fed chicken faced with a poisonous caterpillar in
one set of circumstance may be quite different from the actions useful
to a starving chicken in different circumstances.
What these considerations show is that Ramsey’s account is ill-suited
to an analysis of the nature of a non-linguistic belief, and it is thus a
mistake for him to present (CB), and for philosophers to have accepted
that presentation, as explaining what a belief i s (i.e. a set of actions of a
particular sort). Rather, it is intended as a general account of the truth-
conditions of explanatory belief attributions: my ascribing a certain belief
to a chicken is really an assertion about that chicken’s behaviour and the
conditions under which that behaviour may be seen as contributing to
the chicken’s utility. More generally, my ascribing a certain belief to x
in certain cases is to present an explanatory hypothesis regarding x ’s
behaviour, namely the assertion of a relation between that creature’s or
person’s behaviour and the conditions under which that behaviour may
be seen as contributing to its utility.
6.2.2 Beliefs, private states and representation
The kind of belief which Ramsey thinks ‘most proper for logical criti-
cism’ are those that are ‘expressed in words, or possibly images or other
symbols, consciously asserted or denied’ (( F &P, p. 144). That is, on the
one hand, the beliefs in question have a representational structure, one
which is enabled by the fact that such beliefs involve representational
elements – words, images and so forth. And, on the other hand, being
consciously asserted or denied, such beliefs are occurrent. Now Ramsey
declines to discuss in detail what it is that makes an occurrent mental
state a beliefff, as opposed to a hope, desire and so on, except to say, unhelp-
fully, that to have a belief is to enjoy a representation that things are a
certain way accompanied by ‘a feeling or feelings of belief or disbelief’
((F&P, p. 144). Clearly, the emphasis here is on the phenomenal – one’s
believingg that p has a certain experiential character, about which one
cannot, presumably, be mistaken. But surely no account of belief which
asserts that s implyy having some feelings (or engaging in some wholly
mental doings) in relation to some representational elements consti-
tutes a belief in the content of the representation will be convincing.
How, for instance, would a child ever learn what it is for her to believe

146 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
something, as opposed to being in some other mental state, if what it is
to enjoy a belief isonlyyto enjoy some private phenomena in relation to
a representation?
In focusing upon occurrent beliefs, Ramsey does not make the mistake
of thinking that the expression ‘belief’ has as its referent a private mental
state; for a start, he has already shown that there are at least two ways in
which that expression can be used, one of which is not necessarily (or
so I have argued) to be understood as the attribution of a mental state
to a subject. In the case of chicken-beliefs, the word is used in order to
account for the actions and behaviours of non-linguistic creatures (or,
indeed, linguistic creatures who have not articulated their beliefs). But
the role of such attribution in explanations of action is (in the case of
linguistic creatures) always secondary to the reports of the agent as to
their belief states; attributing a chicken-belief to a human agent is to
assert a hypothesis, one always liable to be overturned by that individu-
al’s reporting of the contents of their mental state.7
But more important, Ramsey is careful to argue that there remains
a connection between beliefs qua internal states and attributions of
belief in respect of explanations of action. What makes the attribution
of beliefs to creatures in the non-linguistic case a viable explanatory
strategy when it comes to their actions is the fact that our occurrently
believing what we believe, combined with other factors such as what
we desire and where we are situated spatiotemporally, is causally rele-
vant when it comes to the ways in which we act. In other words, each
individual has access to a causal model which serves as the basis for
their explanatory excursions into the world of acting creatures. That is
why ‘the importance of beliefs and disbeliefs lies not in their intrinsic
nature, but in their causal properties, i.e. their causes and more espe-
cially their effects’ (((F&P, p. 148). Note that the i mportance of beliefs is
their causal function but that that is not their intrinsic nature. What
belief (general) is, and what a belief (particular) may do, are two separate
areas of interest. Belief is a mental state t ype, qualitatively discriminable
from other states, which has representational content; what a particular
tokenbelief may do is cause an agent to act in various ways under a range
of circumstances.
Because Ramsey retains an emphasis on the causal role of belief
in action, and the resultant explanatory role of belief attributions in
explanations of action, there is room to allow that the meaning of
‘belief’ is given not by reference to one’s internal states but rather in
broadly operationalist terms. That is, an explanation of the meaning
of the word ‘believe’ (or better, the expressions ‘S believes that p’) may

Truth and Meaning 147
be given as an explanation of how that word is used, across a variety of
contexts.8Indeed, one might think that that is precisely what Ramsey is
attempting to do in the case of chicken-beliefs: giving an operationalist
account of belief attributions in explanatory contexts which eliminates
reference to mental states. However, Ramsey obviously thinks that
occurrent beliefs which are capable of being reported by their owners
are of independent interest, and one reason for this is that the kind
of operationalist account given of chicken-belief must, in the case of
linguistic creatures, sometimes come into tension with the first-person
reports of those creatures. Clearly, unless one thinks that first-person
reports are privileged over explanatory attributions in such cases, one
would not be interested in them. So we may assume that Ramsey did
take first-person reports to be so privileged. There are, then, two ques-
tions to be answered:
1. What is the relation between the representational content of a
subject’s belief state and the causal profile of that belief?
2. What is the nature of that content?
6.3 Belief and representation
Throughout this chapter I have tried to emphasise that, for Ramsey, the
business end of statements which attribute occurrent beliefs to thinkers,
statements of the form ‘S believes that p’, is the back-end. That is, the
question which must be answered is this: what is it for a belief to have
as its content that p (as opposed to that q , that rr and so forth)? This, I
have claimed, comes down, following T LP, to saying how one analyses
‘““p” says p’ – that is, what it is for a sign to have the sense that it does.
As I have argued, Ramsey was dissatisfied with Wittgenstein’s account,
involving as it does a ‘mystical element’ in the correlating of signs with
objects, or of the transition from a sign to a symbol, a move quite antag-
onistic to the realistic spirit and thus an area in which Ramsey detected
an opportunity for fresh work. That is the point of F &P: to ‘fill up a gap
in his system’ (((F &P, p. 155). In this section, I explain Ramsey’s attempt
to do so.
6.3.1 Names, objects and antirealism
Ramsey begins the presentation of his view by setting some constraints
on the kind of language spoken by the idealised thinker to be consid-
ered. It will be, for the sake of simplicity, a ‘systematic language without
irregularities and with an exact logical notation like that of the Principia

148 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Mathematica’ ((F&P, p. 144). That is, it shall contain three kinds of basic
syntactic elements: names, variables and logical constants. Names,
Ramsey explains, stand for objects, but his use of the term is not exactly
the same as that of T LP, since he now thinks that names and, more
importantly, the objects for which they stand, may be complex.9 A further
departure from TLPP comes with Ramsey’s claim that a simple object is,
unlike a simple object of T LP, relativised to a speaker’s language: ‘If a , R,
and b are things which are simple in relation to his language, i.e. of the
types of instances of which he has names, he will believe that aRb by
having names for a, R and b connected in his mind and accompanied by
a feeling of belief’ (((F &P, p. 145).
On the customary reading of T LP, names are names because they stand
for simple objects, objects which cannot fail to exist. Names are basic
semantic units that stand for basic ontological units. Likewise, appro-
priate combinations of names – atomic propositions – picture combina-
tions of objects – atomic facts. It is thus the basic referential relation
that holds between names and simple objects upon which Tractarian
semantics finds its foundation: sense drifts up to complex propositions
from the fundamental referential relations that hold between names
and simple objects.
I want to describe this view as being bottom up. Such a view holds
that the foundational source of meaning is the obtaining of basic refer-
ence relations between simple names and simple objects – these are the
fixed points in the language. Sullivan, for instance, appears to find it in
TLP, writing that ‘name-object pairings thus constitute the fundamental
link between language and reality’ (2001, p. 100). He accepts that such
a view may seem, to an unsympathetic reader, at first to entail a ‘brute
metaphysical commitment that sustains the whole theory’, namely to
there being irreducible referential relations between Tractarian names
and simple objects (p. 101). He does not see this as grounds for rejecting
it, however, but rather as requiring additional motivation, which he
attempts to provide. Norman Malcolm (1986) is also an advocate of the
bottom-up approach, as is Russell: ‘In this way the naming of simples is
shown to be what is logically first in logic’ (T LP, p. xv).
I said before that while the notion of reference was explanatorily prior
to the notion of sense in TLP, we ought not to confuse that claim with the
stronger claim that the referential relation between names and objects
is ontologically prior (or prior t out courtt) to the senses of propositions.
I said, further, that whether or not one assents to the second of these
claims is the determining factor in whether one holds a realist or anti-
realist view of T LP. Bottom-up views do take it that both of these claims

Truth and Meaning 149
are true, so that sense is dependent upon reference: the bottom-up view
is the most widespread reading. Others, and in particular Hidé Ishiguro,
have held otherwise, advocating a top-down view of reference. In her
‘Use and Reference of Names’, Ishiguro puts forward a view of the seman-
tics of TLPPthat rejects the bottom-up view, arguing that ‘the “objects” of
TLPP are not particular entities in any normal sense, but entities invoked
to fit into a semantic theory’ (1969, p. 21).10 On her view, it is the use
of certain propositions – elucidations – which are the fixed points in a
language and which ‘settle’ the reference of names. But such names are
merely ‘dummy names’; their role is to provide the e xplanatoryyground-
level of a semantic theory which requires that complexity terminate in
simplicity. That is, Ishiguro endorses the claim of explanatory priority
while rejecting the claim of ontological priority for the name-object
relation: on her view, the sense of (perhaps privileged) propositions,
determined by their use, fixes the explanatorily useful reference rela-
tions between names (dummy names) and objects (semantic posits).
I do not say that Ramsey thinks that the names of some language are
dummy names, but if what objects there are is relative to the resources of a
speaker’s language in the sense that what counts as an object is dependent
upon what names are present in that language, then Ramsey’s view may
be characterised as top down. On the bottom-up, realist view, there is no
scope for relativisation of objecthood to linguistic resource, as the very
possibility of meaning in general (as opposed to in particular languages)
is dependent upon there being a fixed correspondence between names
and objects. 11 But if that is so, there cannot be some alternative account
of meaning, working from top to bottom, which settles what objects
there are. If, however, the range of objects, qua basic referents of basic
semantic units, is something that can vary across languages, and thus
across communities of speakers, then while the notion of reference may
serve an explanatory role insofar as it determines what the truth-condi-
tions for some or other sentence of that language are (truth-conditions,
it should be admitted, which can only be given w ithin that language
or another language which shares its names),1 2 it cannot be the case
that the meaning of those sentences is dependent upon p riorr refer-
ence relations holding between simple objects, construed realistically
as substance, and names in that language. Any conception according
to which the fixed form of the world and the reflection of that form
in language is a prerequisite to meaning is a universalist conception of
language in the sense that, since all representation has in common this
basic metaphysical underpinning, all languages share, to some extent,
their conceptual and expressive resources. But the kind of languages that

150 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
Ramsey envisages – languages in which the bottoming out might look
very different from one to the next – may have nothing in common at all.
To accommodate such diversity is to reject the universalist conception
and thus also the dependence of meaning upon the basic metaphysical
underpinning. I have already argued in Chapter 5 that Ramsey’s concep-
tion of nonsense, and his attendant vision of philosophical activity as a
clarifying activity yielding statements in a meta-language which ‘make
clear’ the significance of a range of object-language claims, entails a
rejection of the universalist conception of language. But the top-down
conception of sense raises questions about the plausibility of there being
a universal metalanguage in which the fruits of such investigations could
be expressed since such a language would have to share its names with
all languages. Consequently, there is built into the picture a restriction
on what languages we could investigate, namely those which terminate
downwards in the same names.
6.3.2 Mental signs
Of the two mental factors that Ramsey considers to be constituents of
belief, I have already discussed the ‘feeling of belief or disbelief’. The
second set of factors are signs, ‘images or other symbols’, ‘words, spoken
to oneself or aloud’. Amongst those signs are some which are names
and which are arranged in the mind to form propositional-sign tokens;
I repeat the important quote already given:
If a, R , and b are things which are simple in relation to his language,
i.e. of the types of instances of which he has names, he will believe
that aRbby having names for a, R and b connected in his mind and
accompanied by a feeling of belief. (((F &P, p. 145)
Ramsey’s reasons for positing mental signs as constituents of beliefs are
two. First, if belief contents are constituted by representational elements,
then there is to hand an account of how beliefs, like sentences, may
stand in logical relations to one another. Essentially, Ramsey takes over
the Tractarian account of logical relations as internal relations that hold
between propositions, internal relations which are exhibited (shown)
when the relevant propositions are fully analysed in a perspicuous nota-
tion. Likewise, that beliefs should contain signs is important for his
account of general beliefs since general propositions are to be under-
stood as disjunctions or conjunctions of atomic propositions that are
symbolised in virtue of a propositional function’s being extractable from
atomic propositions.1 3 Relatedly, since Ramsey thinks that the difference

Truth and Meaning 151
between believing aRb and b Ra comes down to the nature of the rela-
tion that the thinker makes between ‘a ’ and ‘b’, the view that beliefs
contain representational elements explains how, for instance, someone
who believes that aRb is also in a position to believe that bRa. That
is, the involvement of representational elements in belief explains how
systematic thought is possible, just as the Tractarian conception of
language explains how systematic linguistic representation is possible.
Second, and this point is closely related to the systematicity point
above, the occurrence of representational elements in belief allows
for the compositionality of belief contents. That is, the meaning of a
combination of discrete, representational elements is a function from
the meaning of those elements: ‘We can say that the causal properties
are connected with a , R and b in such a way that the only things which
can have them must be composed of names of a , R and b . (This is the
doctrine that the meaning of a sentence must result from the meaning
of words in it.)’ (((F&P, p. 149).
6.3.3 Belief and causation
In the previous section, I spoke of beliefs’ having as their constituents
mental signs, amongst which are names. But a name is something more
than a mere sign in that a name is a sign with a semantic value. Just as
I criticised, in Chapter 4, some interpretations of T LPP for relying upon
the cognitive activity of a subject for the setting up of relations between
signs and objects in order to turn those signs into symbols (names),
so now does Ramsey owe us an account of how it is that mental signs,
whatever their phenomenal nature, may come to mean the things that
they stand for.
I believe that Ramsey’s answer is to point to the causal role that beliefs
play in action. In discussing beliefs which require for their verbal expres-
sion logical constants such as ‘not’, Ramsey argues that those terms are
introduced conventionally in order to indicate the difference between
assertion and denial, which in turn consists in ‘a difference of feeling
and not in the absence or presence of the word “not”’ (((F &P, p. 147). That
is, ‘disbelieving that p and believing that not--p are equivalent occur-
rences’ (loc. cit.).14 But what does he mean by their being ‘equivalent
occurrences’? This is, I think, the central question of F&P, and Ramsey
is not afraid to admit its difficulty: ‘to determine what we mean by this
“equivalent” is, to my mind, the central difficulty of the subject’.
Ramsey’s answer is that equivalence of belief content plus belief state
is equivalence of causal role in behaviour. What makes it the case that
believing that not--p and disbelieving that p are equivalent is nothing to

152 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
do with their ‘intrinsic nature’ – that is, nothing to do with what sign
occurs in the mind of the thinker or with what feelings accompany it.
Rather, the fact that whatever signs plus feelings constitute a belief that
not-- p serves to bring about on the part of the thinker the very same
actions under the very same conditions as whatever signs plus feelings
constitute a disbelief that p . Likewise, when a certain combination of
mental signs accompanied by a feeling of belief occurs in me, whatever
the phenomenal character of the signs and the feeling, and a certain
combination of mental signs accompanied by a feeling of belief occurs
in you, whatever the phenomenal character of the signs and the feeling,
what makes it the case that we both believe the same thing is that the
full belief state that I am in is causally equivalent to the full belief state
that you are in. We are both such as to act in the same way under the
same conditions.
Clearly, this amounts to little more than a sketch, but I don’t propose
to fill out much of the detail here. Much more must be said about what
constitutes sameness of conditions and also about what the relevant
conditions are. No doubt, this will involve reference to a thinker’s desires,
their external environment and what else they might believe. What is,
I think, more important for my purposes is that we now have to hand a
ready account of the relation between a token mental propositional-sign
and its sense, and therefore an account of the relation between mental
propositional-sign tokens and propositions, understood as types of prop-
ositional-sign tokens which share their sense. If Ramsey’s account can
be made to work, then mental propositional-sign tokens plus feelings
will form an equivalence class characterised by their causal role; that is,
the sense of a propositional-sign token (restricted to the mental at the
moment) is to be characterised in terms of the causal role that an occur-
rence of that token in the mind of a thinker, when accompanied by the
relevant feeling of belief or disbelief, plays in their behaviour (given the
relevant account of how such roles are individuated in terms of condi-
tions and behaviour). A proposition is then a perspicuous representation
in a common language of the content of those belief states.
So far, the account I have given resembles the theory of success seman-
tics that I have criticised since on both accounts, belief contents are
individuated and identified on the basis of their causal role. The resem-
blance is, however, merely passing because success semanticists take
their theory to not only individuate and identify belief contents but also
to provide their truth-conditions in terms of the success of the actions to
which they contribute. Their theory is a theory of what belief contents
are, a reductive view which gives nomological relations between desires,

Truth and Meaning 153
belief states, action and success a central role. The causal component of
Ramsey’s view, however, is onlyya view about the individuation and iden-
tification of belief contents, a view about in what ‘the importance of
beliefs and disbeliefs lies’, namely their causal properties. The intrinsic
nature of a belief, however, remains a combination of representational
elements and a relevant mental state.
I have already argued that Ramsey’s view of meaning is top down –
that is, that the referential relations between names and objects are
established as a result of the meaning of the propositional signs in
which those names occur. The view that I have so far sketched is para-
digmatically top down since the meaning of propositional-sign tokens
is determined by the causal role that they play in a thinker’s behaviour.
Now Ramsey’s next thought is that, if some propositional-sign token
that occurs in some thinker’s mind has certain causal properties, then its

a way that the only things which can have them must be composed of
names of a, R and b (This is the doctrine that the meaning of a sentence
must result from the meaning of the words in it.)’ (((F &P, p. 149).

6.3.4 Belief, language and forms of life
In this final part of the account, I want to draw some connections
between belief contents on the view that I have characterised as
Ramsey’s, language and the antirealist consequences of the top-down
component of the view.
First, how does one move from a characterisation of belief contents,
first, in terms of causal role and, second, in terms of top-down referen-
tial relations between isolatable signs and objects to a language? Second,
what makes it the case that I can know what you believe on the basis of
your behaviour and that I c an know what you mean by your utterances
if, as I am going to argue, Ramsey’s view takes sentence meaning to be
dependent upon belief contents?

Truth and Meaning 157
The answers to both of these questions must, I think, start from
the assumption that a community of thinkers have certain features in
common. Wittgenstein’s interest in PII in training draws attention to the
fact that the possibility of an adult training a child in the ways in which
certain expressions are used must depend, ultimately, on there existing a
common basis upon which the adult’s expectations of the way in which
the child will understand and respond to stimuli (pointing, gesturing,
grimacing and so forth) are vindicated. That is, the very possibility of
such training is dependent upon their being a range of behavioural

6.4.3 Realism and the realistic
There is a final, deep worry in the vicinity, which is just this: what
reason is there to suppose that a representationalist account of belief –
that is, realism about mental signs and their arrangements constituting
thought – is a realisticc theory?
The last quote of Sullivan’s, and in particular his comments regarding
psychology, put me in mind of the theory of phenomenal colour expe-
rience and Ramsey’s criticisms of it that I discussed in Chapter 1. That

view held that a speaker’s report of seeing a red patch was to be analysed
so as to reveal that ‘red patch’ was a logical construction from simpler
objects – coloured points in the visual field. And Ramsey’s criticism was
that such a theory belonged to psychology insofar as its virtues were the
virtues of a m odel. Philosophically, however, it failed because it failed to
give an account of certain facts, namely those of our own experience.
And believing the theory, as an account of m yy mind, is to engage in a
pretence, to treat my mind as though it were someone else’s mind and
to ignore the experiential data.
Skorupski says of Ramsey that he ‘thinks that human beliefs are couched
in introspectively accessible mental symbols (words, images) whereas
chicken-beliefs are not’ (1980, p. 77). I read Skorupski as meaning by
‘symbol’ just what I have meant by ‘sign’ (i.e. not the inflated, Tractarian
notion of symbol). And he is, I think, correct regarding introspective
access: Ramsey writes, after all, that the mental factors of the relevant
beliefs are ‘words spoken aloud or to oneself or merely imagined’ (((F &P,
p. 144). But now, when I turn my attention upon my own thought, I fail
to introspect arrangements of signs; what I have are thoughts. There is
no, to refer again to Potter’s phrase, seeing past the sign to the symbol,
as when reading: there is justt the symbol, just the content.
On my reading of Ramsey, names are mental signs individuated by
their respective roles in a set of causally efficacious, basic beliefs. As
such, a name is the name it is because of the causal profile that it enjoys,
the contribution it makes to the causal character of a variety of belief
states. But if that were really the nature of thought, then there should
be no such thing as my havingg a thought in the sense of understanding
it. Rather, there would be signs arranged in my mind, and those arrange-
ments would cause me to act in a variety of ways. That view has nothing
to say about how it is that I know, for instance, what my thoughts are
about; it has nothing to say about my knowing what thought it is that
I am thinking.
This is not, I believe, just the problem of consciousness. Consciousness,
on this view, might yield up an impression of the signs themselves.
This would still not be sufficient for my understanding anything.
Introspection might allow me to say ‘Ah, I have “a Rb” in my mind now’,
but it would not allow me to say, on this view, that I am thinking that
aRb without the addition of some reliable relation between the presence
of such signs and phenomenology of thinking. But the experience of
thought is the reverse: introspection allows me to say that I am thinking
aRb, but it tells me nothing about the constituents of my mind, if any,
which enable that thought.

as marriage correlating them. (((FoMM, p. 23)
The progression of thought displayed in these quotes is quite clear.
Ramsey in 1923 immediately saw that a logic without identity could
not provide a basis for mathematics; having accepted Wittgenstein’s
arguments against both the primitive notion of identity and Russell’s
definition of identity, he then saw that the logicist system of Principia,
with its intensional conception of a class, could not provide that basis
either. Nonetheless, Ramsey did accept that P rincipia provided the closest
thing to a logical basis for mathematics, and he thought that it could
be salvaged. That is the whole point of FoM: Ramsey was attempting to
develop a Tractarian Logicism, an ultimately unwholesome hybrid of the
logicism of Principia and the logical insights of TLP. My task here is to
explicate that project and show how it failed.
7.1 Tractarian Logicism
Tractarian Logicism follows from a commitment to two theses:
A. Mathematical truths are tautologies in the Tractarian sense of
tautology.
B. Identity is not a real relation; it cannot be taken as a primitive of the
system, nor is Russell’s definition of identity adequate.
Taking each of these in turn:
Mathematical truths are tautologies.
For Wittgenstein, all and only logical truths are tautologies, where a
tautology is a truth-function of elementary propositions such that its
truth-value for any argument is true. That is, a tautology is a proposition

174 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
formed by the recursive operation of the logical connectives upon prop-
ositions such that the resulting proposition is true irrespective of the
truth-values of its atoms. Thesis (A) then amounts to the endorsement
by Ramsey of two thoughts: first, following Russell, that mathematical
truths are logical truths, but contra Russell, that logical truths are not to
be characterised by their generality; and second, following Wittgenstein,
that logical truths are tautologies, but contra Wittgenstein, that math-
ematical truths are tautologies.2 That mathematical truths are tautolo-
gies explains both their epistemology and their role in inference about
ordinary propositions concerning matters of fact. One consequence of
adopting this notion of a tautology, a consequence to which Ramsey
draws our attention, is that if mathematical truths are tautologies, it
must be the case that they are ultimately reducible to truth operations
on propositions.
Identity is not a real relation.
Thesis B is a central tenet of TLP, and it is endorsed by Ramsey in FoM.
Wittgenstein seems to adhere to an even stronger claim, namely that
identity is indefinable tout court. In a letter to Ramsey regarding the defi-
nition of identity that he puts forward in F oMM, Wittgenstein asks him to
assume that ‘a’ and ‘b’ have different meanings.
Now although we know that ‘a’ and ‘b’ have different meanings, still
to say that a = b cannot be nonsensical if a ≠ b is to have any sense. For
if a = b were nonsensical the negative proposition would be nonsen-
sical too, for the negation of nonsense is nonsense. (McGuinness
2012, p. 159)
Wittgenstein’s condensed point conceals a remarkable argument.
Consider a Tractarian world, in which all the simple objects are neces-
sary existents. Then, if one succeeds in producing a definition of the
symbol ‘=’ which captures its intended use (by which I mean its use as
a sign which refers to a relation that every object necessarilyystands in to
itself, and only to itself), any sentence in which ‘=’ occurs ought to have
a sense – in particular, sentences in which names for simples flank the
‘=’ ought to have a sense. Assume now that ‘a’ and ‘b’ name the very
same simple. Assume also that ‘a = b’ has a sense, where it is a minimal
requirement on some proposition p having a sense that there is at least
one world in which p is true and at least one world in which p is false
(i.e. p is neither a contradiction nor a tautology). If ‘a = b’ has a sense,
then ‘a ≠ b’ must have a sense. But now, if ‘a ≠ b’ were to have a sense, it

The Foundations of Mathematics 175
would have to be the case that there was a possible world in which ‘a ≠ b’
was true. But such a world would be a world in which there was an addi-
tional simple. Since such simples are necessary existents, if it existed in
that world, it would exist in all worlds. In that case, ‘a = b’ could have no
sense, since there would be no world in which it were true. By r eductio,
neither ‘a = b’ nor ‘a ≠ b’ have a sense.
One might wonder, as Ramsey once did, whether ‘a = b’ might, rather
than being n onsense, simply be senseless, a tautology when ‘a’ and ‘b’
name the same object and be a contradiction otherwise. But if it is to
be a Tractarian tautology, then ‘a = b’ must reveal itself to be a truth-
function on atomic propositions: as we shall see, this is the route that
Ramsey attempted to pursue in F oM.
According to Wittgenstein, an expression of the form ‘a = b’ does not
indicate anything about objects; it merely indicates that the signs ‘a’ and
‘b’ are to be used interchangeably. And since Wittgenstein conceives of
mathematics as consisting of pseudo-expressions of just this form, his
early philosophy of mathematics is limited, not least of all because that
impoverished view of the nature of mathematics restricts mathematical
sentences to equalities ( TLPP 6.2). But as Ramsey rather mildly points out
in CNN,
I do not see how this account can be supposed to cover the whole
of mathematics, and it is evidently incomplete since there are also
inequalities, which are more difficult to explain. (C NN, p. 282)
Wittgenstein’s argument against identity will hold quite gener-
ally for any attempted definition of identity, where what we are
trying to capture is what I have described as the intended notion,
thus supporting the stronger version of B. But the argument is quite
misguided as against the definition Ramsey will propose in F oMM since
he is explicitly not aiming to define a quite general notion of identity
but rather aiming to fix a meaning for the symbol ‘=’ as it occurs in
Principia; the use to which that symbol is put, namely that of defining
classes, is not one that requires the full resources of the primitive
notion of identity.3 That is what Ramsey means when he writes of his
system:
By using these variables we obtain the system of Principia Mathematica,
simplified by the omission of the Axiom of Reducibility, and a few
corresponding alterations. Formally it is almost unaltered; but its
meaning has been considerably changed. ((F oMM, p. 56)

By ‘formally unaltered’, I take it that Ramsey means that the syntactic

of course, the removal of the Axiom of Reducibility, and the introduc-

which changes Russell’s definition of identity. Ramsey’s proposed defini-
tion of ‘=’ reinterprets the sentences of Principia that contain the symbol
and, as a result, also reinterprets certain other sentences, particularly
those which quantify over classes. In particular, the contexts in which
Ramsey wishes to provide a meaning for the sign are those where it is
used to define a class which is, to use Potter’s phrase, essential.

What reasons did Wittgenstein have, then, to endorse NC? To under-

a logical notation. For Wittgenstein, ordinary language is perfectly
in order; in fact, it is in perfect logical order ( TLPP 5.5563). What this
means is that it is not the job of a logical notation to provide order
where before there was none; I need not create a language in order to
acquire one that is logically perfect, since the language I am using this
very moment already satisfies that requirement. This is quite at odds
with the way in which both Frege and Russell conceived of a logical
syntax; for the former, the B egriffschrifftt was to be a language in which
the laws of the most general of the sciences, logic, could be expressed,
ordinary language being too vague and indeterminate to execute that

‘Mr. Wittgenstein is concerned with the conditions for a logically perfect
language’ since, for Russell, ordinary language is ‘always more or less
vague, so that what we assert is never quite precise’(TLP, p. x.). Russell
is wrong with regard to the first claim, but as to the second, there is
no doubt that Wittgenstein was sensitive to the i mprecision of natural
languages. The job of a notation is to ‘avoid such errors’. We
make use of a sign-language that excludes them by not using the
same sign for different symbols and by not using in a superficially
similar way signs that have different modes of signification: that is to
say, a sign-language that is governed by l ogical grammar – by logical

allows us to uncover the logical structure of our ordinary talk. But if
our ordinary talk is indeed logically perfect, then its logical structure,
once exposed, cannot be in any sense i ncorrectt; in particular, it cannot
be the case that there should be the possibility of constructing proposi-

governed by logical grammar cannot permit such constructions. And

not governed by logical grammar and that more work is to be done. So
we conclude that if the inclusion of a particular sign in a notation yields

functions of individuals to be that of functions in extension; but the
range of functions of function to be that of predicative functions.
(ibid., p.56)
The reason for this is that the classes defined by functions of func-
tions are readily given extensional definitions without appealing to the
notion of identity since the equivalent of identity between functions is
mere equivalence.
A final piece of evidence in support of this view is a result that Ramsey
appears to see as a virtue of his modification of the definition of identity
in P rincipia, but which also quite clearly refutes any claim to the effect
that Tractarian Logicism is a form of logicism. Indeed, in conceiving
of PFEs as akin to choice functions, logicism has been left far behind.
Unlike propositional functions which are conceivable as components
of a logical apparatus so long as ‘logic’ is sufficiently widely understood,

The Foundations of Mathematics 197
PFEs understood as mathematical functions clearly have no such status.
Ramsey notes:
If by ‘class’ we mean, as I do, any set of things homogenous in type
not necessarily definable by a function which is not merely a func-
tion in extension, the Multiplicative Axiom seems to me the most
evident tautology. (ibid., p. 57)
According to Ramsey, the Multiplicative Axiom (MA) – the Axiom of
Choice – is neither a tautology nor a contradiction in the system of
Principia, since according to the notion of class therein used, the class
defined by a choice function on some class of classes would itself have
to be eliminable via predication. Further, we can provide a model for
Principiain which the axiom comes out as true and another in which it
comes out as false (ibid., p. 58).
Ramsey takes it as obvious that MA is a tautology in his system. But
why should that be? One explanation is that if we understand PFEs in
the way that I have suggested, then Ramsey has assumed an informal
version of the axiom. In labelling MA a tautology, Ramsey is catego-
rising it amongst the laws of logic. But that is plausibly a mistake on any
serious account of what a law of logic is to be, and so Ramsey’s system
fails to satisfy the requirements of anyy logicism, including a Tractarian
Logicism.
What F oMM illustrates is that Ramsey’s thought in 1925 was shaped by
a desire to use aspects of the theory of TLPP in order to secure a founda-
tion for mathematics while rejecting what he saw as inferior conclu-
sions drawn by Wittgenstein about the nature of that subject. In respect
of identity, Ramsey invoked an inflated ontology of entities of dubious
coherence: PFEs. In respect of the infinite, Ramsey neglected his own
CNN account of propositions in favour of realism, and he optimistically
judged that the work of grasping an infinite conjunction or disjunction
could be delegated to certain features of the symbols used to express
them. In the next chapter, I shall defend the hypothesis that it was his
engagement with Hilbert’s E ntscheidungsproblem which led to his aban-
donment of such an unrealistic view.

8
Logical Revolt
The last chapter was concerned with explaining and criticising the realist
theory of mathematics that Ramsey held in 1925. That theory required
a bloated ontology of functions, individuals and propositions, sufficient
for a supposed logicism from which the Multiplicative Axiom emerged as
a logical truth. By 1929, however, it is clear that Ramsey must have given
up this position, having abandoned the Tractarian account of generalisa-
tions (at least for infinite domains) in favour of a view on which gener-
alisations are expressions of rules that govern particular judgements. It
is clear that once this move is made, something must also be said about
the nature of generalisations in mathematical contexts because these too
appear to range over infinite domains. Yet each of the arguments that
Ramsey gives against the realist construal of generalisations in the empir-
ical case are readily transposable to the mathematical case.
It has been suggested by several commentators that Ramsey, in this
period, underwent a conversion to formalism or finitism. 1 There are,
prima facie, two things wrong with such a claim. In the first place, both
formalism and finitism are distinctively mathematical theses. We have,
however, much evidence to show that these mathematical theses did not
attract Ramsey, and we have no evidence at all for how Ramsey might
have extended the thoughts expressed in his late papers to the mathe-
matical case. In the second place, the very notion of a conversion implies
a sudden and possibly non-rational leap from one view to another. Even
rejecting the claim that it was towards finitism or formalism that Ramsey
moved, the abandonment of the earlier view remains unmotivated by
reason. What is needed is an answer to the question, why did Ramsey
give up the Tractarian view of generalisation in the first place? I shall
here try to fill that lacuna; the explanation I shall give will make no
detour through finitism or formalism of any form.

In the second part, I shall make a case for the following claim: it

particular, was unsupportable.
8.1 Ramsey and Hilbert
In 1922, Hilbert held that there could be no secure foundation for infini-
tary arithmetic in the absence of a reassurance that the quantificational
inferences that were valid over finite domains were valid also in infini-
tary domains. The then widespread characterisation of such claims as
infinite disjunctions (sums) in the case of the existential quantifier
or infinite conjunctions (products) in the case of the universal quan-
tifier guaranteed that such a justification would not be forthcoming.
But unlike the intuitionists, Hilbert did not doubt the validity of these
inferences over infinite domains – he did not seek a revolution in math-
ematical practice. Instead, he sought to find a method of securing these
infinitary inferences by using resources compatible with purely finitary
reasoning:
Our task is precisely to discover why and to what extent we always
obtain correct results from the application of transfinite modes of
inference of the sort that occur in analysis and set theory. The free use
and full mastery of the transfinite is to be achieved on the territory of
the finite! (1922, in Ewald 1996, p. 1140)

8.1.1 Generalisation
In his ‘Mathematical Logic’ ((M L), an article in which Ramsey presents his
most sustained treatment of Hilbert’s formalism and Weyl’s intuitionism,

addition or multiplication applied to infinitely many arguments.

variable has an infinite number of values, if, that is to say, there are

infinite algebraic sum or product, is initially meaningless and can
only be given meaning in an indirect way. This seems to me to rest on
a false analogy; the logical sum of a set of propositions is the proposi-

8.1.2 The (cid:2)-operator
Ramsey’s engagement with Hilbert was neither fleeting nor restricted to
a discussion of Hilbert’s objections to the Tractarian account of quan-
tification. It is evident from his notes that Ramsey undertook a serious
study of Hilbert’s views, without at any point being convinced by them.
One area of especial interest is his discussion, contained in his unpub-
lished notes, of Hilbert’s (cid:2)-operator, for the objections that Ramsey
makes in the course of his thinking about the operator reveal the extent
to which he remained both wedded to the Tractarian view of logic and
unimpressed by the formalist aspects of Hilbert’s finitism.
Ramsey makes two distinct criticisms of Hilbert’s introduction and use
of the (cid:2)-operator. The first concerns the question of the general mean-
ingfulness of the operator given the context in which it is introduced,
and the second concerns the use that Hilbert makes of the operator, or
a variant of it, in the construction of his version of the multiplicative
axiom. I shall here focus only upon the first line of attack.
Ramsey remarks that ‘Hilbert’s (cid:2) function is sheer nonsense, though
good sign substitution’ (1991a, p. 181; H L 004–04–01). But why is the (cid:2)

fixing a role for that expression within a number of sentential contexts
of a certain kind. There are very familiar Fregean reasons for regarding
such definitions with suspicion, reasons which Frege articulates against
