8.2 The E ntscheidungsproblem
The E ntscheidungsproblem, or the classical decision problem, in its
semantic version, is this: for some well-defined formal language L, is
there an effective procedure which would determine of any well-formed
formula Sof L whether or not S is valid (that is, true under every inter-
pretation of its non-logical components)?1 3
The recursive rules for constructing formulae in the kind of language
under consideration ensure that it is always decidable whether or not
some formula constructed from the vocabulary of that language is
well-formed. One way of ascertaining a positive answer to the decision
problem would be to produce an effective procedure whereby, for any
such formula, we are able to establish, in a finite period of time, whether
or nott it is true under every interpretation of the non-logical compo-
nents of the formula. Additionally, in order to qualify as effective, such
a procedure should be mechanical, in the sense that a solution to the
question of the validity of some S should be attainable, at least in prin-
ciple, by a machine, or a person acting purely mechanically, following a
finite set of rules in a finite number of steps.
The completeness of the various proof calculi for first-order predicate
logic assures us that that language is positively decidable, in the sense
that if S is valid, we will be able, mechanically, to produce a proof of it.14
But, as Quine remarks, ‘a proof procedure is only half a decision proce-
dure’; while we can mechanically ascertain a positive answer for any
valid formula, the proof procedure does not deliver negative answers;
that is, it cannot tell us of some sentence that there is an interpretation
upon which it is false (1950, p. 214). If we wish to show that, we must,
in general, rely upon imagination and so conjure up a counterexample,
a situation in which the formula in question would not be true.
In David Hilbert and Wilhelm Ackermann’s 1928 G runzüge der
Theoretischen Logik, they stated that the E ntscheidungsproblem, the clas-
sical decision problem, ‘may be designated as the main problem of math-
ematical logic’. They were not alone in recognising its importance to the
burgeoning field of mathematical logic: Bernays and Schönfinkel called it
‘the central problem of mathematical logic’,1 5 while Herbrand, who recog-
nised the problem as ‘the most general problem of mathematics’ (1971,

208 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
p. 273), noted that a solution to the problem would at the same time be
‘a general method in mathematics and would enable mathematical logic
to play with respect to classical mathematics the role that analytic geom-
etry plays with respect to ordinary geometry’ (ibid., p. 188).1 6
The language of propositional logic is effectively decidable in that
there is always a mechanically constructible, finite truth-table for a
sentence in that language which will determine, for every assignment
of truth-values to its propositional variables, whether or not there is
such an assignment upon which it is false and therefore whether or not
it is valid. Likewise, if we consider a restricted first-order language that
contains only monadic predicate letters (i.e. predicates which take just
one argument), then, given certain effectively implementable syntactic
transformations, a similar procedure is available.17 The same holds for
second-order monadic languages. 18
With regard to non-monadic first-order languages, the strategy adopted
by logicians throughout the 1920s and in early 1930s was to segment
the possible sentences of the language by syntactic type, to attempt
to show relations of reducibility between types and then to consider
the decidability of the class of sentences that emerged from such
categorisation.1 9
Developments in the discovery of a number of reduction classes
provided logicians with a direction for their research, while work on
particular soluble classes revealed methods that might be applied to more
intractable cases. The main reason for this division of labour, however,
was negative: as a formal definition of an effective procedure was not
available, the only way to resolve the decision problem for some class
of sentences was by providing a decision procedure for that class. That
is, until Church and Turing published their papers proving the i nsol-
ubilityy of the general decision problem for first-order logic, only posi-
tive solutions of restricted scope could be established. The Church and
Turing proofs (the result is now known as Church’s Theorem), which
both appeared in 1936, made essential recourse to a formal definition of

no such thing as an infinite truth-function or sentence which we could

Logical Transparency amounts to the claim that all of the logical prop-

that logical propositions, tautologies, be such that ‘one can recognize that
they are true from the symbol alone’ (TLPP 6.113). Taken weakly, these
comments may amount to a harmless claim because as already stated,
first-order logic is positively decidable: if one has a complete proof proce-
dure, then one does have, in the first-order case, a mechanical means of
determining, of some sentence, that it is a tautology if it is a tautology.
Thus, the third quote above is strikingly similar to Quine’s remark that ‘the
usual dependence on luck and strategy in finding proofs is merely a price
paid for speed: for anticipating, by minutes or weeks, what a mechanical
routine would eventually yield’ (1950, p. 214). However, it does not seem
right to read this comment so weakly. In the first place, Wittgenstein could
not possibly have known that first-order logic was positively decidable
based upon the completeness of its proof calculus, since the latter result

was not proved until 1929 by Gödel. Indeed, it is highly anachronistic
to raise the idea of semi-decidability at the time of the writing of TLP. At
any rate, it is certainly not possible to give in advance a description of
all ‘true’ logical propositions, because it would then follow that one had
determined that whatever proposition was not so described was not a
tautology. But even the positive decidability of first-order logic is no such
neat affair – while the procedure will eventually terminate if the sentence
in question is a tautology, there is generally no telling in advance either
when it will terminate or, indeed, thatt it will terminate – that is, that the
sentence is, after all, a tautology. Further, Wittgenstein also holds that ‘in
a suitable notation we can in fact recognize the formal properties of prop-
ositions by mere inspection of the propositions themselves’ (TLPP 6.122).
One such property might be whether or not a proposition is consistent –
that is, whether or not there is an interpretation under which it is true. If
that is what Wittgenstein had in mind, and if he meant by ‘inspection’
anything like a mechanical procedure, then that is a serious flaw in his
logic and a contravention of Church’s Theorem.
It thus appears as though Wittgenstein, and as a consequence Ramsey,
may have held a philosophical, if not formal, commitment, perhaps not
wholly articulated, to the effective decidability of (at least) first-order
logic.2 4 Hilbert and Ackermann’s E ntscheidungsproblem thus pressed the
challenge of determining a formal justification for that philosophical
article of faith.
Ramsey’s provision of a decision procedure in PFL is concerned with
a semantic formulation of the decision problem which varies from,
but is nonetheless equivalent to, the one that I gave at the beginning
of this section. He focuses upon the question of a decision procedure
which determines whether or not a formula in the relevant language is
consistentt – that is, whether there is an interpretation upon which it is
true. Further, he is interested onlyy in sentences which contain at least
one instance of the identity function, for which we further require that
the procedure determine the sizes of domains which, if there are any at
all, satisfy a sentence belonging to this class.
The procedure is itself a wholly syntactic affair; it is made up of a
series of mechanical steps, each of which expands a previous sentence
into a new sentence which is co-satsifiable with its predecessor. Each
expansion of the previous sentence greatly increases both the length
and the complexity of the sentence. Nonetheless, the result of the series
of expansions is that when one reaches the final stage, one may see
whether a sentence is or is not satisfiable on a domain of a certain size
simply by l ookinggat it.

Logical Revolt 213
While the procedure is relatively simple, showing that such transfor-
mations preserve satisfiablity is not trivial. What is, however, of greatest
importance is that showing that the presence of a certain syntactical
structure in the final expansion of the sentence is equivalent to satisfi-
ability in infinite domains requires recourse to Ramsey’s novel combina-
torial theorem (((PFL, p. 104). The reasoning involved in proving that the
procedure is in fact a decision procedure in the finite case is complex,
but that involved in proving it in the infinite case is highly mathemat-
ical, requiring the proof of a new and complex mathematical theorem.
For anyone who had previously adhered to the logic of TLP, and most
especially to the idea that logic is to be transparent in the manner advo-
cated by Wittgenstein, the resources required for establishing a positive
answer to the Entscheidungsproblem for even a relatively modest class of
sentences can have come only as a sharp shock.
It is not my claim that Ramsey intuited that the eventual answer to
that problem would be negative. Rather, I claim only that Ramsey’s
discovery of intractability of the problem – and certainly the discovery
that it was insoluble by anything remotely describable as ‘calculating
the logical properties of the symbol’ – resulted in his abandonment of
the Tractarian account of generality. On that view, generalisations are,
essentially, of a kind, independently of whether they implicate finite
or infinite domains. Further, the T LPP account of quantification is one
on which, according to Logical Transparency, the status in respect of the
satisfiability of the proposition in question is something that must be
calculable from the symbol alone. How it is so calculable is revealed by
the generalisation that shares its sense with a truth-function of (possibly
infinitely many) elementary propositions. But what Ramsey must have
seen through his own engagement with the decision problem for the
class of sentences with which he was concerned was that no such view
could be the correct one for sentences the satisfaction of which require
infinite domains. Wittgenstein’s account of generalisations which impli-
cate infinitely many objects, and the principle of Transparencyy that went
with it, simply could not be correct.

conjunction is not Ramsey’s primary concern, because there are many
finite conjunctions which are unsurveyable also. And yet, nowhere does
Ramsey suggest that generalisations over domains of finite yet unsurvey-
able cardinality fail to express propositions. Let’s take Ramsey’s example:
would the contingency of Cambridge’s enjoying a population of 108 7,
rather than 105, force upon us a different account of the meaning of

224 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
‘Everyone in Cambridge voted’ simply because the world might be over
before everyone’s name had been uttered? In focusing upon unsurvey-
ability, the move that Holton and Price make to global scepticism about
propositions is a natural one, but it is a direct consequence of a confla-
tion of the infinite with the unsurveyable. For instance, in G P&C, one
way in which Ramsey brings out, in the course of objection (2b), the
difference between the two cases of generalisation is by appeal to a belief
as a map which ‘remains such a map however much we complicate it or
fill in details. But if we professedly extend it to infinity, it is no longer
a map; we cannot take it in or steer by it’ ( GP&C, p. 146). So no matter
how we complicate a finite proposition – how far we extend it, how
many conjuncts we add to it, even, presumably, if we extend it beyond
the stretch of any idealised mortal’s lifespan – it remains a map with a
role to play in inference and cognition. When we entertain the thought
that there are infinite conjunctions, however, we must admit that we
have made a mistake; such a proposition simply could not play the role
that is required of it.
The difficulty is this: If ‘(x)ƒƒx’ expresses an infinite conjunction, then
we are owed an explanation of how it is that we grasp the conditions of
its truth, given that its truth-value is a function from the truth-values of
infinitely many conjuncts. For any finitely long conjunction, we have,
of course, the requisite understanding – we have grasped its truth-con-
ditions if we grasp the truth-conditions of each of the conjuncts. And
this is always, in principle, a possibility. But in the case of an infinitely
long conjunction, that process – of grasping the truth-conditions of
each conjunct – is not a possibility even in principle, and so we have
no conception of its truth-conditions, and thus we have no grasp of its
meaning.
It is precisely this notion of a completed operation over infinite
operands that Ramsey sought to defend in the period during which he
accepted the Tractarian view. As I discussed in Chapter 8, Ramsey wanted
to draw a distinction between an infinite logical sum or product and an
infinite arithmetical sum or product, where the latter is conceived of as
a function, without ever succeeding in explaining the basis upon which
such a distinction could be made. In F oMM, he held that a propositional
function specified a set of propositions and that ‘we can, by using an
appropriate notation, assert the logical sum or product of this set’ (((F oMM,
p. 8). How it is that we are in a position to assert, or to be understood
as asserting, a completed logical sum or product that is by definition
incompletable is not discussed until 1927’s F &P, where Ramsey invokes
a new, but no less mysterious, idea:

Generality, Rules and Normativity 225
Feeling belief towards ‘For all x, fx’ has certain causal properties
which we call its expressing agreement only with the possibility that
all the values of fx are true. For a symbol to have these causal prop-
erties it is not necessary, as it was before, for it to contain names
for all the objects involved combined into the appropriate atomic
sentences, but by a peculiar law of psychology it is sufficient for it to
be constructed in the above way by means of a propositional func-
tion. (((F&P, p. 153)
What could this psychological law be, and how does it succeed in
forging a connection between the specification of an infinite set of
propositions via a propositional function and the capacity to assert or
understand the application to infinitely many arguments of a certain
truth-function? While what we see in 1927 is an inadequate answer,
it is also, and more importantly, the recognition of a question previ-
ously obscured. And Ramsey’s unease grew, until in 1929, following his
engagement with the Entscheidungsproblem, he was prepared to assert
that ‘the theory of general and existential judgements is the clue to
everything’(CQQQ, p. 261). That theory was one he did not live to attempt
to resolve. What he did do, as we have seen, is suggest a positive theory
of generalisations over (possibly) infinite domains, one which, as we
saw in Chapter 1, denied propositionhood to such generalisations in
the Tractarian sense.
9.1.4 Wittgenstein and the infinite
Wittgenstein later made several remarks about the way in which he and
Ramsey had thought about quantification and the difficulties presented
for that treatment by an infinite domain, remarks which were recorded
by Moore. There are, in particular, two which are worthy of attention
here. Moore writes (A) that Wittgenstein said he
had made the mistake of supposing that an infinite series was a
logical product – that it couldd be enumerated, though we were unable
to enumerate it. (1955, p. 4)
And (B), Wittgenstein also said:
There is a most important mistake in [the] Tract[atus]. ... I pretended
that [a] proposition was a logical product; but it isn’t, because ‘ ... ’
don’t give you a logical product. It is [the] fallacy of thinking 1 + 1 +
1 ... is a sum. It is muddling up a sum with the limit of a sum.7

226 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
In the P hilosophical Remarks, Wittgenstein writes that ‘you can’t talk
about all numbers, because there’s no such thing as a ll numbers’ (((P R,
p. 147), and that ‘it isn’t just impossible “for us men” to run through
all the natural numbers one by one; it’s impossible, it means nothing’
(ibid., p. 146). But why should we say that there is no such thing as all
the numbers?
Wittgenstein’s concern in Section XII is to investigate the ways in
which the concept of infinity is tied to a conception of possibility that
is neither logical nor physical, but rather grammatical. Talk of infinity
in the case of the natural numbers is to be understood as talk about
the nature of the rules of the symbolism for forming a particular kind
of expression, the numerals. Asserting of the numbers that they are of
infinite cardinality is an attempt to say of the rules for forming expres-
sions of number that they block a certain possibility with regard to the
construction of numerals, namely that there should ever be an end to
such construction.8 And it should be noted that the impossibility of
completion is not to be understood as relating to the finite capacities
of human beings, nor the finite magnitude of the universe’s material,
spatial or temporal resources:
The rules for a number-system – say, the decimal system – contain
everything that is infinite about the numbers. That, e.g., these rules
set no limits on the left or the right hand to the numerals; this is what
contains the expression of infinity. Someone might say: True, but the
numerals are still limited by their use and by writing materials and
other factors. That is so, but that isn’t expressed in the rules for their
use, and it is only in these that their real essence is expressed. (((PR,
pp. 160–161)
The kind of possibility with which infinity is associated – a grammat-
ical possibility – is a possibility contained within the structure of our
symbolism. As such, it is a mistake to think of the grammatical possi-
bility of the unconstrained nature of numerical expressions as being
akin to the kind of possibility which is to be contrasted with the actual.
Wittgenstein noted that the word ‘possibility’ was not perhaps the most
perspicuous in this context, since ‘someone will say, let what is possible
be actual’ (loc. cit.), and it is precisely this move which leads to error.
If we consider the function m =2n, Wittgenstein’s account requires him
to say that it follows from the rules for the symbolism that, for any
numeral, n , m =2n correlates it with a number m – that is, that ‘m=2n’
‘contains the possibility of correlating any number with another’. But

Generality, Rules and Normativity 227
that is not to say that there is any sense to be made of the claim that
m=2n doescorrelate every number with another: ‘In the superstition that
m=2n correlates a class with its subclass, we merely have yet another case
of ambiguous grammar’ (loc. cit.). The slide from one sense in which
m=2n correlates each number with another, namely that the rules of
the symbolism permit the construction of a new symbol as value from
any other as argument, to the other, in which m=2n carves up the set
of numbers into ordered pairs, results from the way that Wittgenstein’s
notion of a grammatical possibility conflicts with the ordinary concep-
tion of possibility, which c an be contrasted with the actual. Ordinarily,
if it makes sense for me to say that it is possible that such-and-such
could be the case, it also makes sense for me to say, perhaps falsely, that
such-and-such is the case (ibid., p. 162). But in the case of a grammatical
possibility, while it is possible that there are infinitely many numbers,
insofar as there is no grammatical constraint on the number of numerals
allowed by the symbolism, it does not, merely on the basis of the sense
of this claim, make sense to say that there are infinitely many numbers.
The inference from the former to the latter is illegitimate, a case of our
being led astray by the language that we use to describe the rules that
govern our talk of number.
The notion of an actual or completed infinity is then, for Wittgenstein,
a characteristic example of a grammatical error, namely that of conflating
a grammatical possibility with the more robust modal notion. Consider
the natural number series, which Wittgenstein takes to be given by the
symbol ‘(1, x, x + 1)’. This symbol encodes the rule that governs our talk
of number, and the occurrence of the variable ‘x’ expresses that feature
of the concept number – namely that no matter its value, no matter how
large the number, we can always form a further symbol ‘x + 1’ which
yields a greater number. The symbol contains the possibility of infinitely
many numbers since the rule that it expresses places no bound on the
construction of numerical symbols. We can, of course, legitimately char-
acterise the natural numbers as being infinite so long as we are clear that
we are expressing a feature of the rules governing our symbolism. The
slide to be avoided is from using the term ‘infinite’ in connection with
some concept in order to ‘exclude nothing finite’, to using the term in
order to characterise the cardinality of the extension of that concept –
that is, the use of that term as standing for a number (ibid. p. 157).
Evidence that Ramsey and Wittgenstein at least discussed this view of
the infinite is provided by a document, written in German, contained
amongst Ramsey’s papers.9 It has been suggested that Wittgenstein
dictated these notes to Ramsey in preparation for a talk on infinity that

228 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
he gave to the Aristotelian Society in 1929 in place of ‘Some Remarks
on Logical Form’, which he refused to deliver.10 The document consists
of notes in German, interspersed with occasional asides in English, and
it concludes:
Infinite p ossibility is represented by a variable which is such that the
possibility of its being filled is without limit; and the infinite may not
occur in the proposition in any other way.1 1
For Wittgenstein in 1929, mathematical objects are nothing more than
the permanent possibilities of certain symbolic operations: our grasp
of the meanings of mathematical statements can be explicated only in
terms of the possibilities of such operations, governed by the appro-
priate grammatical rules, such that our grasp of a mathematical concept
is wholly exhausted by our grasp of a certain rule.
Returning to the two quotes from Moore, it should now, in the light
of what has been said about the Philosophical Remarks, be clear that
Wittgenstein’s criticism of the Tractarian account of quantification is
not located where Holton and Price suspect. (A) is not an objection
to the idea of the possibility of an infinite enumeration that we could
never succeed in completing but rather that such a conception, that of
a completed infinite, is the result of a grammatical mistake. This objec-
tion is even clearer in (B): the fallacy of thinking that ‘1 + 1 + 1 ... ’ is
a sum is the slide from noting the possibility of infinite extensibility
contained in the symbol to thinking that there is a completion of the
symbol, some number that its completion would represent. ‘1 + 1 +
1 ... ’ is the limit of a sum insofar as it is what every increasing finite
completion of that symbol approaches; to say that it is a sum is just the
mistake that we noted above, namely that of thinking that infinity i s
a number.
If we think of a universal quantification over an infinite domain as
expressing an infinitely long truth-function, namely conjunction, then
we must think of our grasp of the proposition that it yields as being
the completion of an infinite process. But the grammar of conjunction,
even as it is discussed in T LP, rules out such a possibility. There, truth-
functions are called operations, and what differentiates an operation from
a function is that, while an operation can take as its argument whatever
its value is for some other arguments, a function cannot. Operations,
unlike functions, are such that there is no grammatical restriction upon
their completion; it is presumably for this reason that Wittgenstein saw
them as a fitting base for our grasp of number.1 2

Generality, Rules and Normativity 229
To say that there are infinitely many arguments for some truth-func-
tion such as conjunction is merelyy to acknowledge that the grammar
of the symbolism for that operation fails to constrain it by imposing a
completion. It is always possible that a conjunction should take a further
proposition as a conjunct, without plunging from sense into nonsense.
But it is a mistake to think that since it is possible that the operation of
conjunction may be infinitely iterated, there is any sense to the thought
of that possibility’s being actualised, of the notion of an infinitely long
conjunction having any sense at all. That is why it is a mistake to think
of such a truth-function yielding a truth-value, just as it is a mistake to
infer from the grammatical possibility of ‘1 + 1 + 1 ... ’ being infinitely
extensible to its being a sum. Universal generalisations over infinite
domains thus cannot be truth-functions of elementary propositions,
and thus, they cannot be propositions at all.
In TLP, Wittgenstein envisages the application of the NNN-operator
to a class of propositions as a single operation; in the case where the
domain is infinite, this would mean the single application of an opera-
tion to an infinite class of operands. It might be thought that this way
of conceiving of the NNN -operator avoids the difficulties to do with the
grammar of conjunction that I have raised above. After all, on this
conception, no infinite process is invoked. Indeed, conceiving of it in
this way satisfies a maxim of the TLPP that ‘all propositions are results of
successive applications to elementary propositions of a finite number of
truth operations’ (T LPP 5.32). Here we have no restriction on the number
of elementary propositions to which such operations are to be applied,
only a restriction on the number of operations that can be involved in
the production of a proposition.
This point, however, evades the difficulty raised by using the expres-
sion ‘single application of an operation to an infinite class of operands’
without saying to what this amounts. Consider the natural numbers:
I might sayy that applying the function ‘+’ to a set N that consists of
every number was not to invoke an infinite process as it is the single
application of an operation, albeit to an infinite class. But what would
be required of me to grasp that sum, were it even recognisable as a
sum? Likewise, what would be required of me to grasp the proposition
expressed by the single application of the NNN -operator to an infinite class
of operands? Surely nothing less than the completion of an infinite
process, namely the grasp of the truth-conditions of infinitely many
finite conjunctions.
The difficulty does not lie with the specification of an infinite class of
operands: in that case, while I cannot enumerate the operands, I may

230 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
specify them by giving a function: ƒƒƒx . The difficulty lies, rather, with the
attempt to perform an operation upon the members of that class and
the attendant expectation that what results will be something complete,
a proposition. There is nothing wrong with saying that it is possible to
conjoin infinitely many propositions, so long as what is meant is that
the grammar of conjunction imposes no completion upon its use, just
as there is nothing wrong with saying that it is possible to sum infi-
nitely many numbers, so long as what is meant is that the grammar
of ‘+’ imposes no completion upon its use. What is wrong, however, is
to think that either possibility is of the kind which is to be contrasted
with the actual. In the latter case, this leads to the conclusion that the
equation has a solution of a certain sort, and in the former case, it leads
to the claim that the meaning of a universal generalisation might be
an infinite conjunction. The confusion rests upon an illegitimate slide
between two meanings of the word ‘possible’, between the grammatical
use and the modal use, the first of which is independent of the notion
of the actual and the second of which is not.
9.2 Rules and normativity
I wish to end this book by discussing, admittedly speculatively, where
I think the instability of the views adumbrated in Chapter 1 lies and
how addressing such an instability can be traced into the later work
of Wittgenstein. While I think there are many external objections that
may be made against that view, I shall restrict myself here to an internal
criticism which arises in the course of considering the extent to which
the invocation of psychological laws might yield a robust account of
meaning.
9.2.1 Philosophical Investigations §81
At PII§81, Wittgenstein writes:
F. P. Ramsey once emphasized in conversation with me that logic
was a ‘normative science’. I do not know exactly what he had in
mind, but it was doubtless closely related to what only dawned on me
later: namely, that in philosophy we often compare the use of words
with games and calculi which have fixed rules, but cannot say that
someone who is using language mustt be playing such a game.—— But
if you say that our languages only approximate to such calculi you are
standing on the very brink of a misunderstanding. For then it may
look as if what we were talking about were an ideal language. As if

Generality, Rules and Normativity 231
our logic were, so to speak, a logic for a vacuum.—Whereas logic does
not treat of language—or of thought—in the sense in which a natural
science treats of a natural phenomenon, and the most that can be
said is that we c onstructt ideal languages. But here the word ‘ideal’ is
liable to mislead, for it sounds as if these languages were better, more
perfect, than our everyday language; and as if it took the logician to
shew people at last what a proper sentence looked like.
All this, however, can only appear in the right light when one has
attained greater clarity about the concepts of understanding, meaning,
and thinking. For it will then also become clear what can lead us (and
did lead me) to think that if anyone utters a sentence and means or
understands it he is operating a calculus according to definite rules.
This comment appears before Wittgenstein’s long discussion of what
it might mean to say of someone that she is following a rule and the
extent to which our so saying might provide an insight into the nature
of meaning; nonetheless, I take it to be connected to those considera-
tions. That discussion has been subject to multiple interpretations, and
a number of authors have sought to locate its focus in a range of places
within the text. What I wish to concentrate upon here, however, are
two contrasts that Wittgenstein draws our attention to and the kind of
misunderstandings that each may draw us into. I shall develop these
into a criticism of the view I attributed to Ramsey in Chapter 1.
What might Ramsey have meant in describing logic as a normative
science? One aspect of such a view is described in Chapter 1; there, I said
that one reason that Ramsey has for rejecting Wittgenstein’s early ‘scho-
lasticism’ is that the view of inference that he takes to be presented in
TLPP eliminates the normative role that he envisages for philosophy: the
idea that philosophy ‘must be of some use’ if it to be taken seriously (((Ph.,
p. 263). On the Tractarian view, if one’s inferences do not track certain
internal relations between facts, then one was not inferring after all; if
one’s thoughts do not picture a possible fact, then one was not thinking
after all. To reuse Ramsey’s metaphor, according to his understanding
of TLP, Wittgenstein’s view is like saying that if one breaks the rules
of bridge, it is not that one is now playing bridge b adlyyor incorrectlyyor
illegitimatelyybut rather that one is now engaged in an entirely different
activity, that of playing not-bridge. C orrection is not an activity internal
to a game but a transition from one kind of enterprise to another.
Ramsey’s view in G P&C appears to be one which seeks to address this
perceived shortcoming. There, the aim of language, or parts of it at least,
is not to picture facts but to order our cognitive lives in response to a

232 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
regulative constraint on enquiry captured by the belief that there is one
‘true scientific system’ to which long enough investigation will lead us
(GP&C, p. 253).13 Generalisations, however, are only one instance in
which the meaning of an expression is given not by definition but by
paying attention to ‘the way in which they are used’, explanations in
which ‘we are forced to look not only at the objects that we are talking
about, but at our own mental states’ (((Ph., p. 267). This element of self-
conscious reflection yields an account of the meaning of expressions
characterised not only by reference to parts of the external world but
also by an acknowledgement of the circumstances in which we find
ourselves willing to assert sentences that involve that expression, the
expectations such assertions give rise to both in the speaker and in the
audience and the undertakings and further beliefs that such assertions
commit us to: in other words, ‘to a multitude of performances’ involved
in the idea of our understanding a word (ibid., p. 264).
What we are left with is a view on which grasping the meaning of an
expression involves knowledge of a range of circumstances not only in
which one would assert sentences that involve that expression but also
in which such circumstances would be correct – that is, knowledge of a
rule for the use of that expression. The comparison with a game is thus
quite natural in that the picture is one upon which the workings of a
language (or at least parts of it) are like the workings of a game, bound
by rules which establish a distinction between correct and incorrect uses
of an expression, and correct and incorrect moves in the game. Logic,
the task of which is to uncover and, indeed, to improve upon those
rules, is thus readily conceived of as a normative science, ‘part of the
vital work of clarifying and organising our thought’ (loc. cit.).
There are, I think, two related criticisms that Wittgenstein hints at
with regard to the remark that he attributes to Ramsey, both of which
one may see developed in the course of the rule-following considera-
tions. The first relates to the thought that in comparing the use of words
to a game with fixed rules, one cannot say that a speaker mustt be playing
such a game. And the second pertains to the notions of normativity and
of idealisation, the thought that one might construct a perfect system of
logic or rules of thought against which our natural languages come up
short and to which we ought to aspire. I shall take each of these, very
briefly, in turn.
9.2.2 Rules and games
In his comment regarding the idea that we cannot say that someone m ust
be playing a game in accordance with a certain set of rules, Wittgenstein

Generality, Rules and Normativity 233
draws our attention to two features of the picture that he takes to be
false. On the one hand, there is the temptation to say that someone
who appears to be proceeding in language according to fixed rules must
be playing according to those rules – a temptation to which he takes
himself to have succumbed. And on the other, there is the denial of the
claim that we are tempted to make – that is, the denial of the claim that
necessarilyy someone (including myself) who appears to be proceeding
according to those rules could not be doing something else.
The latter feature may be readily interpreted as connecting to or antici-
pating certain consequences of the rule-following considerations. There,
we are told to imagine the student who is learning to add 2. We have
shown her a sequence, and she appears to have grasped it, performing
the operation successively just as we would expect. At some point,
however, she returns an unexpected answer, moving from 1000 to 1004.
At every stage before 1000, however, her answers are in accordance with
our own. The student here does not take herself to have made a mistake:
if we explain the operation to her once again, she will say ‘Yes, I under-
stand, but how have I gone wrong here?’ Perhaps we show her how to
continue the sequence beyond 1000, but we now wonder how she will
proceed at 10,000. What differs between we, the teachers, and she (the
student) is not a matter of arithmetical error but rather a disagreement
in judgement about what it is that she ought to do when we tell her to
continue to perform the operation in just the same way.
One question with which Wittgenstein is very concerned is that which
asks ‘What has gone w rongg here? And in virtue of what is it wrongg?’ I shall
not address that here; rather I wish simply to focus on the feature of the
story which gives rise to some discomfort, which is the thought that had
the student not got as far as 1000, we would have simply said that she
had grasped the operation of adding 2. By luck, we did not release her
at 500, and so we spotted an aberration in this case – but it was only by
luck. If the meaning of an expression is to be given by a rule or rules,
and if understanding that expression is a feature of common grasp of
those rules, could it not, therefore, always be the case that apparent
accord between speakers is only ever apparent, that there is always the
possibility of future discord? The uses of an expression governed by a
rule or rules will always outrun its actual use by any given speaker; are
we not then in the position of never being able to judge whether an
interlocutor does mean by an expression what I mean by it?
If, however, we are still in the position of thinking of language as a
calculus, then we do want to say that someone proceeding in a certain
way must be doing so according to that calculus because to deny that, or

234 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
so it seems, is to give up the possibility of discourse. The situation we are
left in when we conjoin these two considerations appears impossible.
We introduced the notion of a rule to present a picture of meaningful,
discursive language as like a game or a calculus, with permissible and
impermissible moves recognised by all players in accordance with those
rules, that knowledge constituted by their grasp of the rule. We did so in
order to replace a certain view of meaning, one on which grasping the
meaning of a sentence is given by grasp of its truth-conditions, which
appeared to be unrealistic in certain cases. And yet we have lost all trac-
tion on the very idea of our fellow players following the rule that one
takes oneself to be following; after all, what could assure one that one’s
fellow players have grasped just those rules? There is nothing that I
could witness which would assure me that my interlocutor will proceed
in every circumstance to use an expression as I anticipate myself
proceeding in those circumstances (and, indeed, I cannot anticipate
how I would proceed in everyy circumstance). And so there is nothing to
assure me that she means what I mean (or take myself to mean) by the
expression in question.
I argued in Chapter 2 that there is no requirement to attribute to
Ramsey the claim that one ought to be able to articulate to oneself what
rule it is that one is following, or, to use his phrasing, what psychological
law or laws one takes to be governing one’s use of an expression. Rather,
implicit knowledge of those laws is evidenced by explicit knowledge of
how one would react or what one would say in some hypothetical situ-
ation. But note that even such knowledge is undermined by the kind of
considerations with which Wittgenstein confronts us because if we follow
Ramsey in holding that counterfactual claims are not truth-conditional,
then presumably we must treat such claims exactly as we treat the claim
the meaning of which we were originally seeking to account for in terms
of psychological laws. That we are disposed to say that in such-and-such
a situation we would assert (cid:18) as a result of our holding that, for instance,
in all cases of (cid:17),(cid:18), is itself a fact governed by a psychological law. There
is no inference per se occurring here, at least not an inference of the kind
such that our conclusion follows logically from what it is that we take
ourselves to accept, but rather a further psychological law according to
which we take it that in that situation we would assert that (cid:18). This is, I
think, closely connected with (if not identical to) the criticism made by
Cora Diamond, and also discussed in Chapter 2.
Coordination between two speakers of finitely many actions, responses
or expectations is not sufficient for identity of rule. Likewise, coordina-
tion in articulation of the actions, responses or expectations speakers

Generality, Rules and Normativity 235
would take themselves to encounter in a hypothetical situation or situ-
ations is, in itself, insufficient to ensure identity of rule since these very
responses are supposed to be given according to mere psychological
laws also. If one takes as a basic starting point that meaningful discourse
must be based upon common understanding amongst speakers of the
meaning of expressions, then it appears that Ramsey’s view attributes to
speakers knowledge that they cannot have. That is, it is no more realistic
than the Tractarian account of general propositions (or, indeed, of infer-
ence) which was the original target of the criticism.
9.2.3 Normativity
I think that the above considerations present something of a barrier to
Ramsey’s contention that philosophy should have a normative role,
that it should correct our thought and speech. If we are looking to our
practices to resolve or dissolve philosophical questions, then into what
space or by what means can any notion of normativity discoverable
by the philosopher enter the picture? One sense in which that is quite
obvious arises from considering how one might correct someone for
having gone wrong according to a rule if one is without the capacity to
determine either what rule it is that they are following or what rule it
is that one takes oneself to be following. Of course, some correction is
possible in some cases; the person who, for instance, claims to hold that
every case in which (cid:17) obtains, (cid:18), but who then asserts not-(cid:18) on some
occasion in which (cid:17) obtains has clearly gone wrong in respect of her
understanding of the generalisation or some part of it, at least relative
to my or our understanding of it. But just as no series of co-ordinations
of activity can determine the coordination of a rule, so no correction of
particular instances of activity can determine correction of a rule: even
after the injunction to assert (cid:18) in such a situation has been issued, there
is always the possibility of disagreement in future cases.
This kind of case is a case of attempted correction of the practices of
an individual relative to the practices of another. But I do not think that
this is the notion of correcting that Ramsey envisaged for philosophy.
Rather, it seems that what he had in mind was a deeper sense of correc-
tion, namely that philosophy should clarify our thought and talk by
determining w hich rules we ought to follow, which psychological laws
or dispositions would be the bestt or c orrectt laws or dispositions for us to
develop in respect of our talk and thought.
However that notion of the b estt or c orrectt is to be characterised, it
seems that in order to be consistent with the realistic spirit as character-
ised in Chapter 1, it cannot be elaborated by reference to anything like

236 Frank Ramsey and the Realistic Spirit
an external, pre-existing standard. Such a view would be one which,
like the views criticised, continued to render our practices answerable
to an independent, sempiternal measure of correctness, our grasp of
which would remain cloaked in mystery. That is a picture towards
which Wittgenstein might be gesturing, if only order to dismiss it, one
in which there is some perfect or ideal way of proceeding which our
ordinary ways of going on only approximate. The idea of logic as a
normative science might then have as its aim the uncovering of such a
calculus so as to direct our existing linguistic and inferential practices
towards it.
I have already mentioned what appears to be the utter hopelessness
of the idea of correctingg a linguistic or inferential practice that is charac-
terised in terms of psychological laws, a hopelessness arising from the
failure to ever detect whether such a correction has indeed occurred. But
that does not yet show that there could not be c orrectt practices, practices
that it would be best for us to adopt. When Wittgenstein says that if we
reflect upon the nature of meaning, understanding and thought, ‘it will
then also become clear what can lead us (and did lead me) to think that
if anyone utters a sentence and m eans or understands it he is operating a
calculus according to definite rules’, he comes very close to the criticism
that I attributed to Ramsey in Chapter 1 with regard to inference and
bridge-playing. But whereas Wittgenstein ultimately comes to question
what we could possibly be asking for when we ask for a clarification of
the idea of better or worse ways of organising our linguistic and inferen-
tial practices, I think that within the context of Ramsey’s thought, there
are means by which that question might be answered. Recall that, for
Ramsey, the very notion of enquiry is underwritten by an assumption
that long enough investigation will yield up a ‘true’ scientific system
(which may, however, not be uniquely determined). Given such an end,
it would seem that there would be better or worse psychological laws
that we might adopt to govern our practices of induction and asser-
tion. That is, one can envision manners in which an enquirer might go
better or worse with regard to arriving at such a system – the strawber-
ry-abstainers discussed in Chapter 1 constitute just one such example.
Their failure, in adopting a poor rule of thought regarding the effects
of strawberry consumption, is a failure to correctly enquire and thus a
failure to arrive at the rule of thought which would belong to the best
scientific system.
My aim in this final chapter has been to begin the task of drawing
connections between the realistic spirit, as I have found it in Ramsey,
and the later work of Wittgenstein. Underdeveloped though they might

Generality, Rules and Normativity 237
be, I hope that they serve at least as a prompt to begin a re-evaluation
of Ramsey’s contributions to the philosophy of the 20th century. More
generally, it is my hope that working through Ramsey’s philosophy
in a manner which seeks to uncover a systematicity in his work will
contribute towards a reawakening of interest in this great philosopher
and, indeed, in the very idea of a realistic philosophy.

form constitute at least a prima facie plausible case for semantic continuity?
In which case, isn’t the onus on Ramsey to show that there is something
wrong with proceeding as though such a continuity exists? In response, I
should say that the expression ‘prima facie’ is doing some illicit work here.
